reviewText:
It's 2016 Capcom. Only having Xinput support on release when several large vendors of controllers/fight sticks/fight pads use Dinput is completely unacceptable. 2/17/16 Edit:

reviewText:
As a long time Street Fighter fan I can not recommend this. The reason why... I can only explain it like this:

Imagine for a second that your favorite restaurant for making omelets was called Capcom. Over the years Capcom has made you the best damn omelets you can imagine. Some of them not as good as others, but generally speaking they are damn good omelets.

However, today, you are promised the best and newest version of your favorite omelet. You are as excited as can be after ordering it, but after only a few short moments the chef comes out with an egg in one hand and a plate in the other.

To your surprise the plate is set in front of you, and the chef just takes the raw egg, and cracks it open onto the empty plate in front of you.

The ♥♥♥♥ is this?" You ask.

Capcom replies "O trust us

reviewText:
Disappointing.

-Launch day server problems are expected these days as they are so common. I'll give a free pass on that even though consumers *shouldn't* accept this practice, especially after so many betas.
-The game is content light. Yes, this was known prior to launch but the multiplayer is supposed to be enough to carry it until this stuff is added later...except the multiplayer is currently jacked up.
-Keyboard remapping...is currently non-existent. Yes, there are third party programs to get around this problem. No, I do not expect to need them for a full priced release from a company as storied as Capcom.
-My fightpads...the game doesn't recognize them.
-My sticks...the game doesn't recognize them.
-bugs present in the betas are still here in the release.

This is...honestly, it's just pitiful. I've been playing Street Fighter since the first game hit the arcades here in 1987 when I was a child. I say this to say that I hold Capcom to a certain standard as a long time fan, and this release falls woefully short of their prior standards. This game is currently a full priced release without half of the content of previous fighting games in the series or of its contemporaries (Story mode, trial/challenge mode, a proper arcade mode, etc.), without proper support for fighting controllers/sticks, without basic PC quality of life features like key remapping for a keyboard.

This game isn't currently worth the price tag. Perhaps it will be somewhere down the line, as there's a decent core game here wrapped up in a shoddy package with a premium cost. Unless you have an abundance of disposable income there are better offerings for your hard earned currency.

my initial review 2016-02-16

I cannot recomend this game as of now because of constant problems with the game's server and lack of absolutely basic options such as rebinding the keyboard keys. The game lacks an arcade mode, lacks trials.It is also worth noting the game's system requirements are way too high for such a primitive graphic design. Not only do the game's textures look worse than USF4 but also it runs much worse. The loading times are also very long compared to USF4.
Until the game has been fixed I do not recommend you buy it unless you want to get frustrated.

reviewText:
The game is not finished. It lacks alot of the content.
Let's use sf4 as the base example, SF5 lacks

1: Basic keyboard remap, you can't remap your desired keyboard controls. if you play with a keyboard, just don't bother

2: No arcade mode. some people don't care about an arcade mode, but alot people do, it's a great mode to play casually and testing out ur combos in semi real combat versus AI, but the game doesn't have it

3: No trial mode. The game lacks a trial mode that exsited in almost every fighting game that has been released after 2003, and it's a great mode to learn characters and basic combos, yet the game don't have it.

4: You cant really invite your friend to play with you at the moment, it asks for a fighter ID where requires you to login into the CFN(capcom fighter network), and the function is not avaliable yet, so playing with your friend is not possible.

5: varies missing features such as the store is not even implemented yet.

6: lots of fight sticks are not supported yet like the old games did, so if u have a fight stick and wanting to play this game, better check with the forum and see if ur stick is supported.

this is what I found so far, will be updating this review if I find more issues or if capcom fixes these issues.

Way to ♥♥♥♥ up an release of you most anticipated game this year, capcom

reviewText:
Alright, I'm just gonna start off by saying that I really enjoy the core gameplay in SFV. It's very fun, the cast feels pretty balanced even though Capcom has only released one DLC char (Alex) so far, the mechanics such as V-Skill and V-Trigger make the game more interesting, and overall when things are working, they work really well in my opinion. I'm actually having a character crisis right now because I personally haven't found a single character that I don't enjoy playing. All that aside:

Since this game was being rushed out for tournaments (under Capcom Pro Tour, to be specific), there were going to be things missing from the game at release.  This is what I and plenty of others expected while playing in the beta, but what we got at release was a mess that turned people away from the game and gave SFV a lot of bad press. And unfortunately, a lot of the bad press is still justified.

Some examples SFV's issues:No D-Input support and no way to  configure keybinds without using third party programs (which makes no sense, since this game is ONLY released on PC and PS4. Why is there little PS4 controller support & no keybind configuration in the game from the jump??)

Arcade mode no longer present, and has been replaced (?) with story mode" and Survival

Story mode is just 4 or 5 easy

Today's Review: Street Fighter V

First things first, i'm gonna write down all the aspects of this game that i consider positive and negative so you understand why i don't recommend this game, at least at its current state.

Overview: SFV for all of those is one, if not the biggest, fighting franchises of the world, developed by Capcom, that, for some reason can't stop letting us down due it's many bad desitions when it comes to... everything, that should really is a well deep balanced game, but that's about it, after USF4 we've come to expect something new and better, and was pretty clear for me that in the beta, this game wasn't going to be that, it's pretty much the same that USF4 when it comes to core mechanics, now a lot of ragging capcom fanboys and sf fanboys will be offended that i compare the mechanics of each game, well, changing the buttons for the combos is not my idea of a next gen fighting game, it's more like we honestly have no idea

reviewText:
To call Street Fighter V disappointing would be giving it undue praise. Calling it a joke would be inaccurate, because there's nothing funny about it. It baffles my mind that anyone could look at this game and think it was ready to be sold for $60. This game is an insult to everyone; Street Fighter fans, fighting game fans, and video game fans.

Looking past the inexcusably absent modes (Arcade, Trials, 1P vs. CPU, etc.) what we do have is just pathetic. Character stories consist of 2-4 matches with braindead AI and lousy artwork. Online is currently broken. There's stuttering out the ♥♥♥, and it can take up to 10 minutes to find a match. Ranks can't be trusted, since there's zero penalty for quitting matches. For some insane reason, you don't pick your character on a character selection screen. Instead, you have to choose a favorite, and that's who you play. I don't know who the genius was who thought this was a good idea, because it's not.

The biggest insult, however, is Survival mode. ♥♥♥♥ Survival mode. You have to play this mode to unlock colors, and it's the worst grind I have ever experienced in a game. You play against a set of AI, which until the end basically just stands there while you destroy them. Then when you're close to beating it, the AI turns on ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t mode and reads your inputs, reacting to things no human could possibly react to. Not only does this mode waste your time, but it teaches you bad habits, which causes you to get destroyed online (if you're lucky enough to find a match). I'm almost certain that Survival is like this because they intend to sell the colors in the shop in March, so they can squeeze more money out of the poor individuals who already spent $60 on this catastrophe.

The worst part about Street Fighter V is that at it's core, this is one of the most solid fighting games I have ever played. When you have a match with a decent connection with someone at your skill level, it's about as fun as Street Fighter gets. It's too bad that you have to dig through the mountain of ♥♥♥♥ to find the gold.

I do not recommend this game.

reviewText:
For starters, I have been a long time player of street fighter, 24 years or so. My review will change when they actually release the game, in it's current state its an early access and a shiny polished turd, is still a piece of crap. There is no reason this game should be advertised as a full release when it is not, I don't know if it was because of presure from investors like sony to have it out at this date, but Capcom you done screwed up.

That mess out of the way, I will say from the games engine, the fighting mechanics I do really like where they are taking it, it feels like a step back to older street fighter and playing more on skill rather then a well timed ultra-combo. Changes to the characters are refreshing, my 2 favorite characters Vega and Ken have changed in ways I actually like and when this game is fully up and running I feel it has great potential.

I am past the point for the steam refund policy and I probobly wouldn't because I do support some early access and I would just get it after it was fxed anyways, but I can't fault those who want to send capcom a message for this, if they had pushed back release date  and opened it for early access I would be less ♥♥♥♥♥♥, but this is not a full release quality game, and this isn't the 1st time Capcom has pulled BS with things like on disc DLC to site one example. Look Capcom, you are getting to a place where you can't screw up like this without taking your company down, for your sake I really hope this gets squared away. For the time being I am going to have to down vote, when the game meets the following I would say I could recommend it.

1. Fix your servers, while some issue on this front are understandable, what we have here is not.
2. Proper Controler bindings, I don't play with keyboard but I have heard a number of gripes and I have to say, the fact it dosen't recognize all my XBOX 360 controler inputs like L3 and R3, coincodently also available on PS$ controllers, should be mappable.
3. Display optimization, I have finally got it to a point where it is palletable with 60 frames and I am not the only one seeing this, now I don't have the worlds best video card, but I can run some serious games with out this much issue and I have seen a number of posts complaining about this so I know it's not just me.
4. Get a proper single player experience going, where the heck is the traditional arcade mode, with your servers dropping like crazy, this would at least satisfy some players, your story mode while nice so I can get the story is a cake walk. Not saying we need this to be difficult, it's nice getting the story especially for characters we are not good at but this is not a substitute for a real arcade mode, you know the thing that has been there since SF2 World Warrior. And you cant count survival, you loose one time and you have to start over with the sorry starting AI, you can't get a consitant challenge from the PC making it hard to improve your skills unless you are playing people, oh yea, the servers are still dropping like crazy.
5. Challenge mode, seriously, not available until march?

Capcom, get your heads out of your rear ends. You hold the rights to some of my favorite franchises and thats why this stuff pisses me off so much with you, I want to see you succeed, quit screwing up.

reviewText:
Well, considering the first wave of updates has come, I think it's time to make a complete review out of this game. Let's divide pros, cons and also neutrals apart to make things clearer.
First of all, on many points, principal or secondary, Street Fighter V (SFV) looks really different next to Ultra Street Fighter IV (USFIV) which was for me and a lot of other people, a reference in terms of fighting. But anyway let's roll.

Pros.
►Graphism ; More colorful, smoother and even better animated than USFIV. Let's also notice the camera and effects improvements especially on Critical Arts.
►PC Gear required ; Well when they said NVidia GTX960 recommended I wasn't excepting to run this game at 60 FPS Max with 45°C degrees. It's quite overrated, so logically, you should be able to run it easily with NVidia GTX570.
►Cross-Platform ; Great idea, nicely executed. You can play with you PS4 friend online even if you play on PC.
►Gameplay ; The V-System is absolutely awesome, making this game way more offensive than USFIV. But still, I have to admit I am not okay with the Cross-up thing but I am pretty sure offensive and airborne players will love it.
►Soundtracks ; Absolutely awesome, brand new progressive metal theme and orchestral revisited themes make some really nice quality music. Let's still note that some characters or stages themes are still bad but, ugh, music taste lawl.
►Characters ; Okay, 16, now 18, maybe not enough if you compare with USFIV 44 characters roadster. But Capcom will publish returning and brand-new characters in the following months and years, so it's just a matter of time. Meanwhile, the stock roadster is still really interesting going from ultra-defensive zoner (F.A.N.G. or Guile) to heavy pressure characters (Cammy or Vega). Also, interesting characters are making their comeback like Rainbow Mika or Birdie.
►Challenges ; Less numerous than the challenges in USFIV, but those will still teach you basics and important combos options for your character.
►Tutorials ; This is an interesting concept for rookies and advanced players to make you understand the key features in this game.
►Support ; Capcom say they will support the game for 7 years and they have also confirmed they will not create a Super Street Fighter V" or "Super Banger Fighter V.2 Ultra Turbo Hot Ryu Maximum". Which means SFV should not been duplicated into different versions.
►Online Ragequitters punishement ; Looks like they added a new system to punish them
date: it will block from doing ranked matches for 2 hours
recommended:
which I think is a good punish to ragequitters.

Neutrals.
►Story mode ; Still

reviewText:
Let me start by saying that Street Fighter V is far from a bad game in terms of its gameplay and Capcom did a pretty good job with porting it to PC. I'm able to run this game at 60 FPS without any hic-ups or having to switch to the lowest settings possible playing on 5 year old hardware.

The main problem with this game comes from the spotty release. Despite having three weekend beta tests, playing online in the full release can lead to random disconnects and frame stuttering so bad that both players just start teleporting around at lightning speeds making it difficult to tell what is going on. It gets really bad if you try and play against overseas opponents, the current netcode is not fit for it. Not to mention I have had times where I’ve been disconnected while playing single player modes and forced to start over from where I’ve began while playing them.

Capcom rushed this out so they had something for people to play at tournaments, so I would definitely wait for them to fix netcode and aim for a price under the current fifty dollars they are charging.
voteText: 112 of 166 people (67%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
2/24/16: Edited for more legitimacy and less memelorditude

+The fighting system is great.  Much more accessible than IV.
+DLC that can be purchased with either in-game currency or real-type money (soon)
+Looks dang beautiful
+Online play works (much better than it did at launch.  Not one server problem for me in days)

-Only support for XInput or keyboard, which the new SFV-themed Fightsticks are not (Use something like X360CE or Joy2key if using a PS3/PS4 fightstick)
-Severe lack of single-player options (Arcade mode, Vs. CPU, etc); not worth $60 (yet)
-Has story mode, but it not very in-depth.  Feels more like a build-up to the upcoming cinematic story.
-Takes a little while to find an opponent in matchmaking (or maybe I'm just impatient)

The gameplay is good, but the overall game is severely lacking in substance.  Features that have been a staple of fighting games are absent.  Capcom has stated that such features will be available in March, but these features are what most people would expect to be available at launch.  I personally like the game, but I'm sure most people want more of a single-player experience than this game has to offer.

reviewText:
IN SHORT, for the casual player, this is not a $60 product.
For seasoned fighting game players, they probably already bought it.

It is a bummer that PS3/PS4 sticks don't work out the box
date: and commands cannot be mapped to different keys for all you keyboard warriors. However, netcode works pretty well and is a huge improvement over the connections of Ultra Street Fighter IV.\n\nIf you are looking for a Street Fighter SINGLE-PLAYER experience that can be enjoyed regardless of skill level, you will be sorely disappointed. In its current state, only buy the game if you already are a seasoned fighting game player, or you are new BUT have experienced fighting game player friends that can show you the ropes. This is a good game to learn how to play fighting games.

reviewText:
At a whopping $80 where i live:

Game feels incomplete. Does not have enough content to support the hours of gameplay a $80 game should have.
While some of the character models look great and refreshing, animations might looks stiff and snappy sometimes especially during scene transitions - such as in story mode.
Story mode is sorely lacking - finished story for all the characters in less than 1 hour. Ugly art is being used to convey story elements. The 2D drawings look juvenile and rushed.
Not enough characters and nothing new to unlock after playing through.
No options to play offline/single player.

I would not recommend this game if it's at the current price. Whether its worth the money will still be questionable even if it is half the current price, given Capcom intends to sell future DLCs on top of its already steep release date price.

reviewText:
Oh Street Fighter V, where do I even begin...

Well lets start with what positives can be taken away. I only list what parts I am using because apperently YMMV drastically.

My GTX970 plays it maxed out at 1080p/60fps, its a stylized look and i dig it.
My Hori Tekken 6 Wireless Fight Stick works fantastically and natively.
I actually find the actual gameplay to be quite fun...
That last point sadly brings me to the negatives and the reason I cannot in good faith recommend the game to anyone not signed up for EVO.

There just isnt enough to do.
No Arcade mode.
No Challenge mode. Yet.
3 Fight Story mode.
Always online. (at least to earn exp and coins, which you want/need)
Busted servers (48 hours in and still struggling to get/stay online, nevermind finding a opponent)
The thing about this game is it feels like what an Early Access title should offer, proof that the gameplay is fun enough to warrant further development but lacking features to justify a full $60 price tag. What we have is the worst of both, a full price and an incomplete game. It fails to be as robust as my expectations, previous installments of the franchise or its competition in the genre.

I'll let that sink in.

Additionally, Street Fighter V lacks the following content normally found in a Street Fighter game:

Classic Story Mode (currently 3 to 4 fights per character, best out of 1)
CPU Vs. Mode
Standard Arcade Mode
No Unlockable Gallery
Challenge Mode
Spectator Mode

reviewText:
Pros:

Even though it is bare-bones right now, the fighting is a ton of fun. If you like to play people online like I do, I think you will have a good time.

Combos are easier than in SF4 and it works out nicely because you are able to get into the mind games of one on one fights much quicker without that technique barrier holding you back. The gameplay feels great. Everything about the ACTUAL game seems to be great.

The features that are missing will be added someday.

Cons:

The features will be added someday, meaning they are not here now.

The game feels unfinished already and with survival mode being the only viable 1 player option right now, it's even worse because survival mode sucks.

If they fix the complete waste of time that is survival mode I would reccomend this game. It being hard is not my complaint. It is that it wastes your time.

Example: In normal survival mode, fights 1-25 are easy, but you hit 25-30 and the difficulty ramps up hugely. So fights 1-25 just feel like a waste of time. If you lose on fight 29, you have to start all over again because its survival. Seriously, balance out the difficulty. I shouldn't be able to win fights 1-25 with crouching heavy kick. Then lose in some fight between 25-30 because the computer suddenly blocks, counters, punishes, and combos. It is the most jarring and frustrating part of survival mode.

Not to mention the fact that you have to be connected to the server while playing it or it doesn't count. Imagine getting to level 48 in hard survival mode, and disconnecting from the server. That is a lot of time wasted.

reviewText:
This is an EARLY ACCESS TITLE being sold as a full, finished, $60 product.

PROS:
-One of the most balanced, solid fighters out there
-Fun and unique cast of characters
-Movement/controls feel very solid and responsive

CONS:
-No Arcade mode
-No VS CPU Mode (only other modes are story which consists of ~4 fights, training, and survival)
-Servers are awful (At launch, servers won't connect. What were the betas for?)
-No spectator mode online
-No rematch option online
-No penalty for ragequitting
-Can't rebind keyboard (sucks if you're a keyboard player)
-Horrible clipping issues with hair going through people's chests and bodies
-No arcade stick support (or Mad Catz/any other fight pad support)
-Random crashing that was present in beta (rumored to be caused by Wacom tablet/touch screen)
-Rest of content tacked on as DLC scheduled to come months from now
-Rest of the characters being sold as extra DLC, one coming in a month proving he's already finished, cut content (which you can also use earned fight money to buy, but grinding for it will take forever)
-New costumes cost $6 (This is more than entire characters in other fighters)

Final Thoughts: This game is basically online only, which is the same thing Titanfall and Battlefront got criticized for. If you don't have reliable internet, there's scarcely any single player content here for you.

Capcom strikes again. Would request a refund but GMG won't give them after they give out keys.

Final thought: I find it interesting how many dislikes my review has even though I've laid out mostly facts (which aren't subjetive) in a concise, easy to read bulleted manner. Capcom fanboys sure can't take criticism about their favorite game I guess.

reviewText:
I'm a big Street Fighter fan and I really wanted to be able to recommend this game but.. I can't. I don't do reviews so this is probably poorly done but as it's a game I know about I felt I could put down some informed opinions. If you want a brief summary, scroll down to the conclusion.

Capcoms attempt to open the game to everyone has neglected the people who want depth in a game. If you're a die hard fan of the classic street fighter where basic is basic then sure this might be the game for you but if you want a game that's evolved and developed depth, you're better off waiting to see where they take this game or look somewhere else.

First off, the game is multiplayer. That's it, if you enjoy playing randoms or have other friends playing this then you won't mind. If you enjoy a nice little single player mode to waste some time like me, then you'll be disappointed. The single player is rushed and poorly done. Clearly a last minute thought.

Then saying that... It really feels like the netcode was a last minute idea (I'm not a pro in anyway about this subject). I would enjoy a more smooth online game play but whoever thought the netcode they've used was a good idea needs to rethink what gamers want in online quality.
If I had to choose between the small input delay of the USF4 online and the teleporting in SFV online play. I would choose a more polished USF4 online. Maybe I wouldn't care so much if it happened to both players and if it was temporary but its not. It mostly happens to the player who's defending... I don't need to explain why that's bad. Then once it starts, it doesn't stop it's there the entire match switching between whoever is defending.

Onto the characters, these have good and bad points. I do love some of the character designs and I love the new characters that have been introduced. I thought it was a great idea to have characters that have clearly aged or changed in appearance and they've tested the water with a few but left the default Ryu and a few others the same as they were back when SF started, hopefully this can be changed with new outfits or better yet, mods.

The characters playstyles are also a good idea (there is also a bad point to this in a moment), each character has their own unique way to fight, despite aggressive playstyles being rewarded more than others you do feel a difference and I like this.
The problem I have with the characters is their move/combo sets.. There is no depth, when I go to play Bison who's been my main, I already know it's going to be HK spam until I've broken the defence because that is literally his safest and only worthwhile move. Yes, against higher level players I can't just spam it I have to adapt but at the core it is just HK and that's the feeling I get with all the characters, they have one good option and one good combo.. That's it, nothing else is worth doing because it doesn't reward you for playing any different.

I do play other characters like Laura or Karin, I get bored just playing one character I like to learn all their basics then learn their more damaging/tight combos but their combos are either lacking or don't do as much damage as more simple combos I do with Bison. Which is actually a good idea and something I thought they would do. If you want to accommodate newcomers without losing the technical players. then just reward the basic combos and keep the more difficult combos. It doesn't need massively long combos but give it more than 3 parts to every combo (without the use of Vtrigger, even then that just becomes 4 parts of the combo).

The stages are also nicely made, the only downside to the stages which isn't a huge problem I'm probably just nitpicking but they're not all interactive. You have the one stage where you'll be knocked into another area of the stage or possibly knocked into a bus or get noodles on your head but that's it. It gives the impression that they spent 75% of their time on that one stage and then rushed the others.
Another issue with this is the restaurant that you can be knocked into (The other half of the stage) Is so nicely made, it gives a different atmosphere than when you're in the streets but you rarely get to see it unless you're always being pressured in the corner which anybody will know that's not where you want to be. It would be a great idea to have it switch between starting the game in the restaurant or in the streets.

To cover some points I'm seeing a lot of people make;

1: SFV has had an insane amount of people register at Evo - This should be obvious and expected, if you've stripped your game down so much to accommodate people who aren't the most skilled at fighters then why wouldn't they all want to compete for that big prize? Having depth to a game up to this point never stopped new people competing and breaking into the spotlight, Capcom shouldn't have felt the need to take such a different direction at the least they could have incorporated a way to accommodate newcomers into the evolved Street Fighter we've become so used to.

2: SFV still has depth with the Vtrigger/Vskill - You would think so but for an example, look at Biffotasty/Desks videos. Watch his SF4 videos and his newer ones for SFV. The SFV videos are plain in comparison, so much so that he's got creative by editing older SF games into the videos (Which he does so well). This isn't a dig at Desk in anyway, I love his channel and his videos you can always see the amount of effort he's put into every video. His quote in a video description of his sums it up:

It's disappointing that it doesn't but since Capcom have tried with all their might to remove absolutely anything that's even slightly situational or anything that might be considered difficult to perform
date: it's not at all surprising."\n\nAnd I'm not saying we need 100 hit combos we never did and with scaling
recommended: the longer combos in SF4 became a bit pointless. Only there to satisfy those who enjoyed the timing/technical aspect. I could give plenty of examples as to why these new simplified mechanics are a bad choice

I can't really argue this considering SFV to date has been a glorified early access. They do still have time to fix where they went wrong but the big problem a lot of people/critics have pointed out is that this was the games "full" release.. The majority of reviewers and gamers might not bother coming back to the game in a years time to do another review. It would of been a smarter decision to do an open beta/early access so people (the pros) could play the game in prep for the big tournaments without the expectations of having a fully fleshed out game.



Overall I really wanted to like SFV but I don't

reviewText:
Pros: Great graphics and well-balanced, intuitive gameplay.

Cons: Rife with errors, bugs, disconnects. In no universe should this game cost sixty dollars. Due to a lack of content, it should, at most, be worth 35, and I think that's being generous. I'm a massive fan of fighting games, and I was hoping to see our community and the fighting game market grow due to the potential success of this game. It is evident now that this will not happen, due to Capcom essentially fumbling with the FGC's most anticipated release since vanilla SF4 (also having a projected sales goal of selling 2 million copies and obtaining only 1.4 marks this as a financial failure, your potential purchase aside.)

If you're uncertain and want to try this game, I would suggest waiting a long, long time. Capcom simply cannot deliver currently. Sadness becomes me. *sigh*

reviewText:
=> May/2016:
Sad that the game didn't get what it deserved. My cons list is bigger than before.
- Servers are still unstable, sometimes data isn't loaded.
- After further experimenting, found that netcode is garbage, even with 4 or 5 bar connections. I hate the rollbacks and teleports, along with the sound cuts. It's common on 5 bar connections to have animation frame skipping, which mess up the moves timing.
- Input lag is high.
- Rage quitting is still not properly punished.
- Keyboard and some sticks still aren't supported. That's some extreme lazyness on the board.
- Game still doesn't remember the battle request and training mode settings.
- Graphics has lots of clipping. Super ugly.
- Matchmaking is unoptimized, keeps matching with the same person and matches tiers/leagues that are too far away, for example Ultra Gold vs Silver. Also, still gives 1 bar connection opponents even if you chose 5 bar.

=> Feb/2016:
I was always a SF fan, since SF2. It's sad that this game hadn't the launch it deserved:
- Unstable servers
- Unreliable matchmaking (1 bar connections regardless of chosen settings)
- No keyboard support
- No support for all fighting sticks
- Game doesn't remember some settings (battle request and training mode)
- Rage quitting is not punished (with points withdrawal, for example)
Some of these alone make the game unplayable for a lot of people.

Make no mistake, though: this game is good. But what are nice graphics, awesome sound, interesting mechanics good for if you can't play the game properly? As for the netcode, it could be better: it is good at 4 or 5 bar connections, but not good below that.

Hope the game RISE UP to what it really deserves. Until then I can't recommend it, sadly.

reviewText:
Disappointing. Not Worth It.


Pros.

*Strong Core Gameplay.

*Amazing Graphics.

*Sounds Good

*Fun



Neutral

*Story Mode 2-3 single round fights long, pretty bad, but updates to  improve this have been promised.

*No Arcade Mode.

*Survival becomes VERY boring and tedious VERY fast.

*Colours for costumes are obtained by completing survival..



Cons

*Problems with ONLINE PLAY (which is what this game is about, unless you have friends (unlike me:'{) who will play locally.

*Big Lag issues, if you're playing with anyone below connection status 5 = trouble, even with connection status 5 you will likely sometimes have issues.


*Lag matches are unplayable.

*Very limited choices when searching for other players, only choice is between connection status and weather you want to play vs PC or PS4 players or both.

*You will be waiting a long time for an opponent, especially if you choose a higher connection status.

*Random disconnects from opponents, random disconnects from server. Not very frequent but they still happen.

*The Client will randomly just close For NO REASON. No explanation.



Conclusion

For me at least, everything could be looked past as long as the online gameplay was solid. It simply is not. The updates so far have not helped at all.

I waited to not give this game a bad review, I wanted to give it a chance with some updates, but still simply put, not worth it.

reviewText:
Personal Experience
Written at 2016-02-17
Some issues might be fixed at later date, this review won't be updated.

Pros
-Decent optimizaion/port for Capcom game.
-Simple, quick to learn, difficult to master game mechanics.
-Multi-play IS VERY FUN, provided that you can find a match within 5 to 10 mins, and play decent amount of game without disconnection.
-Cross server play!

Cons
-Personally find the game to have too little character.
-Server issues (Can't find match, frequent disconnetion).
-Needs 3rd party software for reconizaion of some external devices.
-Lacks off-line content (coupled with server issues, a ciritical at the moment).
-Personally don't think the game has 70 dollors worth of content, 110 dollors if you pre purchased season pass.


Personal conclusion.
If you are an absolute fan of street fighter and MUST play the game right at this moment, get it.  The game has a huge potential.

If you are not an absolute fan of the street fighter, but is looking for a good fighting game to play, hold off this game for now and get Guilty Gear xrd" "Mortal Combat"

reviewText:
Oh boy, Capcom. Now let me get this out of the way. From a technical standpoint this game is fine. I get a solid 1080p 60fps at high settings with my gtx 960 with no frame drops. The controls are great and responsive and the gameplay is already better than IV. With that being said here are the problems.

-Barely any content to justify the $60 price tag
-a majority of fight sticks do not work
-fight money and exp can't be earned offline through story and survival meaning that if the servers are down (like they are at the time of this review then you shouldn't even bother with either mode)
-The story is extremely short even by fighting game standards. All characters stories can be completed in 40 minutes.
-no spectator mode
-only two player lobbies
-no cpu vs cpu in versus mode as well as no player vs cpu battles outside of survival for the latter.

The game is great and fun to play but I would hold out until march or June when it has more updates. Once Capcom adds more content I'll change my review but until then hold off.

UPDATE:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5DCTDZVP3dg
A video of my experience when first booting up the game.

reviewText:
No Story mode, No Arcade mode, No VS CPU, No Trials, No Punishment for Rage-Quitting, Severely simplistic combo system, lenient input windows, terrible lack of optimisation, inability to change graphics settings without ♥♥♥♥ing up the fps and basically a beta that cost 40 quid - Not a great start

The V-Skill system is cool, the new characters are a welcome edition, graphics are nice and despite it being made even easier to get into than SFIV, it is still enjoyable as a fighting game, though I don't see it being half as popular as SFIV, i'm struggling to see the potential in it.
I could see this becoming like SFIII and killing Capcom's plans for future fighting games for the next decade.

Buy it if you want, convince yourself it's a good deal to get a multiplayer beta for full retail price and just wait it out for the standard modes to be added as DLC, but really all ya doing is reassuring a big company that they can get away with pulling off this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, releasing an unfinished product at full price is a ♥♥♥♥-take, and unless people are vocal about it and it hurts their sales, more and more big game developers will start to release unfinished products for full retail as the accepted normal.

Love Capcom, but the launch of this game is an utter ♥♥♥♥ show.

reviewText: This is my first negative review on here, this game was released Svery prematurely, I personally didn't have a heap of issues with the beta like I do in the full game. Now I did go in with the knowledge that the servers may be a bit wonky since the game is now public, but this is far MORE than just wonky. I don't understand how games that came out a long while ago(Battlefield Bad Company 2, Call of Duty 4, STREET FGHTER 4!! etc.) never had nearly the amount of problems that this game has. Street Fighter works with 2 people, that's all there is to it. Battlefield is a game that has a CONSTANT UPDATING ENVIRONMENT, that game when it came out ran great! This is a very unacceptable practice from any developer especially Triple A. Also, the limited amount of content doesn't really bother me since I'm more about trying to 1v1 and that's about it. But for people that actually enjoy single player content, this is just terrible, really really terrible. No challenge mode? Even Street Fighter IV had challenge mode at launch...Get it together Capcom, this was your chance to redeem yourselves, but you blew it!

reviewText:
TL; DR: You purchase this game to admire main menu, nothing else works properly.

I can't recommend this game as is. Capcom should be aware of everything after so many betas and testings, I feel like I've bought a teaser of the actual game.

Ok, let's go to the reasons of my bad review:

Networking issues after launch are common and understandable, but not addressing them in a period of 24hrs is unacceptable.

Not having an arcade mode is simply... NOT STREET FIGHTER.

Lounges are there and not greyed out simply because PRETTINESS, Lounge doesn't work.

You receive notes and prizes as you play, but you can't know what they are because they havent been launched yet.

Story mode... Story, what story mode? OH THAT SINGLE FIGHT I JUST WON??? Yes son, thats the story mode, not the tutorial.

Resolution... it will take about 10min to set your resolution to 1920x1080 GL;HF

If you play on a Keyboard, you cant rebind keys

NO DIMPUT SUPPORT OMG WTF BBQ

Textures are not quite the same as the trailers...

Why would I recommend this game?

The main menu looks gorgeous. Seriously, it does.

reviewText:
Pros:
-in depth and balanced fighting system
-very skill and reaction based
-requires practise

Cons:
- connection problems
- high price
- offline mode not fully released
- online connection is not always stable

Overall: 9/10
Great fighting game, you buy it for the multiplayer anyways.However, cost of the game is not justifiable, they need to charge gamers a reasonable price and not just expect us to pay top dollar for an incomplete game.
I feel like im playing a sport, practising in training mode and developing muscle memory for a skill. Then going to a game to put it to practise. Then there's buying the right gear i.e. Controller or an Arcade Stick. It was a good experience, especially since it was my first fighting game.

reviewText:
Game is worth about $20 and costs about $60, $90 for the people that want all the costumes and colors without ridiculous amounts of work put in.

Pros: Fun game
Good competitive game

Cons: Latency ruins any competitive play online
Latency actually changes what punishes and combos can be done
Matchmaking system makes no sense
Matchmaking system is actually designed to keep your rank low
Matchmaking system ignores connection settings
Sometimes non-laggy games will randomly drop (I assume Capcom's fault)
Periods of time where it becomes impossible to find a match online
Time from finding a match until you fight is too long
Forced to pick 1 favorite character to play for casual and ranked for some reason
Lag switching is very real and sometimes effective
In-game money is made 50 per win and it takes 70k to buy Guile's map (just as a comparison)
Certain characters were made to be played in a very boring fashion
Zoning characters are currently top tier
Top 3 characters are pretty far ahead of the others
Shoryuken is stupidly high priority for something not easy to punish with some characters
Story is 1/4th completed if that
No arcade mode
Survival mode difficulty changes so abruptly from free wins to needing to try that you lose life easily when it changes
I'm not 100% sure but survival mode seems like RNG on what powerups you get
Survival mode is very boring and to finish extreme you need to do 100 fights for little reward
At least 50% of people online will pick Ryu
Online becomes boring as hell facing the same character so often
Ryu's story is boring as ♥♥♥♥ and yet he is still the main character
Ryu is probably the most powerful fighter and is the only one with an actual parry because lol main character
There is not a wide enough selection of fighters yet, USF4 feels like it still looms over SF5 and it will for years while they add 1 character per month
There's only 2 (maybe 1) female costume(s) that aren't ♥♥♥♥♥♥ right now
Costumes are not interesting unless you have the preorder ones or whatever they're from
Etc.

reviewText:
i was wanting to have a fighting game that would replace the street fighter iv series as my most played since street fighter ii. sad to say, street fighter v is not it.

for starters, the mechanics have been, shall we say, streamlined. i understand their intention here, to ease more players into the game, to have beginners have a much better fighting chance against veteran players. downside is that it makes a lot of the characters, for the bread-and-butter combos at least, handle similarly. i can say that there's more than a handful characters where you can use the medium punch > medium punch > special move string very often and effectively.

but the thing is, they have indirectly drove players away from getting this. why? you've heard it - the lack of content.

i've been a long-time fighting game fan. i may not be as good as the pros, but i can say i'm an average to an above average player who can still rack up a decent win streak any time of day. i never thought this lack of content would affect me as much, because i only care about playing with human opponents. but then again, you can have the tightest gameplay and prettiest graphics (which this game both has), but if you can't bring in people to play your intentions for the game are moot.

the game is not a total wreck. it's netcode is better than ultra sf iv and the patches have made noticeable improvements (i can get opponents faster now). but i think it has suffered enough setbacks for it to not succeed. it did not make the splash it was supposed to do, and it was overshadowed by its well-documented issues. you also have to figure in the other current and upcoming fighting games (guilty gear xrd, kof xiv) that get a huge chunk of the attention pie. at this point, even if they manage to cram in more characters and an arcade or a proper story mode in there, it wouldn't do much. people may have already moved on. and we probably will be stuck by the same people that we get to play with online.

it's a game that is letdown by it's publisher's strategy rather than it's quality.

6.0/10

reviewText:
The agony of defeat. I starved and saved for a full PC upgrade to play this game. I'm now running an i7 6700k and GTX 960. Coming from a crappy AMD APU which ran USF4 just fine, this means I paid quite a bit of money to step up for SFV, and all I'm getting for it is huge microstutters, even in singleplayer (offline) modes... and on the main menu.

Adaptive Vsync, FPS locked to 60fps in RivaTuner. Feel like I've tried everything else. Wish I hadn't sprung for that season pass, by the time this game runs properly it will probly be old enough to be in the summer/holiday sales for half off.
By the way, I can't get my OSD to pop up (MSi via Rivatuner) ingame, so I can't get any diagnostics on why the train is wrecking.

I really haven't logged much gameplay. Freezing up for 2-3 seconds in the middle of a match on a competent system... it's just unacceptable. But a few things I've noticed was that it looks feature-gutted in comparison to USF4. Graphics options, benchmarking utility... amenities in SFV are about as sparse as the character roster.

And why is the announcer voice for a new online fight initiating SO LOUD no matter what you do to the audio settings? This ♥♥♥♥ is unchained.

The worst thing about Street Fighter V is that they already know how to make a game that runs properly. It's CAPCOM.

reviewText:
(Note that this review was written few days after the official release and some of the issues raised may be fixed by the time you are reading this)

It is a great fighitng game let down by other issues.

The main points:
1. To progress in the game you need to be connected to a server.  However the server connection frequently fails and thus you finally win something there is a chance of reaping the reward or getting plauged by a server connection message.  This is extremly frustrating when you are not good or new to fighting games.
2. Matchmaking, right now is very slow.  The positive side of this is you can practice playing against the computer while you wait.
3. Matchmaking is not doing a good job of putting me in matches with people of the same skill level.  I do well against the computer but then get destroyed against other people online.
4. There is very little single player content, which is very bad when the servers aren't working.  Generally I would play the single player content while I waited for the multiplayer to get fixed, but since there was so little to do I wrote this review . . . while I am waiting for them to fix the servers.
5. The mechanics are great and fun to use.
6. The graphics are very good.  My gtx970 can run it on max settings at 60fps.
7. The xbox one controller works well.
8.  While it is still up in the air, it appears like the ability to earn fight money is extremly difficult after you beat the little single player section. It feels like players who are not good at multiplayer will most likely have to pay extra to get what the store has to offer.  In other words I don't think, as of right now, you win any fight money for losing at multiplayer and
you are not able to grind fight money in the single player mode.

Conclusion: I really enjoy the game and after they fix the server, add single player and the ability to do a match against the computer I would be able to recomend it.  I hope Capcom fixes these problems and gives the people who bought the game early some sort of perk for having those who paid practically full price practically serve as an other wave of beta testers (assuming that the plan on fixing these issues).

reviewText: This game is not finished.  One of my main gripes is this new netcode.  When the latency is a little off people will start to teleport or worse, you will see your move hit and it will go back in time and instead you will get hit with something.  It completely ruins any immersion I have in the match.  Much more so than the previous delay based netcode with Street Fighter 4.\n\nAt this point I'm let down.  I stopped practicing Street Fighter 4 a long time ago in anticipation for this game and it doesn't live up to the expectations I had.  Even knowing vanilla versions of fighting games almost always have growing pains.  Hopefully this game improves enough to make me remember to update this review.  Until then I do not recommend this game unless you get the full game + season pass for $20.

reviewText:
I'm writing this review as a short review but also as a response to ZoSo, who was defending the release of this game. So let's get down to the nitty gritty of this:

This game is an unfinished product with incredible server issues on launch day. Yes, day one game releases are known for problems on release, but not being able to actually play the game is dumbfounding. Why does the server connection need to be such a priority? 16 characters is quite low for a fighting game of this caliber. Sure it means more focus on each character but if we look at what Mortal Kombat has managed to do with their roster (including X with three fighting styles per), then this is inexcusable.

The gameplay is fine, it's fun, it's the Street Fighter we know. Focus attacks are gone, and the EX meter is now a V-Skill meter, which makes for some interesting options during a fight. It reminds me of MvC3's short X-Factor boost. The prologues for the characters are what I'm currently focusing on, since I'm anticipating the intricate story mode similar to MK, and the style is quite appealing thus far. The soundtrack is nice, rock-style, and the graphics are decent, very in-tune to SFIV.

My issues with this game stretch far and beyond. To ZoSo - You're kidding yourself if you think Capcom won't re-release this game. They said that Super Street Fighter IV was the definitive version, it was the only one they'd do as far as an updated release was concerned. Then what happened? Ultra, that's what. MvC3, and within a few months what happens? UMvC3. Are we noticing a pattern here? Capcom can -say- they won't re-release but then as their current trend of business practice goes, they are the KINGS of rereleases. Resident Evil, Street Fighter, Devil May Cry, collections galore. Anyone who knows their release history can attest to this. Once all characters are released, we're getting a new version. With more stages, costumes, etc..

On the remark that Capcom released this early because of fans wanting to gear up for a tournament: This should not be $60 then. Put it out there for $30 max, and if we want the other content later on we can opt to pay the other. Keep the beta up and running, actually, that would have been much smarter, or making this early access. Fair is fair. Also, why adhere to the fans in releasing a game early? When does that ever work out? Take a look at say, Spider-Man 3. Raimi gave into the fans and squeezed in Venom, and what a mess that film became. It's fine to take suggestions but it's better to go with your guts at the end of the day. If they knew this release would be too hectic then they should have held off, tournament or not. Some fans would be disappointed but there's always next year for the tournament, and the overall consensus would have been better for this title.

Having to wait for the characters and story and other modes is pathetic. Other fighters have a core version where you have limitations but can still play the game. For free, mind you. Capcom has to be aware of this by now...yet their greedy corporation just can't wait to charge full price. The point is - they had options. There were better conditions to bring this game to the public eye, better ways to adhere to the community...they took none of these routes.

*Update*
The dev team are hard at work in fixing the server issue at the moment, so props to them for that. Still disappointed with this release, but I'm grateful for the fast action here.

reviewText:
The game is lacking a bit atm so I can't recommend it.

Once the game gets more content in the form of making online multi-player more enjoyable then I can recommend it.

Pros:

We got 8 man lobbies now, great!

Cons:

Lacks the ability to sort lobbies and match making by region/country/timezone. If I could sort lobbies by timezone or region then I'd be able to waste less time. As it is now, I have to join a lobby to see if the players in there have a good connection to me.

Lacks the ability to sort endless lobbies by ranked placement (rookie, bronze, silver ect) If I could weed out lobbies I would not want to join by only selecting... silver lobbies for example, it would make searching lobbies alot more easier.

No voice chat option, though I think it's possible to use the Steam voice chat... not sure 100%.

The roll-back netcode doesn't really work well. Laggy connections don't benefit in any way from the roll back and just make the game really unplayable. On top of that, there is no way to filter out regions you don't wish to play against. I can set the connection filter to only allow 5 bar connections and it somehow still puts me against players from outside of the US and our connections are anything but a 5 bar connection...

Conclusion:

Other than that, it looks like SF 5 will shape up to be a really great game in the future.

reviewText:
Street Fighter V does combat really well and can be very enjoyable, when it works.

But there is WAY too many issues with the game at the moment and after more than a month there's not a single word on any fix:

- constant lag and one-sided rollback in online matches, and that is to online finder limited to 5 bar (best connection) only. 70% of my online games are a lagfest since few days ago when they did 'server maintenance'. Let me remind you that this is the most basic functionality (a working online) of a fighting game that is having massive issues.
- matchmaking takes too long and there's way too many loading screens/downtime between matches. Sometimes you get matched with much better/worse players in primetime. How is that even possible, there should be more than enough players around my skill range.
- no sanctions for ragequitters. Want to keep your points after a lost match? Just disconnect. No repercussions.
- training settings not saving, you have to put them in every single time...
- no key rebinding? I have to use an .ahk script just to play with the keys I want.

The game in current state is awful at best. I really wanted to like this game and I think it does a lot of things good, but there's just too many issues and there doesn't seem to be any fixes for them on horizon.

I realize the game was released prematurely, but they should be focusing on making their game actually work instead of releasing new content.

reviewText:
Disappointing.

That is the word I would use to describe the release of Street Fighter V, which while boasting a strong core game, is essentially another phase of Beta testing that costs full price.

Amongst the many issues and lack of features, Capcom's failure to support a large number of common previous generation fight sticks is nearly inexcusable. Many recently released games of the genre support any Windows-recognized device that can register inputs, but perhaps the decision to incorporate XInput as their means to handle input devices is the real culprit here.

Don't be fooled by Full Controller Support" as a feature of this game; do your research and make sure your device will work with this game before you regret it.

Either way
date: the fact of the matter is that Street Fighter largely does not support many PS3/Xbox360 supported fight sticks
recommended: so you can either choose to shovel out some more money for a new stick or use a 3rd-party application of dubious reputation such as XPadder

reviewText:
Bought 2\2\2016
Was promised direct input support at  launch meaning it should of been added the first 2 weeks.

But still no direct input support, after all this time. Yet this game uses  the unreal 4 engine and it, does support direct input via plugins that have to be compiled into the release exe, but CAPCOM won't implment it.

To use a normal direct input arcarde stick you must use, Xbox360ce and it, increases latency + it just plain drops inputs on my hori rap 3 the alternative is joy2key and it is even worse.

Basically for me, its a 50% chance a throw will come out a Light kick or light punch, even simple ken combos are a gamble if they come out.
Can't compete with PS4 players who don't have these issues or the lucky people who have brand new x-input arcade sticks.
Avoid the game till they fix this if ever, its not like they respond to anything on the steam forums.

reviewText:
Game is fun.  Mechanics are more dumbed down than I'd prefer and characters have less moves overall.  That being said, this game is not worth $60.  It is worth MAYBE half of that.

Online play, is a HIT or MISS.  Good connection, or completely unplayable.  The lag will make opponents literally teleport around, which is ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in a fighting game.   Half of the opponents you beat simply quit after losing.  There is NO pentaly for that.

The shop is locked until march.  The challenges are locked as well.  Playing story mode and winning fights will earn you in game money.... But there is no place to spend said money. Why the hell release a game and lock THE SHOP?
There is no versus" vs computers.  Literally have to go play story mode or survival if you want to practice in a semi-realistic setting.   BTW story mode is only 3 or 4 fights vs the same characters every time.

The only real positive part is the option to que up for online ranked/casual matches while playing in story/training/survival.  Not that it matters since opponents are going to teleport or DC when match is over.

Game feels unfinshed as a whole.  Not worth."

This is as bad as MKX but at least that game launched feature complete.

reviewText:
Clay Fighter V... Seriously though, I'd hate to give this game a thumbs down because I love fighting games and I really enjoyed SFIV up until AE. But, it just let me down in a terrible manner.

When the game decides to work, it's an okay game at best. Loading times are ridiculously long, not to mention there are a crap ton of loading. Finding a match takes an eternity. The netcode is absolute garbage and breaks this game. And when the netcode is broken, you're left with an AMAZING story mode and a survival mode with FANTASTIC AI /sarcasm. Really, if you're going to release a game strictly dedicated to online, make sure that feature freaking works! What the f*ck were all of those beta tests for?!

Graphic wise, the game isn't as pleasant to the eyes as people make it out to be. I was never a fan of Street Fighter's super steroid art style for their characters. Speaking of which, Ken's model looks atrocious! There are clipping issues, the background stage's low poly, low textured, low frame rate is dreadful and very distracting to the fight that's going on. Have you SEEN the background models in Kanzuki Estate? Look at them and tell me they look good with a straight face.

Gameplay wise, it's meh.... it's okay... It no longer plays like a Street Fighter game.  Remember, this is strictly subjective. But, I feel like this game has a serious case of identity crisis. It doesn't seem like it knows what kind of fighting game it wants to be. Whereas Street Fighter IV was extremely technical, you had to play smart and very patient. This game feels super simple, non-technical and you just go balls in any time you want.

Honestly, I really wanted to give Capcom another chance, especially with the Street Fighter x Tekken fiasco. But with sh*t like this happening, I find it nearly impossible to defend this company any longer. It seems that I'll be sticking with KOF and Tekken for many more years to come. I hope in the future that this game will shape up to be something great. But for now, I wouldn't want to see a trainwreck like this as the main event at EVO.
voteText: 25 of 44 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game, but there are many problems.

I like playing games in single player, but there's just not much to do. I'm looking forward to challenge mode in a future update, but for now there is only story mode and survival mode. Survival mode is the way to unlock the colors. Story mode unlocks outfits, and it's way too easy.

The problem is if you mess up a single round in survival mode you have to start over. No matter how good you are, it takes some time to get through all those opponents (especially the 50 or 100 round sets). So it's quite annoying to lose on one of the last 3 rounds because the opponents suddenly get very strong. Or even worse, if the game server goes down (which it does often) you have to start over through no fault of your own.

Maybe the game will get better when they add more stuff. Challenge mode sounds fun. I'm looking forward to some new characters. I'm also hoping to be able to buy the alternate colors when the shop is released. I really hope that survival mode is not the only way to do it.

Usually when I find something like this that keeps me from enjoying a game, I cheat. I like to make my own trainers - but this game has anti-tampering software. So I can't even do that. All I wanted was to unlock some colors! I don't care about online ranking.

TLDRSingle player mode has only story and survival. Neither are fun. One is frustrating. Can't unlock stuff. Can't buy stuff (yet).

Unfortunately, there's really just nothing to do in the game.

UPDATE:
Even with the new updates, there's not much single player stuff to do in this game. I find myself wanting to play this, but I choose other games because there's just nothing to do unless you play other people online.

reviewText:
I honestly cannot recommend this game for the condition it's in right now. Does the core gameplay work? Probably the best it's been, to be honest, but the lack of content and the online being awful really drags this game down.

Regarding single player and general issues, there's no regular vs mode against the computer (only survival mode which drags), all stories combined takes about an hour or so, hit and miss stick support and some weird changes or decisions that is up for debate to the characters (Vega / Claw isn't a charge character anymore, Bison / Dictator is more akin to his Alpha incarnation and Ryu is the only character that can parry)

Regarding online, you're lucky to get a game on casual or ranked mode and if you do, you're more lucky to get a good connection. I can only get good connections in lobbies but then there's the issue of not gaining in-game currency in lobbies and even then, the amount of currency they give you for wins is absolutely stingy and basically forces you to buy a season pass if you want the content and don't want to waste your whole life waiting for games and slowly grinding for currency. I know Capcom said they'll be doing daily challenges soon but that still doesn't fix the issue of online being a trainwreck.

I luckily didn't pay full price (£45 on Steam, I managed to get it for £25) but I still feel a bit cheated. Once more updates come out and they fix the glaring issues, I will have no problem recommending this game.

reviewText:
A game that has potential to be great, but lacks content and feels rushed. Wait a couple of months to see if things are fixed.

No arcade mode. No VS CPU mode. No costumes. Rushed story mode - locked to easy difficulity (with only 4 fights per character). Boring survival mode. Partial 30 FPS lock i backgrounds.

It's an empty shell of a game that has the potential to become great. But it will take time. Save your money and wait - I didn't pay full price for this and you shouldn't either. Sorry.

reviewText:
There are 3 things that bug me about this game:

(1) Content -  There is a severe lack of modes and characters. For a full fledged $60 game, I would expect a lot more. Now they even have a season pass already planned, which should honestly be free for day1 buyers.

(2) Online - For a game with so few offline game modes, the online portion suffers from poorly designed netcode, making online battles laggy and frustrating. On top of that, finding a match takes FOREVER!

(3) Speed - The game has become much slower than its predecessors. I main with Ryu and dissapointingly he has become as slow as Sagat from SFIV. Another main gripe are some of the moves have been taken away from past characters, mainly Bison's Psycho Crusher... why Capcom?

Overall, do not buy this game. Obviously there will be a GOTY edition down the line with all characters and game modes. RIght now, $60 is not a fair price.

reviewText:
Now i have been defending this game like a blind idiot solely because im a giant street fighter fan! It is now wearing thin even for me how little this game came  with!!! People call it a beta but it is more like a free demo disc you would get with a magazine or something! At first i didnt care it had nothing other than training and online as it gave me time to get to know the new mechanics, learn new combos etc which i have done now but no thanks to the game itself! Street fighter games have never had good tutorials but this time was supposed to be different and was Capcoms main goal to bring in new players to the franchise. Im an experienced player and even i dont know what everything does! For example i have only just learned what a V-reversal is and even online i cant find a way to actually do them! Now the game itself doesnt make you aware of anything the V-gauge does apart from the usual brain dead ultra moves! In fact this game doesnt teach you ANYTHING that you will need ot know inb order to survive online. Yet again bare bones lazy Capcom expect you to live like the mega drive days and hunt for the secret knowledge like some sort of treasure hunt!!! Even other fighting games teach you how to play and since this doesnt it creates massive elitism within the community which quite frankly makes me sick and is poisoning this franchise which is supposed to be here for FUN!

Ok so the lack of any kind of training (other than how to punch move and jump) is bad enough but now we are gtting online turned off for whole days leaving you with nothing at all to do in the game, the store for costumes isnt out til March even though you can see the unlockable costumes on the CPU characters which is just seriously teasing you! Ken and Ryu were supposed ot be toned down in this version but yet again all the best scorers online are ken and ryus who dont even bother to learn a combos cos they dont need to with their OP specials, frame advantages etc etc, you cant even play against the CPU in versus?! No controller support for Pc other than xbox controllers even though this game is out for PS4 & PC only how does that make sense?! Online can be a mess with MASSIVE frame skipping making it unplayable, no penalty for rage quitters, no story mode at all the one they tacked onto it should have been left out as it wouldnt have been half as insulting as this piece of crap is (literaly 3/4 one round fights per character takes about 15 minutes to complete story mode with EVERY character!) and the list just goes on!

Now the gameplay itself is definitely fun and some slight adjustments have been made to make it friendler to play for new comers but not much. I love playing the game but again it feels like some characters have an advantage over others which in a competative fighting game is just pure insanity!

I CANNOT RECOMMEND this shallow embarrassing and quite insulting release of a game even though street fighter is my most beloved game, anime, manga and just in general franchise ever! Now if thats coming from a super fan what does it tell you about this joke of a release?! This seems like in another year it will be great just like super IV was to the normal IV. But how long can Capcom carry on this half arsed attempt at everything they seem to do these days? They were already struggling financially in recent years and if this is any indication to go by this may very well be the last street fighter well at least in their hands.

STAY WELL AWAY UNTIL THIS IS WORTH THE MONEY THEY ARE CHARGING FOR IT! DO WHAT THE REST OF US DIDNT DO AND SHOW THESE JOKERS THEY CANT OD THIS TO THEIR LONG TIME AND NEW CUSTOMERS BY NOT BUYING THE GAME! MAKE THEM DO THEIR BLOODY JOBS FIRST BEFORE WE GO THROWING CASH AT THEM!

reviewText:
Competitively, it is the best game I have probably ever experienced in my life. It's everything I could ever wish for in a fighting game spiritually and I feel blessed to have a chance to play this in my lifetime.

All of that said, do not buy this game. Regardless if you are a hardcore or casual, the way this game has been constructed and the lack of support around it in the first month is nothing short of an absolute nightmare. The game is still unfinished. The servers still do not work consistently. The netcode is inconsisent. There is a complete void of single player outside of a grindy survival mode and a braindead easy story mode that an infant could beat [and did, look it up].

So as of right now with as much time I have invested, unless you are an absolute die hard player like I am and have a good scene around you, do not support this shell of a game.

APRIL UPDATE:

Alex and Guile have been welcome additions to the game.

Game still has a few major issues. The ragequit punishment system implemented is not harsh enough and has not detered several offenders. This has hurt the community quite a bit and disenfranchised a part of the population.

There's also a lingering issue with there being a high input lag for the game (8-9 frames without V-Sync manually disabled through the .ini) that's made the game pretty annoying to play. No additional single player content has been implemented.

reviewText:
UPDATE: After 4 months since the launch, still no keyboard remapping. WTF!!!

What have you been doing all this time CAPCOM!?

Seriously, are you seriously releasing a game like this!?

It's even worse than the first version Street Fighter 4, NOT Super Street Fighter 4, NOT Super Street Fighter 4 Arcade Edition, NOT Ultra Street Fighter 4.

Look at what we have in Street Fighter 5 at launch:

- Story Mode: Capcom said they have done a new approach to this mode, which they actually did. Every character has more background to show, meeting and interact with other between each match through artworks and voiceover. And that's it! Still show no specific story, hard to follow what happens. Moreover, a joke of it is: ONLY 3 MATCHES PER CHARACTER!!! 3 ♥♥♥♥♥' MATCH!!! (and an epilogue) Everything ended suddenly before I could get used to the character. Oh and I couldn't adjust the Difficulties, not just this mode but EVERY ♥♥♥♥♥' MODE!!! (except training mode) I guess the default difficulty is the Beginner, 'cause I can easily got 3 perfect matches each character.

- Versus Mode: I can't play this mode at all, even though I get a spare X360 controller. No matter what I use, keyboard or the controller, I could only play as the first player and was unable to activate the second one.

- Training Mode: Hey, training mode everyone needs. Good thing it's still here.

- Ranked & Casual Match, Battle Lounge: works fine to me, except long waiting time, one match with low-connect opponent jumping around and flickering and RAGE QUIT!!!

That's it! That's what we get at launch! The rest of them contain themselves in This mode will be available as free update in March". YES! CAPCOM gives us an unfinished developing game
date: FOR 60 DOLLARS!!! What about other Features we deserve to get?\n\n- Arcade Mode: that's true
recommended: ARCADE MODE!! That's the best mode helping me getting used to the character and how to use them to fight another. And NO! the current Story Mode is a joke and definitely cannot use as an replacement.\n\n- Keyboard rebinding: YES!! I used AutoHotkey to config my usual control
hoursPlayed:
but thanks to it I couldn't activate V-Skill.

- Trial Mode: WHERE IS IT!? The mode tutoring combos for every character!?

- Tournament Mode!!!

- Turbo Mode: SF5 is pretty slow to the previous ones

reviewText:
I was nervous when buying this game because of its cost and the fact that the reviews I saw from the community were mostly negative and complained about the game. However, the reviews that were negative were given by the community, but companies like IGN were still giving this game good reviews. So if anyone is thinking of buying this game I will break down the pros and cons of this game at its current state.

First off, I have had this game for a while now and it is one of my faveorite games. Street fighter 5, in its current state, shows few signs of an unfinished game. The training mode is better than ever before in a fighting game, and the online play is smooth and in my experience has not taken over 3 minutes to find a match. (when searching for good-the best connections) Survival on hard and hell mode are both very hard, but that isn't a bad thing in my perspective.  The colors that are unlocked by beating hard mode should be seen as a prestigious reward, which you can show off in online mode.

The main complaint from the community is that the game lacks a classic arcade mode. Capcom decided to direct the game towards a more competitive audience, and decided to leave out an arcade mode to be able to release the game earlier. However, the upcoming update which will include a character and additional story content is coming soon, which will add more depth to the current story mode and give the casual players something more their style. All of the core components of an arcade mode are there, capcom just decided to leave it out. This means that it is possible for them to release a classic arcade mode in the future. The amount of characters is also something that is commonly complained about. Because capcom designed the game to be competitive, a low character roster is ideal so that the characters are all balanced, and there is no clear top tier character. That being said, the characters are all unique and fun to play, while keeping all matchups fairly balanced so that the better player will always come out on top.

This game is definitely worth the money, and I can see this game being one of my faveorites for a long time.

reviewText:
Game's got really good graphics and sounds. Stages seem to be very detailed, even including the occasional destruction of background objects. Fighting seems to have a good flow to it.

Unfortunately, the game, as it is now, is pretty barebones in regards to content in the single player side. Story mode as it is now is comprised of three fights with one round each, which is, in my opinion, too little. There's not even a basic arcade mode with 8 to 10 3-round fights like before.

Capcom also seems to have done away with a lot of supers that were avalable for returning characters. Most characters have only one super in the command list, which may have some slightly different gameplay element if done under V-Trigger. Whereas in USFIV, each character could have 3 or even more supers/ultras.

Not to mention the occasional server trouble this game gets. Why oh why does this game need to log in to a server if we want to play story mode or survival with battle requests on OFF? And why does the game need to knock you out of the fight, into the menu if it loses its connection to servers during a Hard Mode survival run (on stage 34)?

Buy it if you want the multiplayer. Or if you intend to get into eSports.

Forget about this game for now if you want single player. Gamers are better off waiting until the full story mode is released in june.

reviewText:
I'd like to preface this review with my appreciation that Capcom at least seems to be actively working on the game and communicating progress...So many other companies fail to do so and build up a terrible reputation.

Street Fighter V is incomplete. It wouldn't be right to recommend this game to anyone but hardcore enthusiasts or competitive players, FOR NOW. It's full of bugs, suffers from unstable servers and is missing important features.

The current story mode is pretty bad. The actual story is fine but the dialogue is embarrassing. I feel like it would have gone over fine as an anime, but could have benefitted from something more than just a direct translation. If you've ever watched a dubbed anime, you'll probably understand. It's also permanently set to easy" difficulty with no way to change it

reviewText:
Not yet.

Servers are beyond congested on launch night. I'm more than aware of issues with online games at launch, but it's  nonetheless noteworthy

Battle Loungues only support 2 players. It appears to still have King of the Hill functionality by moving the winner to the top of the pile, but .. you know, 2 players. That's it.

No trials for characters either, at least not that I can find. The menus seem to be a bit cluttered and clumsy to navigate (I can only Ready-Up online with my keyboard, not my fightstick for instance).

Speaking of Single Player, if you're having connection issues and wish to play offline, you won't receive any in-game currency for unlocking more stuff. Gotta be logged in for that. No animated cutscenes in Story Mode either, unless you consider a bunch of still frame drawings animated.

The game runs smooth, though. Much smoother than the beta. It even has the option of a 'Low Spec Mode' before you launch, which just automatically defaults the graphics settings to the lowest they can go. I tweaked them up to my liking, then restarted in Low Spec Mode and they were 0 again. It's probably best to find what settings work for you in the standard game so it'll actually save them, unless your computer can't handle anything above the basics.

Look, I'm not trying to crap all over the game, but I can't recommend it right now. There's a deep game in here, sure. It's Street Fighter. But hell if a new player will be able to figure out the nuances without trials. And if you wanna play with a group of friends, prepare to take turns swapping in and out of the 2-player lobbies so you can all get a turn. That's not my idea of a good time.

Maybe in a few weeks some of the stuff that should've been in the game in the first place will be included.

reviewText:
***UPDATED 02/17/2016 REVIEW***

Matchmaking now works!!  The game is good fun.  I know they will be adding more content later, but still it feels pretty bare bones.
