The mentality is still that if you pay 60 dollers for a game you get a substantial amount of content up front...not have to wait for it later.  I like how they will be updating the core game and let you get future dlc with money you can get in game.  That is a step in the right direction.  Turning off early adopters...we will see how that pans out in the long run.  I want Street Fighter 5 to do well....I don't want paying 60 bucks for a part of a game and have to wait for the rest  later to be the norm. I currently give this game 3 sad pandas and an ice cream float.

****Original Review****
This is not how you launch the 5th" iteration of a flagship fighting game.  If you want to play this game wait a few months untill the rest of it is released or find a friend who already took to plunge.  Gameplay is fun...if you can actually play the game. :/  Currently I give this game 8 sad pandas out of 10.  Which is to say it is very sad."

reviewText:
-Online not fully functional at launch. I think Capcom will eventually fix it but it's a bit unacceptable with all Capcom's experiance in fixing USF4 for online. Only had 2 matches in one sitting for an hour.

Update: I have been kicked off of Survivor Mode at least twice because of the spotty online servers. This irritated me as I was trying to beat Hell Survivor Mode and suddenly it was game over because their servers arent stable. You only get fight money if you beat survivor mode online and not offline.

-Graphically unoptomized. The game lags on settings it shouldnt for my system, (I can run Batman Arkham Knight relatively fine in full screen or windowed, USF4 was silky smooth). Toning down the resolution and playing in full screen it is still laggy and unoptomized. Game lags when its looking for players to connect to in training stage - which I think they had this problem in a build of AE or SFxT I cant remember which. Once again, Capcom might eventually fix but only time will tell. Update: I made a few tweaks to my videocard and got it running smooth at a lower resolution. Some stages still have minor lag.

-Weird gameplay decisions that are supposed to encourage casuals. As a long time USF4 player, I can assure you this game will eventually discourage casual players. I already see a new tier list forming after only a few hours of play. Capcom went into the wrong direction with this game IMO. The game feels like the older games Alpha, SF3 with a hint of SF4. Those games were not bad, this is like a hybrid of those.

-No full story mode. Not a big deal with me, I barely care about SF's story. The story eventually always seems like it was written by a 12 year old on riddlin. Characters like Birdie literally transforming into Rufus lol. Like why??

-Some of the music is terrible. Like SFxT level of annoying.

-Update: Forgot to mention crossplay with PS4. Ive had matches where characters would jerk around the screen in a way I've never seen before.

reviewText:
This review is going to change as Capcom continues to complete the content that's missing for this game.

Do you like Capcom fighting games (Street Fighter, Marvel, Darkstalkers??, etc)? Yes.
Do you like games with rollback netcode and excellent support for cross-play with console players? Yes.
Do you like playing fighting games in local sessions and/or competitively with friends and randoms? Yes
Do you like early access games? Yes.

Then buy this game now. Despite the $60/70(I'm Canadian) price tag, there is gunna be a lot of free content coming out for this game all year long which makes up for the price tag and the core gameplay is excellent in its current state.

Do you hate early access games with a barebones amount of content? Yes.
Do you dislike fighting games that seriously lack in single player content at its current state? Yes.
Do you dislike fighting games that have an option for you to grind out for free content via in-game currency? Yes
Do you think the Steam community will abandon this game like Mortal Kombat X? Yes

Then do not buy this game (as of right now). Wait for Capcom to continue developing this game more (Roughly by July). They still have a lot of work to do. As the game currently has a lack of content (No DIRECTINPUT CONTROLS, no 8 player lobbies, no SPECTATOR MODE, no proper trials/tutorial for characters, missing story mode, and many more issues regarding online features, etc).

reviewText:
In it's current state, it's as good as a free to play game...maybe even worse. There's a disturbing lack of content for a supposed AAA title, that costs 70$.

Gameplay wise, it's fun, and much faster then previous SF's. I didn't really have any issues technically with launching or playing the game. That's about all that's positive. Oh, it also looks pretty.

The story mode is incredibly thin. It doesn't really offer anything in terms of cutscenes or a compelling story. You'll find yourself skipping over all the text just to get to the next match. From there, you'll probably head to training.

Training is also weak on features. The command list is paper thin as well, and only offers the absolute basic inputs for moves. Nothing to be found for possible combos, or links, or how properties change in V-Skill, or what counters do, crush counters etc. etc. So you're left being pretty uneducated after training mode. Which is strange, because Capcom has changed a lot of things in this version of SF, and you're going to want to spend some time in training to learn it all before you go online. Speaking of online....

It doesn't work. I routinely experienced log in errors, which completely handicaps the ENTIRE game. There's almost nothing to do offline, and even when you're offline, you're required to log in to the server. So the server shuts down, and occasionally takes your game with it. Your match is dead, sometimes the game freezes, and you're forced to shut down. It's a complete mess right now and isn't worth your time.

They've promised" to fix issues
date: and update content at a later date
recommended: but the more people that buy this trash right now
hoursPlayed: will only push back that deadline. Don't buy this game."

reviewText:
The fighting engine is one of the better ones for 2d fighting games in a long time. Single player modes aside, it was clear from all the previews and promos before the game was launched that this was going to be a multiplayer focused title, as a fighting game should be.

There's in-game tools to let anybody #riseup to competitive levels.

The training mode is great, letting you set up post-grounded and blocking responses from the dummy, and lets you queue up for matches (with the option to set in rank, casual, connection settings) while you practice, so there's never any real down time.

The biggest tool the game provides though, is the replay mode. The CFN system tracks -every- recent batch of replay for every player online. That means you can download and watch all the top-ranking players and learn from them, as well as watching your own wins and losses to see what part of your game you need to work on. This is a very under utilized feature that beginners tend to ignore, but when used properly will let any beginner see what the next step of progression would be.

That and the continual free updates for modes, characters, and balance changes will continue to add value to this title.
Casuals beware, this isn't worth full sticker price for someone who don't want to invest time and effort to enjoy gameplay, but for anybody else that wants to challenge themselves against others I would suggest this title to anybody who wants to get into the vast and deep world of competitive fighting games.

The amount of skill you can gain, the setups with all the unique cast of characters, the way the game works allowing for freestyle ways of playing... this itself would last anybody years for 60$.

Edit: 3/28/16 - The game also now have a very nice demo mode where they will guide you through the entire system of the game, along with trials to better understand each character.

reviewText:
Can't rebind keys, can't reccommend.

Also when game first booted up I was forced into playing training before being able to access options, then forced to choose a network ID which I was unable to complete. No matter what name I entered I was returned an error that the name was already taken; even gobledy-gook that obviously wasn't taken.

Game is not finished, nor is it in a workable state.

.//edit
Took computer to fight night and of course had problems launching w/o an internet connection. Just launching the executable did boot the game, but was faced with only a black screen. Nothing happened. Tethered my phone, logged into steam, and launched the game. I was getting the Capcom and SFV logo screen, but was for some reason getting only a few frames per second and the animations were not skipping the frames (i.e. it was very very slow getting to the logo screen). Turns out even on the logo screen the game is sinced to an online heartbeat. After killing the tether the network connection dropped, cleared the error, and game functioned just fine offline.

Also simultaneous opposing directions do not properly cancel like in every other fighting game I've played. SFIV always give priority to the direction towards your opponent, most other fighting games give priority to whatever key was pressed last (e.g. if you press right then press left the game recognizes left even if right is still pressed and vice-versa). Street Fighter 5 ALWAYS prioritizes right over left regardless of where your opponent is, regardless of what was pressed first. This makes charge characters annoying to play to say the least.

reviewText:
I am a long time fighting games fan. I played fighting games since the 90's and my first game was Street Fighter II. I love fighting games; I love their competative nature, and the deeper the fighting game the better. My favorite fighting game was Street Fighter III 3rd Strike, and KoF XIII.

With that being said SFV is one of the best fighting games I have ever played. Out of the new fighting games that just came out it is IMO the best one. Yes' SFV is lacking in content such as arcade mode, a decent story mode, and challenges; but if you want to play a good challenging game with great online I highly recommend this game. Capcom well release a free DLC for the modes that the game is lacking such as the challenge mode.

The game, on the surface looks simple, but on the conterary it is a deep game which needs a high skill level; it is easy to get into but hard to master. The easy part is with the simplified execution, the hard part is how the game actually is played. The game is a high risk high reward game that depends on reads and pressuring your opponent. There are no safe dragon punches anymore if you have to do a move you have to commit. The game demands from you to learn fundementals and neutral game; as scrubs and mashers get punished hard. Every character playes really differently from one another and that adds to the depth of the game. The V system is unique as it adds a different prespective to the game and how it is played because it changes how the characters are played.

Hopefully This Review Was Helpful. Thanks For Reading and Sorry For The ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Grammer.

reviewText:
Ok. I bought the game in April 2016 after some updates and only after reading many reviews and problems it had in advance. So before you buy it, here is what you need to verify:

1) Does your controller/stick has a default plug and play driver for windows 10? If no, do not buy it. It is a risk your fighting stick won't work and a 3rd part software will be needed. My fighting stick is a Hori RAP V Kai (XBOXone, Xbox360, PC) and it is plug and play on windows 10 to all games. I enabled the d-pad button and it works just fine. WARNING: this worked fine for this specific arcade stick. So you need to do a little research in the reviews pages and on the Internet to see if it works with yours.

2) Are you a competitive player? Do you like training a lot to improve? If no, do not buy this game. In its current state, there is no arcade mode, i.e., no offline things to do besides training. If you want to buy this game, make sure your objective is to train, get better offline, then test it on casual matches. After you have a solid performance on casuals, you go to ranked and start climbing the ladder.


3)  Given you have a controller/stick that works fine and you want to go multiplayer, here is the game review:

This game is AMAZING! The new system mechanics makes it easy to train and learn combos. The timing for the combos is slower than on SFIV, but the game is incredibly fast-paced. So all you need to do is set up your combos and develop your REACTIONS A LOT! This game is easy to learn but incredibly difficult to master real-time execution. I mean, you can train perfectly your combos, but if you do not have a fast-reaction time, they will be useless. I'll all about the mind game lol. Throws are incredibly difficult to tech and the punish is hard on any error. So be pacient. You'll get better.

You can play with friends offline or online on a lobby, the game has both.

Best thing of the online multiplayer: CROSS-PLATAFORM! I've fought many PS4 and PC players! Really nice. The matchmaking is good enough. Sometimes you'll get lag when fighting someone outside your country, but that's it. If you do not know if there are many people playing in your country, you should do a little research on the Internet to see how's it going, because you could end up lagged in every match vs other people outside your country.

You can farm fighting money and buy new characters when they are released.

That's it for the moment.
voteText: 25 of 47 people (53%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
This game is not worth the price they ask. Its not worth the price for DLC. And it's really not worth buying until on sale unless you're a diehard fighter fan. Honestly, this is a $20 game with a $10 DLC. Unless you're a long time fan of street fighter, consider this a thumbs down review.

However, if you're a fan like me, I'll go into why it's actually really good and (maybe) worth the money.

V trigger & Super out performs the old Ultra & Super combos. Over all this is a strong balance. V trigger replaces Ultra combos as the new revenge" move
recommended: V trigger is more utility and life saving
hoursPlayed: rather than a second version of Supers. For some characters v trigger is a "get out of jail" ability that lets you punish an overly aggressive opponent
voteText: and for other characters it boosts your standard attacks to allow you to push back harder and come back from a loss. The downside is they are really only available when losing and still need to be timed perfectly because they can be punished very easily.\nOnline play has improved quite a bit over SF4 (but it is still below standard to typical multiplayer games
helpfulPercent: regardless this is still an improvement) and you can connect to opponents fairly fast and play quick best-of-three games. By removing games for windows live
votesHelpful: the whole service runs smoother.\nSimilar characters have been diversified more like we had in SF3 and then some. I'll use Ryu & Ken as an example. In the older titles these guys were essentially identical with just some damage numbers moved around. Ken's kick abilities were better while Ryu's punch abilities were better. In SF4 these two characters became more alike ... similar to how we had in SF2 and over all the diversity felt really cosmetic alone. Ultras and Supers were really the main thing to pull them apart. In SF5 though we have these two with CLEAR differences. Ryu now has a standard attack nullifier while Ken has a forward sprint (which is faster than the double forward dash). Ken also sacrifices some over all damage for extreme mobility. Ryu gives up reach and mobility for hitting much harder. For characters who are almost exactly the same

column19:
I do need to lay out the really horrible ♥♥♥♥ just so you know what you're getting into. Lets be honest: This game is an unfinished product being sold as a complete one. Here is why...

There is no arcade mode. This is as basic and core to this title as health bars. It existed in Street Fighter 1 in 1987. There is NO reason for it not to exist now. It's lazy and Capcom should be ashamed. The only way you can fight against a new hero now is a pathetic story mode or vs another player who will whoop you hard. it's frustrating. Arcade mode served one HUGE purpose and that was to teach you the game so you'd be ready for a vs match. It's pathetic it doesn't exist at this point. The game has been out for 2 months and...
There is almost no one playing the damn thing. If I load up rocket league I get into a game within 20seconds or less. I can wait up to 5 minutes for a match in SF5. The only way to speed this up is to include higher ping players. If I want to play a slideshow fight vs someone from China I can expect to be in game in a 10 seconds and be frustrated beyond repair at the 11th second. There are no players because it is an overproced and unfinished product. It's lazy and lame.
The in-game currency (fight money) is extremely slow to earn and forces you to buy DLC if you want to unlock new characters. If you lose a match you earn ZERO fight money and if you win you earn 50. It costs 100

Unfinished game can be published of kickstarter for crowedfunding, here, on steam, you need to publish finished products.

reviewText:
- No DirectInput support so the vast majority of game controllers won't work.

- Can't search for matches/lobbies based on region (which was in ALL versions of Street Fighter IV)

- Matchmaking that does not work well at all and takes AGES to pair you up. Will routinely pair me with bronze-silver ranked players (when I'm gold ranked) which makes for lopsided matches that aren't very fun for anyone.

- No way to communicate. No voice chat/text chat at all.

- No Arcade/V.S. CPU mode.

- One of the worst game modes I have ever played in a video game. In Survival Mode you must beat ALL 3 difficulty modes (easy, normal and hard) with every single character and every individual costume in order to obtain all costume colors. The CPU reads your inputs and will do frame-perfect reversals and high damage combos. This paired with RANDOM end-of-round bonuses (including health recovery) and no continues makes this an extremely tedious, boring and difficult waste of time. There is nothing more frustrating than playing hard Survival Mode for half an hour just to lose in 5 seconds to the input reading CPU and having to start all-over again.

Please don't waste your money on this game until Capcom fixes the game's glaring problems (if they ever do which I'm starting to doubt).

reviewText:
Edit:  I'll be striking out aspects of my review that no longer apply as Capcom fixes its game.  Inevitably, I'll be changing this to a positive review when it reaches its full potential.

I initially wrote a favorable review of this game.  I was willing to overlook its shortcomings (the threadbare single player experience, the launch week server issues, and the toothless lip service paid to casual inclusiveness) because I felt that the gameplay and art direction were amazing, and I've always had a soft spot for Street Fighter.

Then I started playing in the online cesspool.  It is a devil's playground of rage quitters and Alt-Tabbers.  It is the opposite of fun.  Even in casual matches, people will inexplicably disconnect before an impending loss.  The fact that Capcom went live with what is supposed to be THE flagship online competitive fighting game platform with no plan in place for rage quitting -a common practice now for a decade- is inexcusable.

I also tried my hand at Hard Survival mode, which if you don't know, is the only viable single player mode that you have available to you.  Question: What is the most excruciating RPG grind fest that you've ever played?  Whatever it is, it's better than this.  At least in whatever RPG that you're thinking of you're rewarded in some small way for your efforts over time.  Not so with Street Fighter V Survival Mode.  After spending nearly an hour working your way through 49 opponents, which will range in difficulty from laughable time-waster to all-seeing input reader, you will walk away with nothing if you fail to defeat the final opponent.  I'm not sure if these instances are more or less discouraging than a rage quitter disconnecting on you, but it begins to feel like the entire structure of Street Fighter V is designed to punish instead of reward.

This is all in line with Capcom's time-honored disparity between what it says and what it does.  C̶a̶p̶c̶o̶m̶ ̶s̶a̶y̶s̶ ̶i̶t̶ ̶w̶a̶n̶t̶s̶ ̶t̶o̶ ̶b̶r̶i̶n̶g̶ ̶i̶n̶ ̶a̶ ̶n̶e̶w̶ ̶c̶a̶s̶u̶a̶l̶ ̶f̶a̶n̶b̶a̶s̶e̶ ̶b̶y̶ ̶c̶r̶e̶a̶t̶i̶n̶g̶ ̶a̶ ̶c̶o̶m̶p̶r̶e̶h̶e̶n̶s̶i̶v̶e̶ ̶t̶u̶t̶o̶r̶i̶a̶l̶ ̶m̶o̶d̶e̶,̶ ̶a̶n̶d̶ ̶t̶h̶e̶n̶ ̶d̶e̶l̶i̶v̶e̶r̶s̶ ̶a̶ ̶t̶u̶t̶o̶r̶i̶a̶l̶ ̶t̶h̶a̶t̶ ̶e̶f̶f̶e̶c̶t̶i̶v̶e̶l̶y̶ ̶t̶e̶a̶c̶h̶e̶s̶ ̶y̶o̶u̶ ̶h̶o̶w̶ ̶t̶o̶ ̶w̶a̶l̶k̶,̶ ̶j̶u̶m̶p̶,̶ ̶b̶l̶o̶c̶k̶,̶ ̶a̶n̶d̶ ̶a̶t̶t̶a̶c̶k̶ ̶(̶i̶g̶n̶o̶r̶i̶n̶g̶ ̶c̶r̶u̶c̶i̶a̶l̶ ̶s̶y̶s̶t̶e̶m̶s̶ ̶l̶i̶k̶e̶ ̶w̶a̶k̶e̶-̶u̶p̶,̶ ̶c̶r̶u̶s̶h̶ ̶c̶o̶u̶n̶t̶e̶r̶,̶ ̶a̶n̶d̶ ̶V̶-̶r̶e̶v̶e̶r̶s̶a̶l̶,̶ ̶t̶o̶ ̶n̶a̶m̶e̶ ̶a̶ ̶f̶e̶w̶)̶.̶ Capcom censors certain female character animations because it doesn't want to make (presumably female) players uncomfortable, and then gives two of its characters alternative costumes wherein their breasts are hanging out of the bottom of their outfit instead of the top, one of whom might as well have come out of a Dead or Alive game.  Capcom says it wants to compete with, and possibly even eclipse, the detailed single player content present in rival fighting franchises (Mortal Kombat X is inferred), and then delivers poorly illustrated, poorly written, ultra-easy three-fight story modes for each of its characters, with a larger but probably equally disappointing narrative mode coming this summer.

To elaborate on that last point for a moment, if I were to turn on MKX right now and start a single player fight versus the computer (which I cannot currently do in any sort of meaningful way in SFV), I would be treated before the match to fully animated, engaging dialog between my character and my opponent, unique to whatever character combination is currently fighting.  I could then go into a special mode wherein I explore, in first person adventure style, a large gamespace solely for the purpose of unlocking and viewing extras with my accrued fight currency.  These extras range from additional costumes, to extra gameplay finishers, to concept art, most of it fully annotated by the developers.  Now I'm not a Mortal Kombat guy, but they have set the bar for single player content and attention to detail, and Street Fighter V is so far removed that I doubt that its development team can even realistically SEE that bar.  They can't even get their character models to stop clipping on the character select screen (̶l̶e̶t̶ ̶a̶l̶o̶n̶e̶ ̶f̶i̶x̶ ̶t̶h̶e̶ ̶b̶r̶e̶a̶s̶t̶ ̶j̶i̶g̶g̶l̶e̶ ̶w̶e̶i̶r̶d̶n̶e̶s̶s̶ ̶o̶n̶ ̶t̶h̶e̶ ̶P̶l̶a̶y̶e̶r̶ ̶2̶ ̶s̶i̶d̶e̶ ̶o̶f̶ ̶t̶h̶a̶t̶ ̶s̶c̶r̶e̶e̶n̶ ̶t̶h̶a̶t̶'̶s̶ ̶b̶e̶e̶n̶ ̶p̶r̶e̶s̶e̶n̶t̶ ̶s̶i̶n̶c̶e̶ ̶t̶h̶e̶ ̶f̶i̶r̶s̶t̶ ̶B̶e̶t̶a̶)̶

In all, I can no longer recommend this game to a casual player. I've been playing fighting games since Street Fighter 1 on my Commodore 64.  This is the best -and worst- that Street Fighter has ever been.  The game's one redeeming quality, its gameplay, is marred by a toxic online competitive scene and infuriating single player AI.  You might have some fun, but it won't counterbalance the frustration and disappointment.  You can have more fun for 60 dollars elsewhere.

reviewText: Im rating this game based on gameplay and the adaptability factor versus SFIV AE. Its a completely different game that doesnt require a learning curve like SFIV. Graphics are the best that ive seen in a SF game from Capcom and the changes they made are pretty understandable. But when comparing this Episode 5 version to the last hands down SFIV is still my cup of tea. The game favors those who want to get in the game and play fast and learn things quickly its just not as satisfying and rewarding as I felt in SFIV. Its still a brand new game but Id hold out on spending that 60 bucks and just stick with SFIV until they add or balance the game. But this series WILL Never replace SFIV in my opinion. So Yes And No Im a bit torn with this Capcom Stone ( Not Jewel ) its up for grabs but ill tip my hat to Killer Instinct

reviewText:
Opinion: The core game is excellent.
Fact: The rushed launch and release with severe lack of content is insulting.

Without hyperbole, this is a AAA publisher releasing an Early Access game as retail.

That being said, if you play Street Fighter or other fighting games more than casually, you'll probably be semi-happy with this today. If you only occasionally play fighting games, you should wait for them to deliver more content AND lower the price.

This review might change once they deliver something more than a beta.

I was so excited for this, but it ended up being dissapointing.

My biggest gripe immedialtely is that it was not support for generic joysticks. IV did this so well, so why exclude this here? I don't want to have to run a third party app for something that should be in any fighting game on pc.

Another huge issue I am getting is the game plays at half speed anytime I am ♥♥♥♥♥ing less than 60 frames Seriously!?

Also, how the heck do you release a fighting game with no arcade mode? That should be the most basic mode in any fighting game. SMH Capcom.

Network is having all kinds of issues, but that is almost to be expected. If I just had a decent arcade mode, I could keep myself entertained playing through with the different characters.

reviewText:
Let's see what's on the list.

1. Servers and connections can be bad at times.
2. The game is filled with rage quitters.
3. Capcom's system against Rage-quitters does nothing.
4. Balancing of characters is definitely needed.
5. Matchmaking can be stupid. (You can be Gold or Platinum, and still fight bronze and silver players.)
6. The reason why this game has all this negative reviews, is because it was bare-bones at launch. Capcom was trying to appeal to the FGC and online-only players so much that the casual players were left behind.

Capcom, do better.

I only listed out the negatives, you can hear the positives from someone else. Because it actually does have good things about it.

EDIT: I am now giving this game the name of Rage Quitter V". Everyone always seems to rage quit."

reviewText:
After a disastrous launch, online multiplayer generally works alright now. Matches are not frequent enough for my taste, but they work out fine.

I'll recommend the game when the following issues are resolved:
PS4 fight stick support is still missing (all DirectInput controllers aren't supported natively) - they've indicated they're working on this
Still some remaining server issues - fights not being reported to the servers, disconnects, fight profile data not showing
Rage quitting is not punished - if you face someone in Ranked online mode with a huge win streak, odds are about 90% they'll disconnect before you're awarded the win if you beat them. - This is going to be implemented, but for now, be sure to record every ragequit; Capcom has indicated that they'll be retroactively punishing too
So if you're looking into buying this, I'd hold off for now if you want to be sure you'll get your money's worth. On the other hand, everyone is getting a head start on you in experience, and you'll face a much tougher opposition online later.

Also, be aware the not all content is in yet. The following are still missing but will be added for free:
Proper story mode - there's a 2-4 fight story mode for each character now, but it's too easy and only a prologue
Trials/challenges - a combination of a tutorial and a showcase for what characters can do, as was in SFIV
The shop - a way to spend your fight money (acquired from winning pretty much any type of fight) on new characters or costumes (or by spending actual money on it)
Lobbies that support 8 people instead of the 2-player maximum it has nowSee here for a schedule of the release of those features[images.onesite.com]

reviewText:
Seriously lacking features.

I've been a fan of Street Fighter all my life. I remember walking into Scandia Family Arcade and Fun Center in 1991 and seeing the GIGANTIC Street Figther II arcades with lines dozens of teenagers deep. I've been hooked ever since and I've loved every iteration. Alpha, 3rd Strike, EX, Versus... doesn't matter, I've been in all the way.

But Street Fighter V's launch is seriously lacking features and that's a huge disappointment. It's super refined, it's gorgeous on my PC, and combat with friends can be fun, but I've had constant server issues and there is zero ability to challenge the PC/AI in a simple 2 out of 3 match. Why? What's the point of that?

I'll revisit when the game feels more fleshed out, probably when the cinematic story mode" drops in June. I can wait. I'm not pro

reviewText: Ignore all the negative reviews let me tell you why. The game was supposed to launch in June but Capcom wanted to launch it in 16 February for the Capcom Tournaments and pros to learn the game earlier. That means the game is kinda like an early-access game all the features, characters, actual story and good online experience will be added in future updates for free. All the DLC can be unlocked with in-game currency and that's good. A lot of past fan favourite characters were in the game and Capcom is carring for their fans. The little story modes were made in a small period of time only for introducing the characters story for the actual story in June. Also an Arcade Mode will be added in March so what's wrong with the game? Amazing game mechanics the best out there stunning graphics survival mode actual story mode like MKX's in June 22 characters in September challenges trials arcade mode and shop in March. Now they just want to communicate with fans to fix the game before it's final form and there's nothing wrong about it! I want to say something to the people who don't recommend the game ; Review the game in September when it's ready if you want everything to be perfect for God's sake!

reviewText:
I dont even know where to start.
Lets just skip broken launch and bare bones content and lets get straight to mechanics of game. I understand, Capcom tried to bring normal (casuals) players to street fighter universe but what they displayed in street fighter 5 is absolutely unjustifiable.

There is no challenging mode or trial, that would teach you basics and advanced stuff. If you want to learn another character you need to stick to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ menu and training mode.
What they actually did, is that you can faceroll your controller and throw amazing,super,mega combos. Just like in tekken. Or soul calibur.
This is just my opinion, but if you wanted to throw flashy/higher damaging combos in previous street fighter titles, you needed to spent your portion of time. Not anymore. Here comes the new call of fighter 12.

There are numerous other things, like holding neutral ground, poking, footsies etc.. It seems like nobody was thinking about these mechanics too much. Or maybe the actual character rooster is too small to see any kind of exicting stuff.
Compated to previous titles it just seems.. boring.

Im not going to mention the utterly broken, unfinished stuff like rage quitting without being penalized. Was is so hard to implement automatic lose to player who will leave in middle of the match? Just like every other multiplayer game has it?

The most funny thing on this is how capcom are trying to throw responsibilty on their playerbase. What a great idea. Street fighter 5 playerbase fall into category of infamous league of legends community.

TLDR: if you are tired of Street fighter 4, then with SF5 you can have a little bit of fun. Especially at home, with some friends, just chilling and beating each other. Is it worth 60 euros? Hell, no.

+ solid, fitting soundtrack (especially some stages!)
+ Crossplay

- dumbed mechanics of game
- zero singleplayer content (survival is not game mode, its a time consuming trap for innocent players)
- Capcom being Capcom
- everything else

The mechanics and core gameplay are great, No disappointment here.

This review is of political nature, with the agenda to prevent terrible AAA-launches like this by not having consumers buy into ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t marketing and rushed releases.

None of the below would be problematic if it was labelled beta"
date:
and would be easily fixed and tested within a months time in AAA-production.


This product is in an unacceptable state at launch
recommended:
especially for such a high profile title:

- No controller other than XInput (IE XBox 360) supported - in a FIGHTING game!
- No customizable keybinds - in a FIGHTING game!
- (On launch day) frequent network disconnections that interrupt even single-player gameplay. This was unacceptable 10 years ago already.

So much for the "easy-to-fix" and "Dev-Failed-Mitigation" category.
Next

reviewText: As of this review (February 17, 2016), this is essentially the Arcade Release" of Street Fighter V. Right now it features standard online and local play
date: 1 extra game mode and a training room ONLY with a small-ish roster of 16 characters. Street Fighter V will feel like a traditional console release by the end of this DLC wave in August (with 6 new characters
hoursPlayed: /features
voteText: new costumes and stages added
helpfulPercent: as well as many updates in March and the free story mode dropping in June). It will feel like a truly complete super full game likely sometime from April to June of 2017
votesHelpful: with further additions on top of that.\n\nThe reason Street Fighter V was launched this way was because the gameplay was complete but the modes weren't and many dedicated Street Fighter fans like me want to play it right away. This way the developers can built the extra modes
votesTotal: characters and content while getting feedback on the gameplay of the game. In the long run this continuous development cycle will produce a better game than traditional "one off" developed games or DLC on and off development. But for now
votesFunny: the game isn't anywhere near that point.\n\nBefore I continue
commentsCount: I will offer a warning: If you aren't a super dedicated Street Fighter fan
column16: don't have a console Gen 8 controller/fight stick/fight pad or newer
column17: and don't have a remotely modern PC
column18: don't buy this game yet. For the 1st group wait for more content
column19: for the 2nd group wait for support to be added in March
column20: and for the latter group
column21: wait until you have a PC that can run this game at a consistent 60 frames per second.\n\nIf you don't fit into any of these 3 categories I said not to buy this game
column22:
I recommend you get this game.

\

Now onto the 2nd controversial part
column23: the character DLC. You can get every DLC character for 100k with an in-game currency called "fight money
column24:
which is easy to acquire (or you can pay $6 in real money). In less than 2 hours of gameplay I beat all 16 character's story mode and survival mode on easy and got roughly 250k fight money. If you play the single player modes, play online, and do the daily objectives (these haven't started yet), it is incredibly easy to earn fight gold and having enough fight money to buy characters with fight money will be easy. You will have so much fight money left over it will be crazy.

DLC stages will be available similarly, although the price of them is unknown. In addition to that, there will be a plethora of costumes, roughly as many as MOBA's have in the future, that you can get. Note that a few rare costumes will only be available via real money.

For the last controversial thing is the negative reviews. Much of them came because of reasons previously stated as well as the online not working very well for the 1st 24 hours. That has been mostly fixed.

For some reason of all the Steam releases in the last year this game got blown up the hardest for this. Newsflash: Fallout 4 wouldn't run properly on people's PC's for month; CS:GO's online was flat awful for at least a month after launch. Mortal Kombat X had inconsistent frame rates, tons of bugs, crashes, and online that doesn't function. Developer support for that game was dropped entirely recently with no patches coming in half a year for the PC release... and that game has a 17% higher rating than this game for some reason.

Many of the people who feel scammed by this game were simply uninformed consumers. Capcom clearly communicated this, although the amount of people who pay attention to these things is pretty small sadly. That is why I wrote this review.... to inform fellow consumers so they can make the best possible decision on whether they should get this game, or when they should get this game, as well as encourage them to do some research.

(Note: If I glossed over anything important or missed something, inform me in this review)

On to the actual game review:

Pros:
-The 16 characters are amazingly diverse. There's a character for everybody to enjoy, with 6 more to come in the next 7 months and more after that!
-The gameplay is incredibly smooth. This game has the content of an early access game yet the gameplay of a fully realized and finished AAA quality title.
-This is the best initial release of any Street Fighter ever and it isn't even close. In fact this is one of the best Street Fighter games ever.
-The DLC policy is amazing if you understand how it works (I covered this in an above section). All future game modes and features will be free, and being able to afford the DLC characters with in-game currency is relatively easy (although you could pay real money for them still).
-The visuals on most of the stages and the character models are incredible. Running this on max settings 1080p now is a blast. The graphical leap IV to V may not look like much from gameplay videos, but seeing it in person is night and day.
-The net coding is brilliant. Across over 400 beta matches I had only 1 game with lag (against someone on the other side of the planet), and that wasn't even that bad. There's not a ton of buffering either like other online fighting games.
-No random frame drops to report (sadly after MK X I have to report such things as positive instead of 100% necessary to even be recommended").
-The gameplay issues Street Fighter IV had are long gone (such as strong attacks trading with weak ones)
column25: and the gameplay is more simplified
column26: yet the game mechanically is deeper and feels more rewarding for good play. The gameplay balance in this manner is very good
column27:
and the game feels deeper than IV already.
-Japanese and English voice options for the whole cast or each character individually. I'm glad this is becoming standardized in fighting games.
-The best Street Fighter soundtractk ever. This soundtrack is much better than I anticipated it would be.
-For Street Fighter fans this is the game you've probably been waiting for in regards to gameplay.

Neutral:
-This game is well optimized for most modern PC's (including mine)

reviewText:
I recommend this game with an asterisk. I can only recommend the game if you really enjoy playing fighting games for the competition and enjoy online play. The gameplay is solid and the online works very well (for me at least).

Can I recommend this to average Joe? No (not right now at least).
60$ is too much for the game in its current state. Singleplayer consists of a small story mode (2-3 fights per character and not much in terms of actual story), a survival mode, and a training mode.

Capcom is adding more content throughout the year so the game will be more worthwhile (and probably cheaper) a couple months from now. If you are not very interested in the competitive aspect, I suggest waiting until the summer time when the game is more complete

reviewText: The game itself is excellent. Unfortunately, it feels like an incomplete product because of content that is considered standard to fighting games: trial mode, arcade mode, and 1P. vs. CPU. Despite these lack of features, the game is really fun to play. I would recommend this to fans of street fighter or those interested in getting into fighting games, but you should be aware of the lack of content. Capcom promises to lay out more content in the coming months, but now the only feature that makes the game worth the price of admission is the online mode. It's a blast to to play but it feels like there should have been more.

reviewText: I cannot in good conscience recommend this game to anyone at this stage. Like several people have mentioned here it actually does feel like an early access title. Sometimes even worse, considering that most early access titles are actually PLAYABLE. I've been unable to play more than 5 matches at most since the game's launch and even those were after I got tired of waiting in a queue for almost an hour and making my own lobby. Factor in the constant disconnects and errors regarding sending data to their server, and you've got your standard utterly broken-at-launch online title right here. Yes, I've noticed many people have had way more luck than me with getting matches, but the fact of the matter is MANY have not (feel free to check out any popular/common gaming forums to get a better feel of the current situation).\n\nBesides the broken online play (which is BOUND to get fixed eventually... I hope...), you all should be fully aware that SFV is the most barebones fighting game I've had the displeasure of playing when it comes to offline modes. You can't even do standard VS. matches with a CPU, which has been the most common and basic feature in a fighting game since the very inception of its genre. Then there is an utterly useless training mode and laughably-short and cringe-inducing 5 minute-long story" battles for each character

reviewText:
Wonderful game
I seem to be one of those who is satisfied with the game without any doubt.

It plays very good. I do not even want to return to SF4. I don't understand people, saying 16 chars are too low for a fighting game... Try to master one at least before requesting 40+ fighters. All the characters available are absolutely unique and interesting, so anyone could find his or her fighter.

Lack of single player content does not bother me at all, maybe because I don't have enough time to squeese through the modes and just enjoy online.

What I do love is the music here. A separate THANK YOU to the composer.

I am not sure how the future DLCs will change my mind - there are thoughts that FM only will not be enough to get everything for free in an adequate period of time. We'll see...

Anyway, the game is a brutal, picturesque, addictive and full of rhythm must have!

reviewText:
Well, more than two weeks after launch, and this game still is pretty bad.

If you're a casual player, you were screwed since the beginning, but even for people who would be happy playing online the game is terrible.

Right now the servers are better, but far from ideal. But after all that time, rage quitting still goes unpunished. Of my last five games, I lost three, and of the two that I won, the other player quit. This keeps happening all the time to everyone, and Capcom doesn't care. And I think when they decide to do something about it, it won't be much.

I will not recommend this game just because I want the community to grow and the game to be a success. I really wish all that, but right now Capcom deserve every bit of negative reviews and bad sales they're getting. Fix this game asap. Don't kill Street Fighter because you have a scheduele to meet. Make smart decisions, Capcom. Please!

At the time of writing:

Singleplayer:
Content doesn't practically exist. So let's move on to the multiplayer.

Multiplayer:
Having a television or book close by is a must have, for you'll be spending much time on waiting. By the time of writing this I've played the game 30,2 hrs, and I must have spend atleast 20 hrs of that time on waiting only. It can take anything from 5 to 20 minutes to get a match, if not longer.
Someone might argue that there are not enough new players, So ofcourse there is much waiting, and that it get's easier on higher ranks. By the time of writing this I've reached silver rank ingame, and waiting is still essential part of the multiplayer experience.

Also it would seem to me, that atleast 20% of the ranked game players are lag switchers and / or those people who ragequit to save their league points. Ofcourse that can hardly be blamed on Capcom.

In general:

The fighting mechanics and graphics & music in this game are the only ones that are up to the standard. Unfortunately it does not redeem the other flaws of the game mentioned earlier.

In short:
The usual tirade about I wanted to like this game
date: but..."\nI will keep playing the game and hope Capcom will get it to playable condition.\n"

reviewText:
If I could describe SF5 right now in one word that word would be rushed.  As it stands this game is very much incomplete with basic fighting game features with promises to fix things next month in a content patch.  What we have at launch is a story mode which is embarassingly easy and feels tacked on in the last minute if you see the content of the story and the laughable quality of the artwork. Seeing as how we're keen on giving Capcom a free pass on the quality of their single player story mode that leaves the online multiplayer and local multiplayer. I don't have any real experience with local multiplayer yet but in regards to the online mode the netcode is worse than USF4's which is to be expected considering it is a cross platform game but that alone doesn't excuse Capcom considering they've had a beta for six months. While It's commendable that the dev team has focused a lot of attention to balancing the game it's absolutely deplorable how they treated the rest of the game.

With all that said, unless you're playing local vs. mode or if you have a group of friends that will play with you you should consider waiting until March when the patch arrives with much needed online matchmaking features, more single player content, and a plethora of bug fixes which should have been fixed during the beta.

The foundation for a good game is there but I can't in good conscience recommend SF5 to a new player unless they already have people diving in with them until all these issues are addressed. When that day happens I will be happy to change this review but until then, it's just a shoddy rush job.

reviewText: The game can be fun, if you can get it to work. The entire infrastructure around it is occasionally only somewhat-functional. The servers are frequently wonky, the matchmaking feels random (often pitting you against players that are thousands of points ahead or behind you), and the stats-recording and basic messaging and community functions non-existent. Capcom has not acknowledged, much less pledged to make basic things right.\n\nEnough is enough, Capcom has abused the goodwill of it's fans for decades and, in my opnion, this is where it deserves to die. The artists, musicians, and designers that made this game will get new jobs (as they should as the game is beautiful and the soundtrack might be the best of any SF game to date). Hopefully the management will not.

reviewText:
Like many players I grew up on Street Fighter. The characters, the music and the world Capcom had built all those years ago at arcades captured my attention and hasn't let go. It's always been fun finding out how best to utilize your character and kick the butts of Ken players around the world.

On a serious note, I'm put off by the business model of Street Fighter 5 and how Capcom handled its launch. It's a 60$ retail game with microtransations on the way next month. That may not seem bad as currently there are 2 DLC characters available for free, sounds good right? Well in June Alex and Guile will be gated off by a paywall along with 4 other characters for an as of yet undetermined price. Now, you could acquire these characters with in game money but that requires you to spend hours grinding through survival mode which is always a blast /s. If Street Fighter 5 was free to play I could understand the decision to hold characters for ransom. But it costs SIXTY FREAKIN' DOLLARS to play this game!!

I'm frustrated because I want to love SF5, but this experience leaves me disappointed and cautious of purchasing another Capcom product. Even when the TURBO DELUXE HYPER ULTRA ARCADE CAMMYS SWIMSUIT EDITION comes out I will stay away from this product. There should be no video game with an upfront 60$ retail price that asks you pay more to get the full experience.

reviewText:
Here's what capcom has promised, and to this day, has not fulfilled yet:

-Rage Quit Punishment: Count RQ as a loss for the RQer and give points to winner
-Keyboard rebinding
-dinput support
-Improve matchmaking speed and connectivity
-sound bugs
-rematch bugs
-antivirus stopping launching
-Alex reverting framedata to a previous version bug
-more options for matchmaking like ranking preferences or regional
-save training mode and challenge settings
-allow matchmaking during challenges
-revamp survival mode and colors entirely
-add in the daily challenges promised
-issue with some nvidia cpus not being used properly by default
-issues regarding UE4 on launch or exit
-add in zenny store and the things to go with it
-arcade mode eventually
-training mode that shows hit boxes or frame data
-improved optimization for both console and pc
-lower input lag
-online training
-more stage variants (day/night, sagat statue, etc)
-more stage transitions
-in game newsletter
-microphone option online
-able to type messages in battle lobby
-OPTION TO CHOOSE BETWEEN STAGE AND CHARACTER THEMES
-be able to buy whatever color you want with FM regardless of survival or character level
-have more frequent unlocks for character levels like Killer Instinct does
-fix whatever the issue is with Laura having different framerate on one side
-fix whatever the issue is with Mika having increased CA range in the corner
-lower white damage on gief's v-skill
-put Makoto, Gouken and Cody in the game
-put in special intros for certain character matchups like Ryu/Ken fistbump
-be able to watch replays without favoriting them and putting them on the server first
-Input delay combines with the slightest online lag to make some moves feel unblockable
-Lack of transparency on the part of Capcom has become extremely frustrating, not to mention the apparent poor planning that has caused them to miss character and content release dates
-Wi-Fi players will show up in the 4-5 connection bracket and then drop frames all game
-RQs aren't counted as an automatic loss for those who care about points
-Keyboard rebinding isn't supported for those who care about keyboards
-Many controllers aren't supported by default for anyone who cares about not having to use the 360 pad
-Story mode is super easy and short
-Apparently Asia has been having online issues for a while (live in US so don't know if it's still an issue)
-Survival is a f2p-style unfair grindfest in a game you paid $60 for
-Zenny store doesn't work for those who want to buy the premium costumes (though there's a mod for enabling them)
-Overall, game just feels beta/rushed

Oh, and one more thing, its been said that everything will be delayed, and crapcom is not capable of giving not even the smallest satisfaction to its customers.

More than enough to disappoint customers and loyal fans of the franchise which have been supporting it since 1991.

Stay (FAR) away from this.

reviewText:
I know I pre-purchased the game so I could play the beta, but I was unaware that it would be going on for this long.

Wait... it's released? Oh. Well. Um....

All joking aside, I'd have issues recommending this to someone like myself, the casual player. (read: scrub that needs to git gud lolz)

The single player content is severly lacking at the moment, with a basic arcade mode completely missing. I do understand this is a console game, so an arcade mode shouldn't be expected. The AI is about as stable as Bobcat Goldthwait, often going from perfectly times pokes and counters to 7-10 seconds of standing there like a complete dolt doing literally nothing except waiting for you to hit them. Reminds me of MK2's AI, which is a 23 year old game that ran on a 6Mhz processor. Story mode is best described as cute; it feels like a tacked on afterthought. And survival mode relies on the current state of the AI, so it's really not difficult.

The lack of controller support is extermely frustrating to me, as I have a controller I used in SF4 that is not recognized in SF5 at all. I'm pretty sure that Windows has API's that allow you to inerface with the rest of the universe. I mean, it's just a bunch of things that turn on and off. Like a keyboard, only with less letters. I'm forced to use a wired xbox 360 controller with the analog shoulder buttons, which makes it pretty annoying. This is basic stuff really, so I'm not sure why it didn't happen.

Online play is a bit spotty right now, but mostly works. I still get occasional lag spikes, but that has been fairly consistant for me so it's likely my connection. The disappointing thing for me is the lobby games are 2 player only and about 1/2 the time I can't connect to other players' lobbys for some unknown reason. The same players continue to show up every time after a refresh of the avalable games, but it will tell me it's either not there anymore or it's full. Ranked games wait times didn't seem to bad to me. I would get into a match within a minute or so each time, so nothing too big to report there.

It's unfortunate, but all of these problems seem to sit on top of what is actually a solid game. The actual gameplay is very   good. Characters feel balanced, but more important they all feel accessable. You loose a round to someone online and you don't get mad. Instead you want to fight them again so you can figure out how to counter their game plan.

I would never have considered playing Dictator in SF4; I dislike charge characters. However, with links being a great deal more relaxed from SF4 and the inclusion of non-charge moves to the character I actually enjoy playing him. And I've been a R.Mika fanboi from beta, which is a drasticly different character. It's that accessability that appeals to me. I might even try Sim at some point.

In conclusion, casual players will probably have a hard time getting into this game bacause of the slim offline play options. Which is sad, because the actual gameplay is rewading and engaging without being overwhelming. If online is your thing then this game is a treat. It's deep and rewarding. I'm going to have to go with a no on recommending it though; what you're spending your $60 on right now is an extended beta. I will change that when/if the actual full game is available.

reviewText: Well, after multiple hours of trying to get the game to connect, it's a fun game. The actual play is very good, with enough changes to make it feel considerably different from IV. I had long since before accepted that Capcom was mostly out of ideas, hence the art style looks like IV (but more polished), and much of the music is (again) remixes of SF2. That's fine. What I can't forgive is the terrible online play. IF you manage to connect, you'll be annoyed by the experience of trying to find a lobby or match. Which you have to do, because for some asinine reason they decided to omit an Arcade Mode for you to play in while leaving Fight Request On. Your only one-player options are Story and Survival Modes, both of which seemingly have no real difficulty settings for AI skill. Which means your one-player experience is beating up on a very, very weak and not-fun CPU. As a further insult, on the many cases where it fails to connect, the game reminds you that you can't get Experience or Fight Money in offline mode, and hence, nothing you do will mean anything. You would think that after the super-extensive Beta testing of this game, they might have all this figured out by launch, but you'd be wrong. Game developers making sure the game they've already been paid for is functional at launch is Old Economy thinking. That said, the game is pretty, and, when it works, is actually fun. The problem is this: do you want to spend 10 minutes screwing around and waiting for the server to connect every time you want 90 seconds of play? As of right now, this makes Mortal Kombat X look like a brilliant example of online play. At least MK X had a worthwhile one-player mode! Wait until it's on severe discount and they get the kinks worked out. All I got for pre-ordering was one whole costume for a character I never play.

reviewText:
Do you have some friends to play with IRL ?

Yes ?
Good for you, the gameplay is awesome. The game is fun to play.
This new system with V-Skill // V-Trigger for each character is a masterpiece imo.

You don't ?
That's a shame because :
- The story mode is a joke
- The survival mode is stupid, unbalanced, boring and too easy for the most part and then you die surprisingly at the last fight ! Surprise ! You can try again ! 30 ? 50 ? 100 matchs ? Enjoy !
- No Arcade Mode
- There is no mode where you can learn combos for your characters, go to Youtube ! wow.
- The online is still the worst for me. I have fiber and can't play a single match without teleportation everywhere. I feel like i'm the one suffering for their bad connections. And I'm not even talking about ragequit without consequences.

Do I recommand this game for now ? No way. Wait for patches and more solo content (June 2016).

I'm sure this game will be a must-have but it feels like it's still an early access product.

reviewText: Game play feels increadably smooth, the v system gives each character a unique feeling, the DLC model is possibly the ideal format, and the cast is super well balanced. Unfortunetly single player is sparce (no arcade mode!), 3d models have clipping issues on the css, and no keyboard rebinding. The game is incredible but unfortunetly surrounded by many annoying choices that means some people just won't be able to enjoy the game.

reviewText:
Overall this is an amazing game.

But first and foremost at its current state, this is a game for the fighting game community, Im coming from the competitive smash scene myself. Once this game was announced and saw gameplay I knew I had to try out this series. Having very little street fighter experience and jumping right in was daunting but it has been a rewarding journey throughout.

The animations for each individual character are very detailed and a joy to look at. I found myself picking random characters to look at their idle animations because it was that good. the visuals really contribute to the stages and their backgrounds (Hillside Plaza is beast!)

Training mode is robust and much can be learned from going to the lab and practicing a few combos. Practice various scenarios, mix-ups etc.

The original soundtrack for this game is also epic and I get hyped listening to the stage/character select music.

Characters currently available and to come all look unique and amazing to play. The introduction of the V trigger system really makes for fun play, making comebacks possible.

If you enjoy the aspect of testing your metal online against more and more challenging people online this is the game for you. Winning a close match is one of the most rewarding parts of this game, it's not easy but through a robust training mode you can level up and face all the world warriors.

reviewText:
I'm quite a bit disappointed at the moment with Street Fighter V. There is very little in the way of single player content, and the game doesn't even include a basic arcade mode. The story mode currently available lasts for three or four fights, and that's literally it for each character.

None of this would be nearly as bad if I didn't find myself having pretty long waits between online matches. On the bright side, in the matches I did get into, I had no technical issues or lag, even playing between platforms against PS4 players.

The game's mechanics seem pretty solid, and this should eventually evolve into a pretty great game. At this time, however, I can only really recommend this to a hardcore Street Fighter fan. I hope down the road I'll be convinced to change this review to a positive.

reviewText: Easier combos will make it easier for players new to fighting enter the competitive scene, but with a horde of dedicated players ready to body anyone that comes their way, there's still quite a barrier to entry. reviewText:
Most of the 3.4 hrs I have on record is pretty much me staring at the menu screen and trying to telepathically will my way into the game.

Streaming for a friend of mine, I think his Street Fighter-derived and miscellaneous quotes best sum up the experience:

Connect to me if you dare, I will disconnect you.
Handsome fighters never lose connection.
I'm the weakest release in the world.
I will meditate then refund this incomplete game.
Next time we meet, I'm going to break your 3-way handshake.
Go home and be a family LAN.
Well this is quite the amazing...menu.
When does the game get released?
#Riseup? More like #SteadyDecline.
#GIMMEJUSTONEMATCH
Excuse me...I'm...going to...look at some spreadsheets.

I want to love this game, even bought the more expensive package...but sadly, I have to give this a negative right now due to the constant disconnects, lack of connections, and other issues reviewers are giving this game.  The one time I got in a battle, my opponent and I was about to have one of those epic jump kick clashes when the game just disconnected.  Might as well just flashed To Be Continued!!" on the screen...sigh."

reviewText:
A rushed, buggy game that is lacking content, and will continue to do so.  The game is basically Online Only if you want Fight Money, which by the way, doesn't have any kind of Registration System for it, meaning your hard work is going to be lost at some point given their current incompetency in regards to functionality.

Framerate Drops, Battle Lounge doesn't work (and it's not even 8 players yet), the Story Prologue stuff for each character is A JOKE, lasting 4-6 minutes per character.  On top of that, the promised Cinematic Story Mode will have over 1 hour of cutscenes in a mode that Capcom has now promised to last no more than 2.

Save your money now.  Save your money in the future.  This is not getting better anytime soon.

reviewText:
EVEN THOUGH I RECOMMENDED THE GAME IT'S IMPORTANT TO READ ON AND SEE WHAT KIND OF PLAYER YOU ARE BEFORE DECIDING ANYTHING BASED ON MY QUICKIE REVIEW

As it stands now I'd only recommend the game to people who are interested in only playing other people be it online and offline (and if you play online you need to be patient cause matchmaking can be wonky and there's a ton of rage quitters), and wanting to play at tournaments (be it your locals, regionals, or majors), then go ahead and buy it and get your skills up.  Plays nothing like SF4 and more like a strange version of 3rd Strike without parries and the nuances, which is a big plus in my book. It's fairly simple to learn and there's quite some neat things under the layers.

Now if you're NOT the previously mentioned type of person, then avoid the game for now. It's currently in what I'd say is an Esports Early Access state, beta" would start after the March patch and full release (lol) would be in June where the complete story is in and other necessary modes. Cause as it stands as a -GAME- there isn't much there at all."

reviewText:
If you're a fan of the Street Fighter franchise you're definitely going to enjoy this next installement.

A lot of the reviews are a bit outdated (to an extent) because the game had an early release. A lot of features weren't available during the early release which are available now. The core game is more or less there for you to enjoy. More or less every controller you can think of will work with the game, whether it's a pad or a stick. I personally use the xb1 and the dualshock 4 controllers [d-pad].

Capcom will slowly release new characters with a new game model where there won't be more SFV games, but rather any additions will be tacked onto this one. That's not to say there won't be a SF-VI but until then this is the only game you'll need (no ultras).

For those familiar with the game, you will notice the new features very quickly. A big ones I like is the V-Reversal function. A mechanic that allows you to get out of frame traps, corners etc...

The graphics looks pretty good. The art-style is on the cartoony side perhaps as a reference to the original 2D sprite design of the game.

For those new to the franchise, this iteration of street fighter is a good place to start your fighting career :). Just keep in mind that to get good, you'll need a good deal of practice so until then don't feel too bad if you've lost a match.

reviewText:
Aside from the obvious server issues that will probably be fixed soon, the no-keyboard-remapping and the stupid censorship, here are the main reasons why the game is currently too frustrating to play and not worth it in its current state:

- Too much downtime between matches, what is the point of having no character select if you have to wait 80% of the time in menus or loading screens? And this is not a server issue but a critical flaw in game design, we had the same problem in beta, I just hoped it would be fixed for retail.
- If your opponent ragequits you don't get any points, and he keeps his winning streak, in 2016.

I won't even comment on the barebones story mode or other aspects that make this an Early Access title, fix these 2 items and my review will probably turn positive but in the meantime, thumbs down it is.

reviewText:
This is an incomplete product that should be Early Access and not a $60 release:

-Many core features like the character challenges and tutorials will be patched in in the coming months.
-You need to be online to play some SP features that unlock new colors and costumes. If you get disconnected you lose your progress, for example halfway through a 50-round survival mode session.
-The character story mode is one of the worst offerings I've seen in a videogame. Ugly rushed art, abysmal voice acting, non-existent AI, no end boss or anything fun, just an hour+ of tedious mashing to unlock some costumes.
-No Versus CPU mode. Yes you read that right.

Many annoying things that should have been ironed out before release:

-Ranked matches don't let you select a character. You need to go back to the main menu to change your favorite character" everytime you want to play someone else.
-Settings don't autosave. Enjoy setting up the same options over and over anytime you boot up training mode.
-No way to edit key bindings (need third party software).
-No DirectInput controller support (need third party software).

If all you care about is play online or local versus then go for it. If you expect a full product then hold on until Capcom patches in core features."

reviewText:
As a rather big follower of street fighter I was looking forward to playing this game. The gameplay is as great as always but I find it impossible to recommend this game to basically everyone besides your couch versus players since it's the only fully functional mode as I write this review.

Story mode is underwhelming with only 4 missions per character with barely any lore, cringeworthy voice acting and kinda rushed looking artpieces. You can finish this one in an hour.

Versus is functional and pretty much as you expect it to be.

Online is just not functional. Some people are reporting that it's working for them, I can't and many others either. Being stuck in the opponent searching" process is the most common issue for me.

Survival is pretty barebones and gets boring quickly.

Training is actually well done but you can't really call this one a "gamemode"

I'll probably change this review to positive when they add more single player content to it and fix online but for now it's just unrecommendable for me. Stay away from it until further patches and content."

reviewText:
Aside from the obvious server issues that will probably be fixed soon, the no-keyboard-remapping and the stupid censorship, here are the main reasons why the game is currently too frustrating to play and not worth it in its current state:

- Too much downtime between matches, what is the point of having no character select if you have to wait 80% of the time in menus or loading screens? And this is not a server issue but a critical flaw in game design, we had the same problem in beta, I just hoped it would be fixed for retail.
- If your opponent ragequits you don't get any points, and he keeps his winning streak, in 2016.

I won't even comment on the barebones story mode or other aspects that make this an Early Access title, fix these 2 items and my review will probably turn positive but in the meantime, thumbs down it is.

reviewText:
Do you want a feature complete game? Do not buy this.
Do you want a fighting game? You might want to consider reading more before buying. And please make sure to read more reviews before deciding whether to buy this! Use this as a second opinion!

This game is not feature complete. There is no real story mode; no real singleplayer. There are no lobbies (there is something called a battle lounge, but its 1 on 1). There is no challenge system and while I have not played survival, its pretty quick and lame from what I have read. All this stuff is coming in the free March update. The games mandatory tutorial does not tell you much aside from that your fists can punch, you can throw out a fireball if you are Ryu, your legs can move and kick, and you can block stuff. The tutorial, however, fails to mention more crucial things: did you know you can quick recover from a knockdown into a roll by double tapping left when you hit the ground? You can also quick rise by double tapping down. They acknowledge throw breaks, but don't tell you how to do them, which might seem like its common sense to most people but someone brand new to the series wouldn't get it. The tutorial overall is just very vague for a game that is trying to bring new blood into a niche genre.

As a fighting game, I'm enjoying this. I think right now its a solid experience if you want to hop in, train, and fight live players. I play them pretty casually, so I'm no expert at the systems present, but it does change quite a bit from the last title I spent time with (SFIV). The new Variable Gauge system creates more identity to the characters, as activating your V-Trigger will alter your moveset, giving them new properties or creating new moves entirely. Every character now has a V-Reversal while allows them to escape pressure through a knockdown as well as a V-Skill that alows characters to dissipate projectiles or other perks unique to the character. The Variable Gauge system changes a lot from the last system, but people who have played the Alpha series or Third Strike might feel right at home with it.

Links and execution in this game also feels much easier than 4, making it a breeze to get in and start practicing your bread and butters until your thumb or wrist hurts. This also means this game is very accessible to new fighting game players, so long as they take the neccessary steps to get outside information, have a proper mindset, and a willingness to learn from their mistakes.

Overall, I think Street Fighter V can only get better from here on. At $60, its a very tough decision for a lot of people. If you wanted a feature complete game, you should wait until March or maybe April at the latest before jumping into the fray. If you know all this, and don't care, you have a fighting game that is very solid when the servers aren't acting funny. Here is hoping Capcom keeps it up and makes this game fantastic, because it has the potential to survive for a really long time if they play their cards right.

reviewText:
On first inspection it seems as though something is missing from this game. There is no arcade mode, an emphasis on choosing one character and a story mode that does not challenge you or enhance the gaming experience in the slightest.

However, once you get a taste of the game play and see how the fighting system is balanced you will feel like you are not only playing the best Street Fighter yet but an entirely new take on the game. Getting into ranked matches and graduating from rookie to bronze and so on, brings a reward of it's own as you get to fight fighters that are at the same level as you and the survival mode provides it's own brand of challenge (always starts really easy but on the hard and hell levels spikes in difficulty providing an challenge that is very addictive).

Yes, a few things have to be improved but this game is the most balanced first release of a street fighter series yet. Every character is actually fun to use and learning their unique styles adds to the game's scope. It is always good having your best character reserved for ranked matches but playing versus with many of the characters has provided hours of fun. I look forward to the updates but there is no game at the moment that I look forward to playing more after a hard day's work. It really is the best Street Fighter in terms of game play I have ever played and I started on champion edition on the SNES.

reviewText: I remember when I was just a little Chowd, and I would love playing Street Fighter arcade machines whenever/wherever I could find one. There really weren't any combos, or v-triggers, or ultimate moves- but the game was fun. It had a soul that was undeniably evident, and it oozed with the love that Capcom clearly put into making it- this explains why I would constantly have to wash my hands after handling slimy joysticks and buttons... probably had nothing to do with pizza grease. Anyways, I purchased Street Fighter 5 because of my love for the originals. Sadly, however, the game has become a money-making shell of it's former self. I don't know how one of my favorite childhood games has been twisted into such a steaming pile of perverted, shameless, hollow, forced, half-baked, sewage boy excrement. Unfortunately, I forced myself to play it for longer than 2 hours, so I could not get a refund for the worst-spent $60 of my life... besides for that one time I bought Charles Barkley's Shut Up and Jam. Only difference is- I wrote them a letter when I was around 10 years old and they actually gave me a refund.\n\nChowd- out.

reviewText:
Great core gameplay, but not without its faults. If you are interested in single player game modes then I would suggest holding off on purchasing this game until that content arrives, but if you are mostly interested in online then you would find a lot of enjoyment with this game. With that said, there are still some things to consider.

The biggest issue in my opinion is that this game (A PC and PS4 exclusive) lacks Direct input support on PC. This means that all of your PS4 arcade sticks won't work on this version of the game, you will need a stick that has X input (360 stick) or use third party software to get your direct input stick to work. Doesn't sound like a huge issue, but I have experienced noticeable input lag with using anything but Joytokey. Maybe your system will work better with the some software over others, I don't know, there are several of these sofwares but Direct input support has been promised on launch day by a Capcom representative and they haven't mentioned it since. For all the players who like to play 2D Fighters on keyboard, there is no key mapping, so you're stuck with the default mapping.

The next issue I'd like to mention is Ragequitting. Capcom's solution to ragequitting is laughable at best. These types of games will always have ragequitters and many games have implemented very capable systems to handle the issue, but Capcom's solution has taken too long to be implemented and has the posibility of locking out people who genuinely disconnect from the servers for up to two hours.

Again, the gameplay is solid,  but if Capcom would just do a better job communicating with the community about the issues in the game and when we can expect certain things to be fixed instead of constantly giving us the silent treatment I think the game would be doing a lot better.

reviewText:

-Fantasic fighting mechanics (V-Gauge, V-Reversal, and V-Trigger)

-Monthly updates adding new characters, stages, and costumes.  (In my opinion it makes me want to play it longer)
-Great soundtrack (the usual with capcom)

-The new characters fit very well and don't feel out of place.

-Capcom has said No More" to the "Super" and "Ultra" variants of street fighter and will add to this game monthly.
