reviewText:
Like another kind user and player of SFV I feel obligated to help flesh out the issue with Street Fighter V.  So far I'm incredibly pleased.  I'm pleased because I knew ahead of time that the game was going to be released in a bare bones state due to players wanting to have a hands on experience before the big tournament that's just around the corner.  That being said I knew ahead of time that the net issue was going to be a bust.   I woke up at midnight for the release knowing full well I would not be playing online.  As dozens of people I've played with over at SFIV world came piling into SFV the prediction came true.  I'm not even mad, nor should the average player.  A rush like that is what it is and any release launch with such a tremendous following that not only has a casual interest but also a vested career interest is going to have its hiccups.  Many of the hiccups were explained ahead of time by Capcom.

The lack of support for controllers, pads can be overlooked.  I've stucked with my 3rd party tool since Street Fighter IV, Yatagarasu and had no issues in V.  Capcom said that support for all of the variety of controllers and such would come.  Being forewarned about your purchase is key and the responsibility of the player.  When I saw Story Mode I was pleased but mistook it for arcade mode.  I complained and then found out that things like arcade mode and other modes would come in the near future.  That is a huge bonus for me, but I had already resigned myself to the idea of playing the game in its bare bone state up until more content came.

This game is a project alongside Capcom.  Capcom has laid out an insanely good foundation with this game even with the issues at hand.  The issues at hand will be fixed, pure and simple.  Our community has in a lot of ways forgotten the variety of amazing games that have had rocky starts and when it comes to cross platform it's even worse I can imagine.  So far given the Beta's consistent play I'm impressed.  I barely knew the difference between PS4/PC if I did at all.  The players and Capcom are going to be working together on Street Fighter V.  Play the game to earn the DLC, show your investment in the game by playing and spreading the word.  What we have is a blueprint for what could be another amazing series in the Street Fighter universe.  I sincerely hope that impatience and ignorance (Not knowing) do not ruin it for many players.  That would be stupid (Willfully ignorant).

Graphically I think the game looks amazing.

Gameplay:  I came from Ultra, it feels right at home with solid changes that I'm getting accustomed to.  It feels a bit slower with more thought involved.  With easier combos it's a nice step toward more player diversity in strategy in my opinion.

Audio:  I.. can't remember music, but the quality is good?

I don't do reviews often outside of games I adore and I've been a Street Fighter fan since SFII in the arcades.  SFV has some solid gameplay in my opinion and the fact that I can work toward what I want in the game gives me a reason to keep sharpening my skills.  For many of the naysayers that are upset about the controller support, key bindings, current content I would advise other readers to disregard them in favor of knowing that those players had every opportunity to know ahead of time what they were getting for sixty dollars.  I purchased the game for 45 dollars, due to the fact that I wasn't a huge fan of paying so much for so little at one time.  Also I'm almost always broke!

So patience please and fight on!

reviewText:
Buy the beta instead. You see the Beta wasn't broken and allowed me to play it. Now I press start and the game tabs you out a few times till it manages to work it's way to the main menu. I mind you it's going at 10fps. Once at the main menu you try to turn the settings down and... oh wait! You're already set to 240x100 with everything at the lowest and you're now getting 60 in the menus but only 10-20 in game. You can be running 980ti in SLIx2 but that won't help you here cause you're going to lag. I have a 960m and an i7 4720MQ. This system was far more than capable of running the game at max settings 1920x1080 and achieving 60fps at the same time. Buy the game around late march if you really want it. That is the real release date.

Edit 1: I loaded up my desktop and I can play the game now. It has a GPU with roughly the same power as a 960m although it is still better. And it's AMD. The problem so far seems to be Nvidia's drivers that have caused the slow down in SFV. Currently running a Radeon 7870 and an i7 5820k @3.8Ghz. Though after putting some time into the game I see that the connection is terrible to everyone. I have 6Mb/s upload and 60Mb/s download. My ping is usually 20ms near me and across the country it is 50-60ms. (1 frame is roughly 16 ms in a 60fps game). The netcode for SFV (GGPO) uses rollbacks to give a smooth or seemingly lagless environment online. The problem with that is capcom totally has it messed up. So you're Ryu and you throw an EX fireball from full screen and the other player is hit by your hadouken. Then in a fraction of a second the player teleports from in the hit stun of the fireball to in your face. Their health literally goes back up, you lose the EX bar and they do a full punish. I am not kidding... this is how online is. Now USFIV has been out for a long time and the netcode, as bad as it was, was polished to a degree so this comparrison is a little unfair. I could, in USFIV, play someone from Japan with a 3 frame lag online connection (which is really good) and it would be impeccably stable. I can't play my friend in the same room online without lag in SFV.

Here is some more info.
My friend has dual 860ms in sli and an I7 4720MQ. Both of our laptops supprt wireless AC and so does my router. The connection over wifi from my router to either of our laptops is sub 1ms. So stop complaining that wireless creates lag. It might on wireless B but wireless N and AC are pretty safe bets on not being the cause of a bad connection. And my desktop is wired directly to my modem. I've tested it and the connection problems are not on my end and usually not on another persons end either. The game is simply laggy and nearly unplayable online. Even the best connections will have teleporting. Buy it in March if you really want the game when the problems have a good chance of being slightly better than they are now.

reviewText:
Its not a very exciting fighting game to me.  Gets very boring, very quickly.  Ugly and clumsy menu & interface.  Lousy flavor of the month character DLC. Very stubby normals for all characters. Everyones anti air normals seem very slow with narrow range. Even online fights are boring after 20 mins. Longer load times all around and poor netplay with rollback & connectivity issues.  Overall, its just not very good IMO.

Most USF4 players I know transitioned just fine, they're into it and they claim they love it (tho hardly any of them are ever playing it). However this review is my opinion. Myself and a few others i know who played a lot of USf4 agree, its just kinda dull. I doubt this game will have the same following and impact that USF4 had, my guess for the FGC is, this game will be dead and replaced with another franchise afer a year or two, because SFV is just a bit flat and very unpolished.

reviewText:
* Online play
The netcode is really good! Getting a match with a random player (casual or ranked) is better than Street fighter IV as you can choose to automatically enter a match only if it has a high quality connection! A well needed feature that we never got for Street Fighter IV. But the wait time in between matches are really bad. They need to cut introduction segments like Here comes a new challenger!" if that somehow slows down loading time. Or pausing the searching for games feature as soon as you move into settings in training mode. A paus feature in those menu's would be a much better design choice.

* Story mode is not finished.
You can't set the difficulty
date: there's no challenge at all and only between 3-5 matches per character.  There's no animation to convey the story and the still images feel lackluster
recommended: rushed and more like a proof of conscept than something usable in a release title. There are lots of cheap fan artists around that are really good. There's no good reason not to hire those people. However

Gameplay:

* Inputs are easier that SF4
No more 1 frame combos.

* Less comeback mechanics
If you played good until the end there's no risk of your opponent getting lucky with a random ultra like SF4.

* It's less rewarding to do random risky moves.
The game overall forces you to learn footsies as it does not reward you with high risk high reward random moves.

Compared to Street Fighter IV:
It's hard to say at this point how good it is compared to SF4. It's different. The core gameplay seems great but question is how deep the skill level is. It's defenetly not bad and it might be quite deep once we get to know the game and after a bit of tweaking from the developers.

Street Fighter V feels like an early access indy title but I guess Capcom is to proud of a company to put that tag on their game. It probably would benefit them though as people would be more willing to check back later to see if it's better than before.

Conclusion:
The core gameplay is ok. There are lots of other great fighting games on steam that give you a lot more for your money than this one
commentsCount: so I can't really recommend it unless you're a Street Fighter player who want's something new."

reviewText:
This is the game that I really want to give a positive review to and the reason why is that the devs created a stunning game with wonderful fighting mechanics and that is the core of a fighting game. I will never giving a fighting game a bad review for its poor story as if a person shows up to a fighting game looking for a engrossing story they have purchased the wrong game. The flaws in this game for me that are the deal breakers are:

- Servers not working at launch (some people argue that this is to be expected this is not to be expected this game was in beta for awhile capcom had more than enough time to get it right)
- Lack of single player content, no traditional arcade mode? I mean really how hard is that to put into a game as others have said it makes the game feel unfinished
- 1 character constume, (2 if you count the 2nd that is locked into story mode ONLY, even after clearing story mode)
- Two menu's on the game locked out saying coming in March as a free update" to me that clearly means that not all of the game was ready for the Feb 16 launch but corp Capcom said LAUNCH the game
date: FIX it later.\n\nI will take another look at this game in March
recommended: but as of right now there is no way I could ever recommend this game to anyone in its current state."

reviewText:
Well... I love streetfighter games, and I knew going in, that there would be huge lack of content.  I didn't care.  I just wanted streetfighter.

However, this game is so buggy, it really doesn't work on my system at all.  primary specs below:
4670k i5 @ 4.5ghz
8gb 2600mhz ddr3
R9 290 over clocked

I expected to play this game at 1440p like all my games (witcher 3, mortal kombat, alien isolation, far cry 4, mad max, etc...).  However, as I'm writing this, I am only able to run it at 720p or the game goes into slow motion (seriously unplayable).  Even if I turn down the settings all to low, I cannot increase the resoluation at all.  -note: the frame rate is playable but the game is in slow motion.  Its not the entire game laging either, as the audio is still on target (while their mouths lag far behind the dialogue).

Oh and lets not forget my friend Error 2100d... I average about 2.2 minutes of connectivity to capcom's networks for every hour I play... and I live in the city with 100mbps...

update (2/18).

I tried this game on my work pc and it runs great at 1080p.  The work pc is a haswell i5, 8gb ram, and gtx760.  I'm shocked that its running so well, given how much more powerful the r9 290 is compared to the gtx760.  I'm not completely convinced itsan AMD card problem though, as I have read about some nvidia cards having the same issue.  -Hope this gets sorted out.

reviewText:
* Online play
The netcode is really good! Getting a match with a random player (casual or ranked) is better than Street fighter IV as you can choose to automatically enter a match only if it has a high quality connection! A well needed feature that we never got for Street Fighter IV. But the wait time in between matches are really bad. They need to cut introduction segments like Here comes a new challenger!" if that somehow slows down loading time. Or pausing the searching for games feature as soon as you move into settings in training mode. A paus feature in those menu's would be a much better design choice.

* Story mode is not finished.
You can't set the difficulty
date: there's no challenge at all and only between 3-5 matches per character.  There's no animation to convey the story and the still images feel lackluster
recommended: rushed and more like a proof of conscept than something usable in a release title. There are lots of cheap fan artists around that are really good. There's no good reason not to hire those people. However
hoursPlayed: this game should not be bought for it's story mode
voteText: so it shouldn't be a deal breaker even if it's very lackluster. Also
helpfulPercent:
they are going to add more to this mode later on.

* Survival mode
This is the only mode that's worth playing singleplayer. The game mode itself is quite nice. The only bad design choice is that if you choose the hardest difficulty
votesHelpful: you still have to fight super easy opponents the first 20-40 matches. Other than that
votesTotal:
it's quite nice.

* Some joysticks does not work and you can't remap the keys.
My Street Fighter Tournament Arcade Stick does not work. I had to make a workaround by remapping the button with the third party software JoyToKey.

* Game crashes
If you experience a complete crash to windows every 15 minutes
votesFunny:
make sure you don't have a wacom tablet connected. After it's removal it hasn't crashed once.


Gameplay:

* Inputs are easier that SF4
No more 1 frame combos.

* Less comeback mechanics
If you played good until the end there's no risk of your opponent getting lucky with a random ultra like SF4.

* It's less rewarding to do random risky moves.
The game overall forces you to learn footsies as it does not reward you with high risk high reward random moves.

Compared to Street Fighter IV:
It's hard to say at this point how good it is compared to SF4. It's different. The core gameplay seems great but question is how deep the skill level is. It's defenetly not bad and it might be quite deep once we get to know the game and after a bit of tweaking from the developers.

Street Fighter V feels like an early access indy title but I guess Capcom is to proud of a company to put that tag on their game. It probably would benefit them though as people would be more willing to check back later to see if it's better than before.

Conclusion:
The core gameplay is ok. There are lots of other great fighting games on steam that give you a lot more for your money than this one
commentsCount: so I can't really recommend it unless you're a Street Fighter player who want's something new."

reviewText:
The game is fun in offline versus mode, and if that's all you plan to play, then I do recommend it.  The gameplay is solid, and the framerate feels smooth.

However, anything that requires online mode is pretty much broken right now...constant disconnects, and extremely slow server response time if you can actually stay connected.  There's also a general lack of polish.  The store and arcade mode 3-round AI fights are missing.  Configuration options are minimal. (no benchmark to make sure your settings allow a full 60 fps, no option in versus mode to hold start for pause, only player 1 can choose to return to character select in versus mode, etc.)  Training mode options are unintuitive, and the shortcuts using RS are sluggish in taking effect.  The tutorial is terrible.

I'll be happy to change my rating when Capcom irons out all the wrinkles, but in its current state, it still feels like a beta.

Update: Server performance has improved significantly.  I still get occasional disconnects, but it's definitely playable now.

reviewText:
This is the game that I really want to give a positive review to and the reason why is that the devs created a stunning game with wonderful fighting mechanics and that is the core of a fighting game. I will never giving a fighting game a bad review for its poor story as if a person shows up to a fighting game looking for a engrossing story they have purchased the wrong game. The flaws in this game for me that are the deal breakers are:

- Servers not working at launch (some people argue that this is to be expected this is not to be expected this game was in beta for awhile capcom had more than enough time to get it right)
- Lack of single player content, no traditional arcade mode? I mean really how hard is that to put into a game as others have said it makes the game feel unfinished
- 1 character constume, (2 if you count the 2nd that is locked into story mode ONLY, even after clearing story mode)
- Two menu's on the game locked out saying coming in March as a free update" to me that clearly means that not all of the game was ready for the Feb 16 launch but corp Capcom said LAUNCH the game
date: FIX it later.\n\nI will take another look at this game in March
recommended: but as of right now there is no way I could ever recommend this game to anyone in its current state."

reviewText: If you want to jump straight into the multiplayer as soon as you get the game and don't give a rat's ♥♥♥ about single player content go ahead and get it. Although you're going to need joytokey if you're using stick. I've had pretty bad frame drops (even while standing still in the training stage) and my game tends to crash every 10-15 minutes or so. Although that's probably a me problem. I'm using an Asus with 12 gigs of ram, i7 (yes I know not optimal for fighting games), and a NVIDIA 940m graphics card. As a long time Street Fighter fan, I really want to like this game, but as of now, for the lack of base content such as the challenge mode, cinematic story, and store (which you need to buy the story mode alternates) I would say keep your money. If people were to read this review after about 6 months of this review then the story would be different. As of 2/16/16 I would not recommend Street Fighter V, and it pains me to say that.

reviewText:
Edit: March update added trial mode.  The rest stands.

$70 cdn AAA title was released unfinished.  Currently there is:
-No Arcade mode
-'Story' mode is a currently a 2-3 round prologue, with AI so dumb a toddler literally mashed random buttons and beat it.
-No directinput support
-No keyboard remapping
-Less characters than the original SF4 release

Basically Capcom shovelled this out the door to have a new title for their Capcom Pro Tour instead of the tired old USF4.  Providing a functional game for the home market was clearly secondary.  This is not a $20 'preview edition' like MGV: Ground Zeroes, this is supposed to be a full AAA release.  Capcom has said many of these things will be patched in later, but that does not change the fact that for now you are paying full price for a multiplayer beta test.  If you're still on the fence about buying it anyway, just wait for the eventual sale on it at this point.

THIS GAME SHOULD CURRENTLY BE FLAGGED EARLY ACCESS AND BUYERS SHOULD TREAT IT AS SUCH.

reviewText:
Online problems, no story mode, controller support is trash, blah blah blah.

Got that out the way.

I was surprised when there was no arcade mode, I didn't play beta. So I was disappointed because I wanted to practice up vs the CPU. But all is not lost like people say it is. There is a well thought out Survival mode. Which normally I shy away from, but they have taken the idea and revamped it. There are health boosters, extra gauges to fill your v trigger, 2x Damage, and other boost you can choose from all in between rounds. But they come at a cost! You have to spend the points you earn playing each round which effects your overall point total in the end which is used to unlock skins and other kick-nacks. In addition to all that you can chose between 5 different levels of AI difficulty. All and all its a nice alternative to a classic story mode. I can say its refreshing.

I would say this game is worth checking out right now, every relevant complaint is one that will be addressed soon, the near future. or immediately. Also, I have the recommended settings and the game runs great at 1080p.

reviewText: An incredible new entry in the Street Fighter Series shows its latest entry as both the most accessible and most compellingly competitive iteration yet: Street Fighter V is a charming, addicting, beautiful, and engaging online fighting game made for the latest generation - of consoles and of players both. Its incredibly diverse cast offers toolsets for every playstyle from defensive and calculating to viciously aggressive. The game is strategically deep and deeply rewarding; a variety of modes offer offline ways for players to learn the game, and it boasts some of the best online netcode yet (only to be rivaled by GGPO-netcode games). Pay no mind to the ant-minded, short-sighted negative reviews about launch day problems - this is the world's premiere fighting game that boasts the absolute best the entire genre has to offer you, and it is going to get better and better for free for years to come. Get on the streets.
voteText: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Alright so I wrote this review while I had the flu and didn't really cover as much as I wanted to, so let's get down to it because this deserves a proper review.

First off lets address what is in the game currently:
16 fighters
10 stages
Prologue Story Mode
Survival Mode
Training Mode
Offline 2 player
Ranked Matches
Casual Matches
2 People Battle Lobbies
Replays

WHAT IS NOT HERE BUT IS COMING:
Trials
Arcade Mode
8 player lobbies
Cinematic Story Mode

We have known about this far before the game dropped, yet several people bought the game and are upset about the lack of single player content currently despite the fact that Capcom did not make any effort to hide its absence, this information was circulating eventhubs, capcom unity, hadoken, shoryuken, facebook, twitter, etc.

But let's talk about the characters. There are currently 16 characters in the game with 6 more planned as DLC that will be released from March to September. Of the 16 in game, 8 are from SF2, 4 are from the Alpha series, and 4 are brand new characters. Some of the characters have seen heavy changes in both their visual design and in gameplay style, such as Nash and Dhalsim, while others have remained mostly the same such as Ryu and Zangief.

In regards to the DLC, each character will cost $6 or 100,000 fight money. Fight money is a currency you make in game by winning matches and completing various activities in the singleplayer. For point of reference, it would take close to 3, maybe 4 hours for even an amateur to beat the prologue story mode and easy survival mode with all characters. Doing this will net you close to 300,000 fight money, enough for the first 3 dlc characters. Currently the other thing we know we can spend fight money on is the story mode costumes unlocked in the store by completing prologue story mode with that character and purchased for 40,000 fight money. These can only be earned with fight money and not real life money. Premium costumes will also be coming to the store and these can be purchased only with real life money, I believe about $4.

As for the gameplay itself, the game is ridiculously solid. You'll probably notice instantly that this is not Street Fighter 4 and you can not play it like Street Fighter 4. Whether this makes you happy or sad depends on the person. For new mechanics we have v-skill, v-trigger, and v-reversal. V-skill is a move used by pressing MP+MK and does not spend any meter. What it does varies per character but generally builds your new v-gauge. V-gauge can be used on two thngs: V-trigger and v-reversal. V-trigger expends your entire v-gauge and its effects vary per character, but generally turns the tides of battles very quickly. It is used by pressing HP+HK while your gauge is full. V-reversal uses 1 meter of the v-gauge and is use by pushing forward and 3 punches while blocking. It will generally knock the enemy away or have you perform an evasive maneuver. Either way its great for escaping pressure safely if you can't otherwise.

Another major mechanic is the inclusion of crush counters. For those familiar with Blazblue, it is similar to a fatal counter. It occurs when you counter the opponents attack with a specific normal, generally a heavy attack, from your character. The crush counters do more damage, apply more stun, build v-gauge, and leave the opponent wide open for attacks. Learning what moves do crush counters and how to combo off of them is a very important factor and leads to perhaps one of the bigger shifts between SF4 and SFV.

SFV is a more defensive and punish based game. That's not to say rushdown pressure isn't important or that its useless, but it adds things to be considered. Normals in this game have so far been noticeably safer and less prone to punish on block than other games. This game seems to encourage making reads to counter your opponent ahead of time or otherwise making them whiff. There are still tons of unsafe things in this game to be sure and its all the more important to know what they are and when to use it. With how fast stun is built and the inclusion of crush counters, matches can be ended very quickly by someone who has completely downloaded their opponent.

I wouldn't say this is slower than 4 at all, but it has been called simpler. And it is. SF4 had so much stuff to consider its ridiculous. This game definitely focuses on returning to the basics of street fighter and emphasing commitment to your attack and general control of the field. Mindgames and fundamentals are the focus here. A lot of people are talking about jabs, whether they are more or less useful than in 4, personally it seems its just as important, just in a different way. You can not confirm light attacks into medium into specials fadc into ultra in this game. If you jab, you jab and thats mostly it. They have horrible damage and limited combo potential. But they are fast and great for interrupting things with long start up or grabs, their original purpose.

It is far to early to speak on terms of the balance of the game, everyone has their picks for most broken, for me its Bison, but we really need to wait and see on that one. So far it seems everyone has at least some tech they have to make them viable.

As for the single player content there is not much to say. Story mode is basically 2-3 battles with whatever character you pick with dialogue, plot, and artwork between each battle (1 round and ridiculously easy, starts you out with full meter). Survival mode has Easy (10 rounds), Normal (30), Hard (50), and Hell (100). Easy nets you your character's 3rd color, normal is 4-6, and hard is 7-10. The ai is busted in survival. Its basically brain dead easy and never moves or blocks much for about the first 25 or 30 and then it suddenly spikes to Ryu doing the Evo Moment 37 daigo parry into combo into critical art and giving you random rng on health supplements. Hopefully they'll sell colors for 10,000 fight money come march or something.

The netcode is really solid when ther servers aren't down, which is more frequent than I like, but its still the first week. Follow @SFVServer on twitter for live updates on what they are working on  currently, planned maitenance, and server status.

Over all this is an amazing games if you know what you're getting in for and do your research and love fighting games and multiplayer. If you're in it for singleplayer content wait until March or June, simple as that. If you're wondering why the game was released in the state it is, its because people asked Capcom in swarms to release it early in time for Evo and the Capcom Pro Tour. Capcom did this for the FGC and long time Street Fighter fans and its sad to see them receive so much flak for it, especially since they didn't hide the state of the game. Hopefully people will come around once more single player content is added. Capcom is finally listening to the fans and also letting us get dlc created after the game launched for free,  and I don't want that to change.

reviewText:
despite a bit of a rocky launch - which seems to be the norm for this day and age of meeting deadlines and pushing products out - this game is godlike

it is amazingly satisfying. im talking about the animations, the punching people, the normals that have being blocked animations and hitting animations - fantastic

i already greatly like street fighter, but i won't be an apologist - the game was pushed out a little too early in the context of -- if you are a new player, you won't be getting much in the way of things helping you out, at least, during the launch - the story mode is going to be added at a later date, battle lobbys can only hold 2 people at the moment, -- along with a bunch of other features that weren't ready to be pushed out at the same time as the official game launch date

capcom is pushing this game to the e-sport level. i had a lot of competitive and casual friends buy it with various opinions on it. most of the competitive friends say its great, feels good, all the characters are vibrant and grandoise compared to their earlier counterparts - the more casual friends i have playing it don't have the past games for reference to make the comparisons on what has changed so they focus less on that and more on what they are currently getting instead of digesting the changes - which at launch, isn't overly much

anyways - it comes with pros and cons.

PRO:
- it is insanely fun, once you break the barrier of being able to think more on your opponent then how to do a fireball and uppercut at the right times
- it's built to last, given the slew of characters they are unlocking, once per couple months was the most recent rumour
- it is much more beginner friendly in regards to combos

CON:
- beginner friendly combos doesn't mean much if you don't know how to play the neutral - you have to go to 3rd party sources to understand that
- fighting games at their core are their maximum level of fun and engaging when your execution reaches a level where you can start concetrating on the match and situations, rather than what button does what and how to fireball - this is /no/ different

TL;DR

it's street fighter, however - probably the best street fighter yet. -- that still means, it's street fighter though.

reviewText:
2/22/2016 Edition - Review
TL;DR: Most people should get this game in a month or two.
People who want to get into the fantastic *already complete* multiplayer sooner will have a blast getting it now, with some caveats.


The game addresses many issues that SF4 had, making this one of the most dynamic and fun fighting games on the PC but there are plenty of things that are getting patched in later that should've been included. I won't list them all, other reviews detail them more in-depth than I could but I will try and highlight some of them.


Expanded Summary:
If you are a fighting game veteran - will go straight to the multiplayer mode and training only - then this is worth getting as released. There were several things rushed about this game but the base gameplay and training options weren't. The tiers are very tightly packed as of this writing (only standout is Zief being weak at high levels) The training mode won't teach you anything about fighting games but if you're a vet, the options are great to play around with.

DO NOT GET IT RIGHT NOW if you're interested in anything else, aren't used to fighting game theory, and/or want to use a DirectInput device. While 3rd party software will let you use  a DI device, this will add in a bunch of measurable delay. Capcom has confirmed that this will be addressed so don't forget about the game because of it, you'll only be denying yourself a great experience.


Notable things that may persist even after the planned patches, will update as needed:

Netcode -
Fantastic, except for an exploit which can offload any lag to one player over another. If you're starting to win but then suddenly get some stutter on your end while they keep reacting beautifully, it might be suspect. This is mostly an issue against PC players. Does not seem to be prevelant at my current tier (Super to Ultra Bronze) but may be an issue with higher ranked people.

Ragequits -
They don't count as a loss. Once again, will be more prevelant with higher ranked players but just know that I'm not seeing a lot of it. I'd predict that this was done because of early server issues. Major issue if not fixed after the content update drops in a month.

Artificial Load Delays due to Always Online -
Game checks in with the server for every load. Some of this is unavoidable, but shouldn't be the case for something like training. Your mileage may vary but it may be an annoyance if you're used to SSD wait times.


Overall, I'm recommending this game because of the sheer amount of personal enjoyment I've experienced and because of the quality and balance of the base gameplay.

Review will be updated as necessary.

reviewText:
So I wrote out a long review and Steam lost it so heres a short one.

I like the game. If you want to know the features it has please read the store page, I want to specifically address peoples concerns here.

Issues people have....

Limited fightstick support - Can be fixed with JoyToKey. Not ideal, but they plan on fixing it in the future.

Missing features - This was announced, and if you dont like it pretend the game comes out in March, if you preordered the game before this was announced you would have paid anyway, I like having 2 weeks to earn some FP before the stores open.

Art style/Graphics - There has been footage and screenshots for ages, I dont understand peoples sudden problem with it.

Server issues - Games with online features more often than not have issues on launch. This is not a problem exclusive to SFV.

The store model - It works for League of Legends and if its what they need to not release DLC or a SFVI in a years time I support it. Plus free content for playing the game, which im going to do anyway.

Keyboard mapping - This sucks and from what I have seen it wasnt common knowledge before the game came out, this can be fixed through a 3rd party program and from what I have read they are going to fix this in the future.

Easy AI - Go play on the ranked servers theres pleanty of people with the same issue you can take out your frustrations on.

Long story short the fighting feels fantastic and what more do you want from a fighting game? Would you rather have an  early story mode that feels gross?

They gave us a little taste of whats to come and I want more, sure the game Is a little bare right now but what I have seen I love (other than the server issues which they are quite actively talking about on twitter) and this is more than enough for me to toy around on till the free March update which will probably feel like a new game.

reviewText:
So here's the deal. The game is getting better. The netcode is a million times better than it was at launch and right now far exceeds anything the sf4 netcode was ever capable of. As has been said a thousand times before, the competitive portion of the game itself is incredibly solid. There is a very good reason why this game is shattering attendance records at tournaments and events. The game is good, period.

So.... should you buy it?

If you like street fighter already, yes. If you want to get into competitive fighting games, also yes. However, outside of those two demographs there really isn't that much reason to pay the entry fee. Unlike blizzard games, or most mobas, street fighter is missing a compelling universe. If your into fantasy, story, characters, collecting stuff, or just about anything outside of winning there really isn't much here. People might say that sf4 is better in this respect, but they are wrong. Arcade mode is really the only thing that seperates the two in terms content beyond competition, and sfv just decided to split all the arcade mode content into two (significantly less interesting) forms.

So the main weakness in street fighter v is the same weakness in the entire series. If you like street fighter you will love this game, if you don't like street fighter then this game will not change your mind: at least for now. Capcom has a reputation for long term support and multiple re-releases. So when the game is inevitably re released under a new name (as a free content update, that’s a promise the community would never forgive if broken), maybe then it will be worth a second look.

reviewText:
If one were to recommend Street Fighter V based solely on the gameplay it's pretty top-notch. The re-inventions to a lot of the cast has made the game really nice as everyone feels viable. The netplay (when the servers are up!) is top-notch and on a good connection feels amazing. That said, the package surrounding the game at launch feels super bare-bones and there are some really questionable decisions made with regards to earning colors, having a laughably bad story mode, X-Input only (I'm sure glad I have to use Joy2Key for a game made in 2016!!!) controller support, etc etc etc.

The one really damning thing though is that at launch the game does a TERRIBLE job at teaching new players at how to play. Fighting games are notorious for this but if you want new players there should be a robust tutorial and not require players to search Youtube for what a V-Skill is. Apparently this might be fixed in the future but first impressions are pretty important. Stuff like this spreads pretty quickly.

Despite my gripes I still recommend it but really only after they've patched a lot of stuff. The base game is fantastic and I feel like it's the best SF since Third Strike. The problems can be fixed but at launch it's maybe not so great.

reviewText:
This game is fantastic. Capcom managed to make it rewarding to vets, while making some tweaks to make it easier for new players. Overall this is a rock solid product, and instantly one of the best fighting games out there.


Punching and kicking people in the face has never been more satisfying. Street Fighter V feels like an expansion to the Alpha series. Alpha counter is back, powerful level 3 supers are as potent as ever, EX moves feel like Level 1 supers, big counter hit juggles and combos are a core part of the gameplay, and much of the cast got their start in Street Fighter Alpha.

The V gauge system is a welcome change and adds nice variety. This bar governs your ability to alpha counter (aka V Reversal) and V Trigger. You must choose which to use your bar for, which adds a nice layer to the game. Activating V Trigger will spend your whole bar and you cannot V Reversal. Alternatively V Reversal costs 1 chunk of V bar so you cannot activate V Trigger. Offence or Defense, it's your choice.

Many things are just like you'd expect in a street fighter game. The low/overhead/throw mixup game is present, along with things like Trip Guard, Negative Edge, pianoing, frame traps, etc. However, a few key changes were made that players will need to be aware of. Super Grabs can combo. That's right, Zangief can headbutt you and hit confirm into grab super. You cannot die from block damage (except supers!), you take white recoverable damage from blocking medium or hard attacks, and alpha counters can be baited and grabbed with fast recovering attacks.

Currently you can play training mode ( which has lots of tools for creating situations you would want to reproduce), VS mode, story, survival, and a few online modes. The game has cross platform matchmaking PC to PS4 which hasn't been done before. Capcom is still making improvements on the infrastructure of the online platform, and they are being very transparent about that via @SFVServer which is great. My overall experience so far has been positive. Many online matches feel very smooth, and things are only getting better.

A couple of things I'd personally like are to make ranked matches 2/3 and allow player 2 to rematch between matches. Overall those are small complaints though, and this game is a lot of fun. I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Been playing for a week now, up to about 18 hours, and I have no problem giving this a thumbs up.

-The characters are diverse (and by that I mean F*** Birdie).
-The stages are better than SF4 (and by that I mean SFxT stages).
-The matchups are balanced (unless you lose).
-The mechanics are easy to learn (and by that I mean it's not an Arc System Works Game).
-The connectivity is great (and by that I mean the connectivity of people on YOUR continent).
-The actual feel" of the game is one of the best fighting game experiences I've seen in a long while (and by that I mean it's one of the best fighting game experiences I've had in a while).

I think the only negatives that irk me on a regular basis is the wonky interface.  Trying to do things like find where to see replays or turning off notifications was confusing at first.  It works
date: but it can be streamlined.  One week out connectivity issues are mostly dealth with but stat pages don't seem to work.\n\nReally
recommended: as long as you've got the patience to learn and study from your mistakes there's no reason pros and casuals alike can't enjoy this game.  The systems and techniques that pros like to use on one another are there
hoursPlayed: and for the casual player the motion inputs have been simplified and the frame windows widened.  And if you're mid-tier it just seems like the best of both worlds.\n\nI understand some are dissapointed in the amount of alternate modes / extras in the game but

reviewText:
What's great is that capcom made a combat system that has a lot of depth but is also easier for newcomers to play. Unfortunalety, and surprisingly for the best combat system in the series for newcomers, there's not much content that allow people to learn the game (no single player,  etc.).

A lot of people have been complaning about the amount of characters... but to me, it's all about quality over quantity. Personally, there were a lot of characters I never saw being played ... and a lot of them felt the same. I think capcom made the right choice by reducing the roster of characters but making sure they all felt different.

In summary, if you enjoy fighting games, you'll enjoy this one. If you are new to the genre, you're not very good at it and you don't have friends to play this game with... wait a few months for some proper solo content to be added to the game.

reviewText:
///\WARNING///\nThis is coming from a mostly casual fighting game player
I'd like to gradually get better at this game
So this is here to look at the game at a casual point of view
----------------------
Street Fighter V, I've been pretty hyped for this game for a good while (4-6 months)
When I recieved this game I was very excited to get into the fighting of the game
And I can safely say the actualy FIGHTING for a FIGHTING game is good!
It is remarkably fun to work with
----------------------
The fighting in this game is obviously fun but...
You are a bit limited to what you can do in the rest of the game
Don't get me wrong, this game is still pretty great!
But the game lacks things other fighters usually have
This game is still not complete and characters are still coming out
I really hope that in the future they will add more
The current modes you can fight in is:
Story, Versus, Survival, Challenges, Training, Ranked Match, Casual Match, Battle Lounge
http://static.capcom.com/unity/haunts/Menu_Challenges.png
----------------------
STORY
The story currently is very plain and simple
It has drawn pictures without animation and dialogue with voice acting
This is also where you recieve your story mode costumes (I'll explain this later, just bear with me)
BUT WAIT THERE'S MORE
Capcom wil be releasing a full and complete story mode this June!
Or atleast it's said to be released in June
http://www.eventhubs.com/news/2016/feb/13/story-mode-street-fighter-5-will-feature-over-hour-cinematic-content-possibility-exists-future-story-expansions/
----------------------
VERSUS
There really isn't much to say here, every fighter usually has a versus with two players fighting each other on the same computer
----------------------
SURVIVAL
This is not the most liked gamemode
Survival is where you will choose one of 4 difficulty settings and a character to fight with
Your 4 options are :  Easy   Normal   Hard   Extreme
You may choose any character in the game to fight with
You will have to fight enemies for a varied amount of time and recieve credits to get you temporary upgrades for the next enemy.
When you complete one of these you recieve Colors for the costume you are wearing
This leads to extreme grinding
Easy= 1 new color for the costume you're wearing
Medium= 3 more colors
Hard= 3 more colors
https://ryanmarkel.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/STREET-FIGHTER-V_20160217234353.jpg
These battles are treated as any other: beat the enemy and win
Depending on what difficulty you chose will change how many battles you will have to fight.
Easy= 10  Medium= 30  Hard= 50  Extreme/Hell= 100
The upgrades you get are completely random which makes this unfair
You could be at level 29 and desperately need a full health recovery but instead recieve a low health recovery and lose everything!
These can be very time consuming and if you lose at that level 29 or level 49 or even possibly 99, you get nothing back.
I honestly get bored of this mode rather quickly
But some competitive players might enjoy this
----------------------
CHALLENGES
This is in some fighting games
This is where the game teaches you combos for each character and currently they have 10 combos for each character you could learn through challenge mode.
----------------------
TRAINING
This is where you play as any character and...well...train!
You fight against a non moving CPU where you can establish your own combos, or train already known combos.
You are able to set up a good amount of CPU options.
http://www.streetfightergod.com/#!training-mode-guide/aw4u9
----------------------
RANKED & CASUAL MATCHES
Ranked matches raises your LP when you win.
Your Rank depends on how high your LP is.
Platinum = 7,500 LP
Ultra Gold = 6,500-7,499 LP
Super Gold = 5,500-6,499 LP
Gold = 4,000-5,499 LP
Ultra Silver = 3,500-3,999 LP
Super Silver = 3,000-3,499 LP
Silver = 2,000-2,999 LP
Ultra Bronze = 1,500-1,999 LP
Super Bronze = 1,000-1,499 LP
Bronze = 500-999 LP
Rookie= 0-499 LP
The Higher rank you are, the more LP you lose when you...lose
Well, it's a bit more than just that
Lets say you are a Silver rank and you got paired up with a Rookie
If you beat the Rookie, you get a little bit of points and the Rookie loses a little bit of LP
If you lose, the Rookie gains lots of more LP compared to what you would get if you won and you would lose much more LP then he would if he lost.
CASUAL
Casual is a less competitive mode for people who don't really wanna rank up that much
This mode is a bit more focused to get you fight money (I'll explain this later)
----------------------
BATTLE LOUNGES
Find battle lobbies according to your search settings
For example
I wanted to find someone with a high internet connection stability and on a PC
you can find a lobby with these settings
you can somewhat compare this to how the Lobbies work in Skullgirls and Guilty Gear
----------------------
There are still 2 things I haven't covered
The Shop, Fight money and Fight Request
----------------------
FIGHT MONEY
Fight money is acquired from:
Story Fights
Winning Survival modes
Casual Matches
Ranked Matches
----------------------
SHOP
This is where you spend your fight money
You can buy:
Titles
Costumes for characters
Colors for those Costumes
Stages
Characters
----------------------
FIGHT REQUESTS
While you are playing some of the game modes, you are able to press the start button and select battle settings and wait for someone else with those settings to fight you at any time
----------------------
CONCLUSION
Street Fighter 5 feels amazing to control but few options
The way to unlock colors can be annoying
No arcade mode
Currently incomplete story and still characters coming out

I would recommend this game to anyone willing to pay $60 for this game
If you are kinda not really thinking that it's not worth it yet, you're not wrong
The Season pass costs  $30
It will give you all upcoming characters and stages
For now, to people who are not really sure on buying it, you might be a bit dissapointed
I'd recommend buying it (If you're not sure on buying it) when the story comes out and a bit more characters too
Or wait until the summer sale

reviewText:

reviewText:
Edit: March update added trial mode.  The rest stands.

$70 cdn AAA title was released unfinished.  Currently there is:
-No Arcade mode
-'Story' mode is a currently a 2-3 round prologue, with AI so dumb a toddler literally mashed random buttons and beat it.
-No directinput support
-No keyboard remapping
-Less characters than the original SF4 release

Basically Capcom shovelled this out the door to have a new title for their Capcom Pro Tour instead of the tired old USF4.  Providing a functional game for the home market was clearly secondary.  This is not a $20 'preview edition' like MGV: Ground Zeroes, this is supposed to be a full AAA release.  Capcom has said many of these things will be patched in later, but that does not change the fact that for now you are paying full price for a multiplayer beta test.  If you're still on the fence about buying it anyway, just wait for the eventual sale on it at this point.

THIS GAME SHOULD CURRENTLY BE FLAGGED EARLY ACCESS AND BUYERS SHOULD TREAT IT AS SUCH.

reviewText:
The game currently offers terrible value.

They delayed the story mode of the game to summer and the character-stories that are in the game last 5 minutes each with ca. 3 fights and a few still-images. Seriously. There is currently no arcade mode. Or challenges. The tutorial is nothing but a button-check and explains nothing about the mechanics of the game. The movelists do not list any framedata and do not mention all properties of a move (such as armor or projectile invincibility).

The game also lacks polish. You can see glaring clipping problems with almost every model. Hair and chainst go through their own body. The game is not well optimized and you need to edit .ini files to tweak the game properly. There are no advanced graphics options. NO REBINDABLE KEYS! The game also does not support all peripherals that it should and even for PC fightsticks, you may need to install a work-around. The main menu is also a joke. There is tons of dead space and 20% of the actual menu is taken up by an image. If you are using a controller, you have to make your way around that image to get to the option you want. You cannot spontanuously decide which character to pick, you have to pick it beroe even starting the match-search.

If you can see past all of that and only care for online, the game has some terrible disconnection problems currently. The worst part of that is that you can't even waste your time with the story mode because you won't be able to earn fightmoney, the in-game currency while offline. So you lose out on currency which you could later spend on characters. Oh, the online store is also still unavailable.

IF you can connect to the server, you won't be happy with the lobby system which currently only supports 2 players, making a lobby almost pointless.

The downtime between matches is way too long. When it finds a game, you will be taken through SEVERAL loading screens, from the overly long Match Found" to black to the character select (where won't selevt your fighter
date: you need to do that in the menu beforehand lol) to white and THEN to the match. After the match
recommended: you have to watch an animation and then wait for every point to be added to each profile. Then black
hoursPlayed: then back to the menu. It is insane.\n\nNow

It even introduces option selects in the tutorial. That game also has tons of offline content such as a story for every character AND a story-mode. It also has Trials etc.

Fanboys will say "But SFV will build up on this!"
Killer Instinct which will also come to PC with crossplatform play released with little content initially BUT it didn't ask for full price

reviewText:
For what it's worth, the only reason why you would want to get this game now is if you want to play solely online and learn the game and the characters in so far.

Reasons why you shouldn't get it now if you are unsure are:
The game is half-finished. The mechanics are all in and stuff, but it lacks a huge amount of stuff a fighting should normally really have day one. It doesn't even have an arcade mode (!). Supposedly, things are coming in the future but for a full price title it gives you nothing for your money. The story mode is merely a prelude that even a baby can finish (literally) and the tutorial teaches a new player by far not enough. If you search for fighting games that actually give you great singleplayer content and also have great tutorials, look for the Guilty Gear/Blazblue series or check out Skullgirls.

But there are also more reasons, even for online only players, that should just not be in a game which had like 5 betas and had no notion of being not finished. Basic stuff like training mode actually saving your settings. Matchmaking is kinda ♥♥♥♥ed up and so is online playing, with some people being unable to play at all and horrible rollback on matches that could actually be fixed with very quick patches. The game also has horrendous loading times, where you sometimes spend more time on the loading screen than in the actual game. Also, the game STILL doesn't have D-input support which makes the vast majority of controllers or sticks not useable without using third party programs. And to top it off, pc version lacks both, keyboard rebinding and an option to turn off v-sync. Could go on and on about what's wrong, but if you are unsure better wait for a few months where it will hopefully be in a more finished state.

reviewText: Incredibly fun game. I really enjoy that they removed bs mechanics like FADC and 1-frame links. Now combos are reasonably do-able and still rewarding. The cast feels quite varied as well, with none (at the moment) seeming like complete garbage compared to others, but I'll let the pros pick them apart and inevitably find the strengths of each character.\n\nI don't particularily like the idea of releasing a bare bones game with the promise of more content on the horizon. But I guess if the new content is free, then we have alot to look forward to.

reviewText:
Online problems, no story mode, controller support is trash, blah blah blah.

Got that out the way.

I was surprised when there was no arcade mode, I didn't play beta. So I was disappointed because I wanted to practice up vs the CPU. But all is not lost like people say it is. There is a well thought out Survival mode. Which normally I shy away from, but they have taken the idea and revamped it. There are health boosters, extra gauges to fill your v trigger, 2x Damage, and other boost you can choose from all in between rounds. But they come at a cost! You have to spend the points you earn playing each round which effects your overall point total in the end which is used to unlock skins and other kick-nacks. In addition to all that you can chose between 5 different levels of AI difficulty. All and all its a nice alternative to a classic story mode. I can say its refreshing.

I would say this game is worth checking out right now, every relevant complaint is one that will be addressed soon, the near future. or immediately. Also, I have the recommended settings and the game runs great at 1080p.

reviewText: An incredible new entry in the Street Fighter Series shows its latest entry as both the most accessible and most compellingly competitive iteration yet: Street Fighter V is a charming, addicting, beautiful, and engaging online fighting game made for the latest generation - of consoles and of players both. Its incredibly diverse cast offers toolsets for every playstyle from defensive and calculating to viciously aggressive. The game is strategically deep and deeply rewarding; a variety of modes offer offline ways for players to learn the game, and it boasts some of the best online netcode yet (only to be rivaled by GGPO-netcode games). Pay no mind to the ant-minded, short-sighted negative reviews about launch day problems - this is the world's premiere fighting game that boasts the absolute best the entire genre has to offer you, and it is going to get better and better for free for years to come. Get on the streets.
voteText: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Alright so I wrote this review while I had the flu and didn't really cover as much as I wanted to, so let's get down to it because this deserves a proper review.

First off lets address what is in the game currently:
16 fighters
10 stages
Prologue Story Mode
Survival Mode
Training Mode
Offline 2 player
Ranked Matches
Casual Matches
2 People Battle Lobbies
Replays

WHAT IS NOT HERE BUT IS COMING:
Trials
Arcade Mode
8 player lobbies
Cinematic Story Mode

We have known about this far before the game dropped, yet several people bought the game and are upset about the lack of single player content currently despite the fact that Capcom did not make any effort to hide its absence, this information was circulating eventhubs, capcom unity, hadoken, shoryuken, facebook, twitter, etc.

But let's talk about the characters. There are currently 16 characters in the game with 6 more planned as DLC that will be released from March to September. Of the 16 in game, 8 are from SF2, 4 are from the Alpha series, and 4 are brand new characters. Some of the characters have seen heavy changes in both their visual design and in gameplay style, such as Nash and Dhalsim, while others have remained mostly the same such as Ryu and Zangief.

In regards to the DLC, each character will cost $6 or 100,000 fight money. Fight money is a currency you make in game by winning matches and completing various activities in the singleplayer. For point of reference, it would take close to 3, maybe 4 hours for even an amateur to beat the prologue story mode and easy survival mode with all characters. Doing this will net you close to 300,000 fight money, enough for the first 3 dlc characters. Currently the other thing we know we can spend fight money on is the story mode costumes unlocked in the store by completing prologue story mode with that character and purchased for 40,000 fight money. These can only be earned with fight money and not real life money. Premium costumes will also be coming to the store and these can be purchased only with real life money, I believe about $4.

As for the gameplay itself, the game is ridiculously solid. You'll probably notice instantly that this is not Street Fighter 4 and you can not play it like Street Fighter 4. Whether this makes you happy or sad depends on the person. For new mechanics we have v-skill, v-trigger, and v-reversal. V-skill is a move used by pressing MP+MK and does not spend any meter. What it does varies per character but generally builds your new v-gauge. V-gauge can be used on two thngs: V-trigger and v-reversal. V-trigger expends your entire v-gauge and its effects vary per character, but generally turns the tides of battles very quickly. It is used by pressing HP+HK while your gauge is full. V-reversal uses 1 meter of the v-gauge and is use by pushing forward and 3 punches while blocking. It will generally knock the enemy away or have you perform an evasive maneuver. Either way its great for escaping pressure safely if you can't otherwise.

Another major mechanic is the inclusion of crush counters. For those familiar with Blazblue, it is similar to a fatal counter. It occurs when you counter the opponents attack with a specific normal, generally a heavy attack, from your character. The crush counters do more damage, apply more stun, build v-gauge, and leave the opponent wide open for attacks. Learning what moves do crush counters and how to combo off of them is a very important factor and leads to perhaps one of the bigger shifts between SF4 and SFV.

SFV is a more defensive and punish based game. That's not to say rushdown pressure isn't important or that its useless, but it adds things to be considered. Normals in this game have so far been noticeably safer and less prone to punish on block than other games. This game seems to encourage making reads to counter your opponent ahead of time or otherwise making them whiff. There are still tons of unsafe things in this game to be sure and its all the more important to know what they are and when to use it. With how fast stun is built and the inclusion of crush counters, matches can be ended very quickly by someone who has completely downloaded their opponent.

I wouldn't say this is slower than 4 at all, but it has been called simpler. And it is. SF4 had so much stuff to consider its ridiculous. This game definitely focuses on returning to the basics of street fighter and emphasing commitment to your attack and general control of the field. Mindgames and fundamentals are the focus here. A lot of people are talking about jabs, whether they are more or less useful than in 4, personally it seems its just as important, just in a different way. You can not confirm light attacks into medium into specials fadc into ultra in this game. If you jab, you jab and thats mostly it. They have horrible damage and limited combo potential. But they are fast and great for interrupting things with long start up or grabs, their original purpose.

It is far to early to speak on terms of the balance of the game, everyone has their picks for most broken, for me its Bison, but we really need to wait and see on that one. So far it seems everyone has at least some tech they have to make them viable.

As for the single player content there is not much to say. Story mode is basically 2-3 battles with whatever character you pick with dialogue, plot, and artwork between each battle (1 round and ridiculously easy, starts you out with full meter). Survival mode has Easy (10 rounds), Normal (30), Hard (50), and Hell (100). Easy nets you your character's 3rd color, normal is 4-6, and hard is 7-10. The ai is busted in survival. Its basically brain dead easy and never moves or blocks much for about the first 25 or 30 and then it suddenly spikes to Ryu doing the Evo Moment 37 daigo parry into combo into critical art and giving you random rng on health supplements. Hopefully they'll sell colors for 10,000 fight money come march or something.

The netcode is really solid when ther servers aren't down, which is more frequent than I like, but its still the first week. Follow @SFVServer on twitter for live updates on what they are working on  currently, planned maitenance, and server status.

Over all this is an amazing games if you know what you're getting in for and do your research and love fighting games and multiplayer. If you're in it for singleplayer content wait until March or June, simple as that. If you're wondering why the game was released in the state it is, its because people asked Capcom in swarms to release it early in time for Evo and the Capcom Pro Tour. Capcom did this for the FGC and long time Street Fighter fans and its sad to see them receive so much flak for it, especially since they didn't hide the state of the game. Hopefully people will come around once more single player content is added. Capcom is finally listening to the fans and also letting us get dlc created after the game launched for free,  and I don't want that to change.

reviewText:
despite a bit of a rocky launch - which seems to be the norm for this day and age of meeting deadlines and pushing products out - this game is godlike

it is amazingly satisfying. im talking about the animations, the punching people, the normals that have being blocked animations and hitting animations - fantastic

i already greatly like street fighter, but i won't be an apologist - the game was pushed out a little too early in the context of -- if you are a new player, you won't be getting much in the way of things helping you out, at least, during the launch - the story mode is going to be added at a later date, battle lobbys can only hold 2 people at the moment, -- along with a bunch of other features that weren't ready to be pushed out at the same time as the official game launch date

capcom is pushing this game to the e-sport level. i had a lot of competitive and casual friends buy it with various opinions on it. most of the competitive friends say its great, feels good, all the characters are vibrant and grandoise compared to their earlier counterparts - the more casual friends i have playing it don't have the past games for reference to make the comparisons on what has changed so they focus less on that and more on what they are currently getting instead of digesting the changes - which at launch, isn't overly much

anyways - it comes with pros and cons.

PRO:
- it is insanely fun, once you break the barrier of being able to think more on your opponent then how to do a fireball and uppercut at the right times
- it's built to last, given the slew of characters they are unlocking, once per couple months was the most recent rumour
- it is much more beginner friendly in regards to combos

CON:
- beginner friendly combos doesn't mean much if you don't know how to play the neutral - you have to go to 3rd party sources to understand that
- fighting games at their core are their maximum level of fun and engaging when your execution reaches a level where you can start concetrating on the match and situations, rather than what button does what and how to fireball - this is /no/ different

TL;DR

it's street fighter, however - probably the best street fighter yet. -- that still means, it's street fighter though.

reviewText:
Now that the online seems to be functional (for the most part) I can recommend this game.

Only to a hardcore fighting game player. There is really not much here to attract the casual player or one that is not interested in simply just playing matches over and over online.

Most fighting game enthusiasts would take a new game 2 or 3 months early if they could only play simple online ranked matchmaking with the promise of fleshing out more content for a richer experience in the coming year, as long as they fulfill that promise and add things of actual substance i can recommend this game, or I'd have to be forced to change my review to negative as even though I'm completely in love with the system mechanics and flow of SFV (a much more stripped down, reminiscent of older games yet with the right modern sensibillities well worked in) the product is completely barebones at launch and will only appeal to die-hards that are content with duking it out over and over again.

Even for competetive players, there aren't things like only training mode or lobby features here at launch. But with the approach to treat the game as a developing platform similliar to Killer Instinct, I can give this a TENTATIVE recommend, with the proviso they do not drop the ball as the continue to add features and content to this game.

reviewText:
A game in it's early ways, but with a solid core. It has everything a fighting game fan would need in 16 very different characters, good balance, solid training mode and netcode that is solid most of the time after the slightly shaky start where the servers where simply overwhelmed.

This game is not for people who expect huge amount of singleplayer content as the game is very sparse with it at this point. It will all come along the way for free, so you will not be squeezed out of more money after you put down the initial payment.

Personally I'm having a great time and would have paid double the price for the game as it pretty much contains all that I would need from a fighting game as it is right now. Having more being added later on for free is sugar on top.

reviewText: It's fun for what it is, you need an emulator if you wanna use the Madcatz fightstick or the game pad because for some reason it only has a controller layout for Xbox 360 and Xbone controllers. And if your using a 360 or One controller for some reason it contantly thinks you're pressing up on the analog stick and will just randomly start going up on the menu screen or make your character randomly start jumping(which is terrible for me because I am strictly a pad playing scrub), which has cost me some matches. It might just be that I'm using bad controllers or something, but I don't think that's the case because I tried 3 different controllers to test it. But, then again, all the controllers i used are like a year old, so I don't honestly know if it's the games fault or mine. But, other than that, I think the game is fine, challenge mode is okay, online matches are fun, but the nedcode is a bit iffy right now so just hope for good connections, plus you can look for matches while you're doing other stuff in the game like the challenge mode or trainning mode which is pretty cool and helps you when you are about to die on the challenge mode because it resets the level you're on after the match is over. The game doesn't have an arcade mode or a vs cpu mode, so that kinda sucks, but the level of entry for this game is pretty low so you can enjoy yourself playing some online matches. All in all, I recommend it for people who like fighting games online, but if you're not into that, I'd say wait until July to get it, that way you have all the offline features and you will get some new characters that aren't in the game yet.

reviewText:
If one were to recommend Street Fighter V based solely on the gameplay it's pretty top-notch. The re-inventions to a lot of the cast has made the game really nice as everyone feels viable. The netplay (when the servers are up!) is top-notch and on a good connection feels amazing. That said, the package surrounding the game at launch feels super bare-bones and there are some really questionable decisions made with regards to earning colors, having a laughably bad story mode, X-Input only (I'm sure glad I have to use Joy2Key for a game made in 2016!!!) controller support, etc etc etc.

The one really damning thing though is that at launch the game does a TERRIBLE job at teaching new players at how to play. Fighting games are notorious for this but if you want new players there should be a robust tutorial and not require players to search Youtube for what a V-Skill is. Apparently this might be fixed in the future but first impressions are pretty important. Stuff like this spreads pretty quickly.

Despite my gripes I still recommend it but really only after they've patched a lot of stuff. The base game is fantastic and I feel like it's the best SF since Third Strike. The problems can be fixed but at launch it's maybe not so great.

reviewText:
This game is fantastic. Capcom managed to make it rewarding to vets, while making some tweaks to make it easier for new players. Overall this is a rock solid product, and instantly one of the best fighting games out there.


Punching and kicking people in the face has never been more satisfying. Street Fighter V feels like an expansion to the Alpha series. Alpha counter is back, powerful level 3 supers are as potent as ever, EX moves feel like Level 1 supers, big counter hit juggles and combos are a core part of the gameplay, and much of the cast got their start in Street Fighter Alpha.

The V gauge system is a welcome change and adds nice variety. This bar governs your ability to alpha counter (aka V Reversal) and V Trigger. You must choose which to use your bar for, which adds a nice layer to the game. Activating V Trigger will spend your whole bar and you cannot V Reversal. Alternatively V Reversal costs 1 chunk of V bar so you cannot activate V Trigger. Offence or Defense, it's your choice.

Many things are just like you'd expect in a street fighter game. The low/overhead/throw mixup game is present, along with things like Trip Guard, Negative Edge, pianoing, frame traps, etc. However, a few key changes were made that players will need to be aware of. Super Grabs can combo. That's right, Zangief can headbutt you and hit confirm into grab super. You cannot die from block damage (except supers!), you take white recoverable damage from blocking medium or hard attacks, and alpha counters can be baited and grabbed with fast recovering attacks.

Currently you can play training mode ( which has lots of tools for creating situations you would want to reproduce), VS mode, story, survival, and a few online modes. The game has cross platform matchmaking PC to PS4 which hasn't been done before. Capcom is still making improvements on the infrastructure of the online platform, and they are being very transparent about that via @SFVServer which is great. My overall experience so far has been positive. Many online matches feel very smooth, and things are only getting better.

A couple of things I'd personally like are to make ranked matches 2/3 and allow player 2 to rematch between matches. Overall those are small complaints though, and this game is a lot of fun. I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Been playing for a week now, up to about 18 hours, and I have no problem giving this a thumbs up.

-The characters are diverse (and by that I mean F*** Birdie).
-The stages are better than SF4 (and by that I mean SFxT stages).
-The matchups are balanced (unless you lose).
-The mechanics are easy to learn (and by that I mean it's not an Arc System Works Game).
-The connectivity is great (and by that I mean the connectivity of people on YOUR continent).
-The actual feel" of the game is one of the best fighting game experiences I've seen in a long while (and by that I mean it's one of the best fighting game experiences I've had in a while).

I think the only negatives that irk me on a regular basis is the wonky interface.  Trying to do things like find where to see replays or turning off notifications was confusing at first.  It works
date: but it can be streamlined.  One week out connectivity issues are mostly dealth with but stat pages don't seem to work.\n\nReally
recommended: as long as you've got the patience to learn and study from your mistakes there's no reason pros and casuals alike can't enjoy this game.  The systems and techniques that pros like to use on one another are there
hoursPlayed: and for the casual player the motion inputs have been simplified and the frame windows widened.  And if you're mid-tier it just seems like the best of both worlds.\n\nI understand some are dissapointed in the amount of alternate modes / extras in the game but
