reviewText:
///\WARNING///\nThis is coming from a mostly casual fighting game player
I'd like to gradually get better at this game
So this is here to look at the game at a casual point of view
----------------------
Street Fighter V, I've been pretty hyped for this game for a good while (4-6 months)
When I recieved this game I was very excited to get into the fighting of the game
And I can safely say the actualy FIGHTING for a FIGHTING game is good!
It is remarkably fun to work with
----------------------
The fighting in this game is obviously fun but...
You are a bit limited to what you can do in the rest of the game
Don't get me wrong, this game is still pretty great!
But the game lacks things other fighters usually have
This game is still not complete and characters are still coming out
I really hope that in the future they will add more
The current modes you can fight in is:
Story, Versus, Survival, Challenges, Training, Ranked Match, Casual Match, Battle Lounge
http://static.capcom.com/unity/haunts/Menu_Challenges.png
----------------------
STORY
The story currently is very plain and simple
It has drawn pictures without animation and dialogue with voice acting
This is also where you recieve your story mode costumes (I'll explain this later, just bear with me)
BUT WAIT THERE'S MORE
Capcom wil be releasing a full and complete story mode this June!
Or atleast it's said to be released in June
http://www.eventhubs.com/news/2016/feb/13/story-mode-street-fighter-5-will-feature-over-hour-cinematic-content-possibility-exists-future-story-expansions/
----------------------
VERSUS
There really isn't much to say here, every fighter usually has a versus with two players fighting each other on the same computer
----------------------
SURVIVAL
This is not the most liked gamemode
Survival is where you will choose one of 4 difficulty settings and a character to fight with
Your 4 options are :  Easy   Normal   Hard   Extreme
You may choose any character in the game to fight with
You will have to fight enemies for a varied amount of time and recieve credits to get you temporary upgrades for the next enemy.
When you complete one of these you recieve Colors for the costume you are wearing
This leads to extreme grinding
Easy= 1 new color for the costume you're wearing
Medium= 3 more colors
Hard= 3 more colors
https://ryanmarkel.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/STREET-FIGHTER-V_20160217234353.jpg
These battles are treated as any other: beat the enemy and win
Depending on what difficulty you chose will change how many battles you will have to fight.
Easy= 10  Medium= 30  Hard= 50  Extreme/Hell= 100
The upgrades you get are completely random which makes this unfair
You could be at level 29 and desperately need a full health recovery but instead recieve a low health recovery and lose everything!
These can be very time consuming and if you lose at that level 29 or level 49 or even possibly 99, you get nothing back.
I honestly get bored of this mode rather quickly
But some competitive players might enjoy this
----------------------
CHALLENGES
This is in some fighting games
This is where the game teaches you combos for each character and currently they have 10 combos for each character you could learn through challenge mode.
----------------------
TRAINING
This is where you play as any character and...well...train!
You fight against a non moving CPU where you can establish your own combos, or train already known combos.
You are able to set up a good amount of CPU options.
http://www.streetfightergod.com/#!training-mode-guide/aw4u9
----------------------
RANKED & CASUAL MATCHES
Ranked matches raises your LP when you win.
Your Rank depends on how high your LP is.
Platinum = 7,500 LP
Ultra Gold = 6,500-7,499 LP
Super Gold = 5,500-6,499 LP
Gold = 4,000-5,499 LP
Ultra Silver = 3,500-3,999 LP
Super Silver = 3,000-3,499 LP
Silver = 2,000-2,999 LP
Ultra Bronze = 1,500-1,999 LP
Super Bronze = 1,000-1,499 LP
Bronze = 500-999 LP
Rookie= 0-499 LP
The Higher rank you are, the more LP you lose when you...lose
Well, it's a bit more than just that
Lets say you are a Silver rank and you got paired up with a Rookie
If you beat the Rookie, you get a little bit of points and the Rookie loses a little bit of LP
If you lose, the Rookie gains lots of more LP compared to what you would get if you won and you would lose much more LP then he would if he lost.
CASUAL
Casual is a less competitive mode for people who don't really wanna rank up that much
This mode is a bit more focused to get you fight money (I'll explain this later)
----------------------
BATTLE LOUNGES
Find battle lobbies according to your search settings
For example
I wanted to find someone with a high internet connection stability and on a PC
you can find a lobby with these settings
you can somewhat compare this to how the Lobbies work in Skullgirls and Guilty Gear
----------------------
There are still 2 things I haven't covered
The Shop, Fight money and Fight Request
----------------------
FIGHT MONEY
Fight money is acquired from:
Story Fights
Winning Survival modes
Casual Matches
Ranked Matches
----------------------
SHOP
This is where you spend your fight money
You can buy:
Titles
Costumes for characters
Colors for those Costumes
Stages
Characters
----------------------
FIGHT REQUESTS
While you are playing some of the game modes, you are able to press the start button and select battle settings and wait for someone else with those settings to fight you at any time
----------------------
CONCLUSION
Street Fighter 5 feels amazing to control but few options
The way to unlock colors can be annoying
No arcade mode
Currently incomplete story and still characters coming out

I would recommend this game to anyone willing to pay $60 for this game
If you are kinda not really thinking that it's not worth it yet, you're not wrong
The Season pass costs  $30
It will give you all upcoming characters and stages
For now, to people who are not really sure on buying it, you might be a bit dissapointed
I'd recommend buying it (If you're not sure on buying it) when the story comes out and a bit more characters too
Or wait until the summer sale

reviewText:
For what it's worth, the only reason why you would want to get this game now is if you want to play solely online and learn the game and the characters in so far.

Reasons why you shouldn't get it now if you are unsure are:
The game is half-finished. The mechanics are all in and stuff, but it lacks a huge amount of stuff a fighting should normally really have day one. It doesn't even have an arcade mode (!). Supposedly, things are coming in the future but for a full price title it gives you nothing for your money. The story mode is merely a prelude that even a baby can finish (literally) and the tutorial teaches a new player by far not enough. If you search for fighting games that actually give you great singleplayer content and also have great tutorials, look for the Guilty Gear/Blazblue series or check out Skullgirls.

But there are also more reasons, even for online only players, that should just not be in a game which had like 5 betas and had no notion of being not finished. Basic stuff like training mode actually saving your settings. Matchmaking is kinda ♥♥♥♥ed up and so is online playing, with some people being unable to play at all and horrible rollback on matches that could actually be fixed with very quick patches. The game also has horrendous loading times, where you sometimes spend more time on the loading screen than in the actual game. Also, the game STILL doesn't have D-input support which makes the vast majority of controllers or sticks not useable without using third party programs. And to top it off, pc version lacks both, keyboard rebinding and an option to turn off v-sync. Could go on and on about what's wrong, but if you are unsure better wait for a few months where it will hopefully be in a more finished state.

This game has some of the most satisfying feeling combat. The animations and sound effects are just right, making it feel extremely meaty. Very satisfying to land hits in this game. The Characters are all pretty different thanks to the v skill and v trigger system. Ken and Ryu are not just simple copy and paste jobs this time around.

Lack of single player content be damned - this is some of the most intense fun online experiences i've had in a while and i'm someone who is relatively new to fighting games (started with usf4 in august last year). The more lenient combo system really helps to get down the basics and bnb's (bread and butter) of a character really fast, while the game still offers plenty of depth with footsies and general mindgames.


One thing though - for players who are starting out with sf v as their first fighting game:

The tutorial will not really be helpful for you, at all. You will have to search online and in the steam guide section to get you started. You will also need a lot of frustration resistence, because being a beginner means you will get blown up a lot at the start. It will take a time for you to get a feel for the flow of the game and when to press buttons and when not etc. Don't get discouraged, it will get better if you put in the time :). Also, now that the game is new, it's probably one of the best times to enter because there are other new people as well. When i started out with us4 it was 8 years or something into it's lifecycle, so people with 1000hrs playtime were much more common then people with low playtime or even beginners who just started out, too.


Capcom is in it for the long run with this game. Content WILL come and this game will be played for years to come.

If you aren't flustered by the lack of sp content right now on launch and only care about the online (which admittedly does have some server probles at the moment,let's hope todays maintenance fixes some of them) this game is imo well worth the money - considering you'll get thousands of hours out of it. Or you could always join at a later date,when more content has been added. In the end it is up to what you value the most i guess, but this is a fine game at it's core that was a bit rushed but feels just so good to play.

I would definitely recommend this to every fan of fighting games and newcomers, because now is the best time to join and learn. Later on people will already be pretty good and have figured everything out, making it harder for you to start.



If you are looking for sparring partners you can also just add me - i'm always on the look out for more people to play lobbies with.



Technical Stuff:

I have a pretty powerful rig, so running this game with max settings in windowed borderless mode (with borderless gaming app 8.4) in 60 fps is not a problem. I do play without AA though, because i think the one that the game offers is WAY to aggressive and introduces some weird ghosting/smearing artifacts or something. Game looks much cleaner with AA set on low and because of the constant 60 fps jaggies really aren't noticeable in motion.


I also did this to get rid of the motion blur while still having the other effects from the post processing apply:

https://www.reddit.com/r/StreetFighter/comments/462cch/how_to_adjust_the_individual_postprocess_options/


Character models in this game are ace. Looking at them in the char select screen is just a treat - which makes the obvious clipping in some animations all the more disappointing. Backgrounds are pretty hit and miss. There are some cool ones, but generally they have pretty low res textures, 30 fps animations which stick out and super low poly models.

Soundtrack is in my opinion pretty good. I turned off usf4 music nearly right away, but in this one i really like hearing a lot of the tracks, this is subjective of course, but i think they struck a good balance between the classic and modernized stuff.

reviewText:
Once again, Capcom comes out with great core gameplay, a game you really want to play because of how well it plays only to botch literally everything else about it.

Do we even need to talk about singleplayer content? Probably not, for 60 dollars it has literally nothing in terms of singleplayer content. I highly doubt much will change with the cinematic free dlc coming in June. Absolutely unacceptable for a 60 dollar game, especially for people who don't play fighting games for the competative aspects.

Now the crux and the biggest complaint with this game.
This game has some of the worst programming I've ever witnessed. In a game that really requires stable connections and good netcode to even function (like most twitch games), they really dropped the ball. In a world were they easily could have licensed a version of GGPO3 (which works really good with Rising Thunder another 2½D fighting game) but instead opted for their very own netcode. Huge mistake.
We left the old delay based netcode and finally entered the rollback based netcode, but in return we get some half ♥♥♥♥♥ product that have some of the dumbest decision making ever. They went out of their way to literally let the lag in a game be burdened by the person with the best computer/connection creating what most people by now know as one sided rollback. I dont know what they were thinking but they thought wrong.
The netcode suffers from other kinks, like extreme rollback from people that are just the street over which makes literally no sense. This type of rollback has also made it fairly impossible to play with people/friends across continents as you can not set a specific delay and it will just rollback really hard.
Its not good.

The matchmaking is pretty much not working. Capcom (geniuses that they are) decided to mimic League of Legends more rank based matchmaking, because everyone knows you should always just copy whatever is most popular/makes most money currently. It just doesnt work. The rank is useless as the game will still put you up with whoever is most available.
There doesnt seem to be much hidden MMR (or ELO) and LP (the in-game point system) doesnt matter at all, just like the ranks dont.

There is three different ways to play online. Ranked, Casual and Battlelounge. Ranked and Casual are just matchmaked (ie just sitting in que waiting for the game to pair you with someone to play with), but battlelounge is a game the player creates and people can join. This works the same as endless lobbies in SF4. At times it makes sense to play lounges because you might want to learn a new character but not play people who are really trying"

The ping bars (which indicates how good of a connection you have to said person) load forever and 95% of them will never show up.\nNo worries one might think because you can also see what country the lounge starter is from and in that sense be able to pick and play a lobby via that to ensure less lag. No

reviewText:
So here's the deal. The game is getting better. The netcode is a million times better than it was at launch and right now far exceeds anything the sf4 netcode was ever capable of. As has been said a thousand times before, the competitive portion of the game itself is incredibly solid. There is a very good reason why this game is shattering attendance records at tournaments and events. The game is good, period.

So.... should you buy it?

If you like street fighter already, yes. If you want to get into competitive fighting games, also yes. However, outside of those two demographs there really isn't that much reason to pay the entry fee. Unlike blizzard games, or most mobas, street fighter is missing a compelling universe. If your into fantasy, story, characters, collecting stuff, or just about anything outside of winning there really isn't much here. People might say that sf4 is better in this respect, but they are wrong. Arcade mode is really the only thing that seperates the two in terms content beyond competition, and sfv just decided to split all the arcade mode content into two (significantly less interesting) forms.

So the main weakness in street fighter v is the same weakness in the entire series. If you like street fighter you will love this game, if you don't like street fighter then this game will not change your mind: at least for now. Capcom has a reputation for long term support and multiple re-releases. So when the game is inevitably re released under a new name (as a free content update, that’s a promise the community would never forgive if broken), maybe then it will be worth a second look.

reviewText:
This game has absolutely nothing to appeal to general audiences and in a lot of ways is a ripoff.
While it may be fun for some people who like street fighter, honestly I hope general audiences don't buy this so Capcom learns that they can't just release an unfinished game at full price and concentrate on pumping out DLC that they plan to charge real money for instead of finishing the game that they released.

Its been 4 months since release and so far:
-Character models still clip with themselves
-Still no arcade mode
-Real story mode (not a crappy random 5 minutes of bad art and BO1s) still a far ways off. Supposedly one or two months if it isn't delayed.
-No stage transitions except the one they paraded around before release
-Alex's legs are on backwards half the time?
-What's with this 8f of input lag anyways?
Basically anyone who isn't wholly devoted to the multiplayer experience will be disappointed as all they have to play would be a boring short storymode, a horribly stupid survival mode, and training mode. Even if you like the multiplayer you're probably going to be disappointed.

Personally I have issues with lag online in quite a few matches and even offline oddly enough.

Besides these issues we also have a variety of annoyances.
Ken still looks pretty terrible.
Fight money accumulates extremely slowly past the first chunk so if this game lasts a while it's going to be a pain buying characters.
Controller support is not anywhere near as good as USF4 was.
2P has to politely ask 1P to go back to character select.
10 trials per character ain't much compared to SF4 again.
Game does a poor job of explaining itself to new players.
Frame data not readily available in game, probably due to the $$ you can get by selling a guide book with that.
Release schedule for DLC characters seems to be Oh god it's almost the end of the month just release whatever we have"
Guile looks like a mall cop.
It's seriously a full price game? I have played flash games with more content than this.
Not very graphically impressive despite how poorly it runs.
Feet are huge.
Guile can't put on and take off his sunglasses.

If you are all about watching the tournaments and mostly just care about the multiplayer and such sure maybe it's cool for you. But for everyone else
date: remember that you can refund stuff on steam. Like seriously. Refund it."

reviewText:
For a Street Fighter game that has such a heavy online focus...

Why does it have a horrible online netcode?

Why does ANY lag make it unplayable when other games, such as Skullgirls or Street Fighter III: 3rd Strike Online Edition, allows for compensation?

Why does it not punish rage quitters?


Also why the hell are colors locked behind survival mode? Most of my game time has been in that grinding it out to unlock everything god damn. Now I got no content to fall back on because online sucks, I physically can not get a better connection, I can't even use my joystick natively.


I'm going back to Fightcade. I get a more engaging experience playing against the old Japanese gods.

reviewText:
The game is fun, but really incomplete, flawed and badly optimised, undeveloped.

On PC, there are no keyboard settings or language settings which should be standard options. Controllers, which aren't Xinput-based, don't work plug and play / without a third-party app. The game has several audio bugs and online often malfunctions and presents errors.

The game lacks single-player game modes, such as Arcade mode, which are present in other fighting games. Certain game modes are awfully designed and not fun. Earning costume colours is a pain in the ***. Ranked matches online are contaminated by rage-quitters who aren't punished. The system that is supposed to punish them often punishes those, who people have quit on, which is ridiculous. The netcode isn't the best, sometimes all the rollbacks are put on either player and not on the other. One player has a flawless match while the other sees nothing but rollbacks/lag which results in an overall terrible experience.

Street Fighter V has terrible optimisation when it comes to input lag. Players suffer from 8 frames (~0.13s) of input lag which is unacceptable in a fighting game.

Capcom cannot keep what they deserved the players, such as DLCs and the deadlines of those. They continuously fail to meet expectations. They tease players and then let them down. An in-game store called Zenny Shop" has been delayed since March. It's been 3 months as of this review."

reviewText:
Full review: http://play-zine.com/2016/02/street-fighter-v/

Pros:

- New systems deepen the mechanics of all characters
- Cross-platform gaming and good netcode
- All DLC characters would be acquirable through gameplay

Cons:

- Sparse content, at least for now
- Intimidating to newcomers

The new Street Fighter is based on the same principles from the last three decades of franchise’s existence – two fighters dueling on a 2D side-scrolling backdrop using a combination of 6 strikes. But this is far from being a simple, shallow game.

The game ships with 16 characters to chose from, four of which are newcomers to the series, and Capcom plans to add more through DLCs (it’s possible to win them by playing the game). Although it sounds like there’s too few when compared to Ultra Street Fighter 4, we should remember that SF4 also had less than 20 fighters and that all the game changes and new characters were added through re-issues of the game at full price which fragmented the player base. The decision to make the game a basis to add new content on to over time is far better than the Capcom’s earlier practice with the series and we fully support it.

Variable System is a completely new addition with which every character gains an additional set of moves. Namely, the V-scale will fill up as you get hit or perform a chosen character’s specific move, and it has a different number of increments for each fighter. By filling up the scale, you’ll be able to activate the so-called V-trigger which enables your character to perform a specific move and temporarily strengthens his special attacks. Also, now you can block an opponent’s relentless assault, followed by a combination of buttons with which you can unbalance your opponent for a brief counter-attack window. This whole system is great and you’ll spend a lot of time discovering all of its applications and finding new move combos with familiar characters.

The current campaign is a sore excuse for a story-mode, because it isn’t a challenge like the former Arcade mode, nor does it last long – it takes about ten minutes to go through each of these stories. Although Street Fighter was never primarily a solo game, some players might be bothered by this “bare-bones” release from Capcom. But still, the game is mainly targeted as a multiplayer game for playing with friends or online, and for which there’s no lack of modes.

reviewText:
Flowchart Ken's school of tl;dr recommendation:

-Do you prioritise offline single player content? Stay away for now. If you have less than two hours of playtime on Steam, it is possible to refund the game.

-Do you prioritise casual multiplayer (offline or online) with friends? I'd still say recommended... with some caution I will elaborate near the bottom of this review.

-Do you prioritise multiplayer and\or competitive aspect of fighting games? Preferably with the intent of improving your own game? Most certainly recommended... with some caution.

Compared to previous titles and the franchises reputation, Street Fighter V introduces several rather radical changes to movesets and approach to balance as technical layers have been beheaded one by one, favouring good old fundamental babysteps over technical, extravagant and flamboyant balls. Everyone has only one clear set of normal moves as opposed to normals and close normals - the latter only working at essentially point blank range as the name suggests, almost everyone in the cast has an ability dedicated to bypassing or neutralising projectiles outside jumping, many characters' moveset has been drastically changed compared to their previous appearances, heavy attacks can inflict crush counter" which opens up even more damaging combo opportunities for mistimed buttons or missing reversals up close

reviewText:
This new release has amazing core gameplay for pros and newbies alike. The combo mechanic has been simpified while being deep enough to keep pro players interested.

The initial release was very bare-bones but that fact was communicated and the reason for the early release was the pro scene. Pro players don't care much for single player and thus only the core features were included.

Fighting game enthusiasts who want to dive into the game and study the mechanics will have a lot of fun with the game already.
Everyone else should check back later when the rest has been added.

reviewText:
Great game, plays smooth on multiplayer even with most the matches against playstation crossplayer! Lets you decide to allow match making restrictions to 3 bars and up, or 4 bars, or just 5 bar connections (what I do lol) only when searching online. I rarely get lag.

And I run an i5 3570k 4.4Ghz and a 980ti 16gb ddr3 ram and play 4k 60 fps. Textures and effects on max, AA and post processing on medium, and everything else on high and runs SMOOTH :-)

And, the gameplay in my opinion is the most polished of street fighters yet. And yes, I play with an xbox one controller lol! The d-pad on it was meant for the game lol!

reviewText: The core fighting in Street Fighter V is very satisfying. I get the same warm feeling that I had when playing Street Fighter II in the arcades back in the early and mid 90s. If you set your parameters correctly, the online experience can be very good too. It's nice to be able to play in practice mode while queued up for a ranked or casual battle.\n\nIf you want to fight against AI opponents, wait until June when Capcom has said they will release the full single player campaigns. Otherwise, this serves as a good entry point for newcomers to the fighting game genre. It took me around 10 hours of practice to start winning a few battles in rookie and bronze. Now I win as many as I lose but am trying to improve. There is a lot of satisfaction in winning battles and I never feel cheated when I lose.

reviewText:
If you care about single player, don't buy this. You'll hate it.

In it's current state, SFV is essentially a multiplayer-only title. Not having functional servers is inexcusable. It's getting better, but the launch situation was pathetic.

Any yet, I'm giving Street Fighter V a postive review. Why? I enjoy the fighting. I love offline competitive play and training mode. For me, the game is a lot of fun.

I realize I'm in the minority. The negative reviews are warranted and Capcom screwed up big time. BUT. This awful launch will pass, content will come, and the fighting will still be excellent. SFV will (eventually) be a game that everyone can enjoy.

EVO. Pro Tour. I get it. But seriously, Capcom. This launch was a disaster.

TL;DR Single player content is a joke, servers are (were?) a mess. When it works, the gameplay is amazing. The balance is fantastic, the game is tournament ready. If you're a competitive player who wants a leg up, buy it. Otherwise ...? Move along, citizen.

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME FOR THE CONSUMER WHO IS AFTER SINGLE PLAYER CONTENT (AT THIS MOMENT IN TIME)

That said, so far I have only played 34 hours, a mixture of ranked, lobby, and offline play vs my brother and friends, and boy, I am enjoying it more with each session. Play enough online matches and you will encounter some horrific lag fests, but, in my experience, connection issues seem to lessen every time I return to the game.

The roster is well balanced and has a nice mixture of old and new characters, the graphics are very good, the music is excellent, and most importantly, the gameplay is stellar - I think the groundwork is definitely there, and that in time SFV will become a better game, especially when they add more modes and larger lobbies in March.

As mentioned, gamers looking for single player content should wait a few months to see what is added to the game, but if you are looking for a multiplayer game to play online or with friends locally, you could do a lot worse than Street Fighter V.

reviewText:
OK, so I don't usually write reviews but really felt I had something to say about this one because of the mixed response it's been getting from the community.

Personally, I can understand the mixed reviews, but honestly, from my own perspective, this is a really, really good game. Yes, for sure it's incomplete, and I'm looking forward to the full story-mode version coming in summer (which I think will help promote longevity for this game), and yes, I want arcade mode with incrementally increasing difficulty, which I imagine they'll add at some point (but for now I don't think they've made any promises on this? Correct me if I'm wrong).

So, here's the deal. Really, what this game needs is a Dummies Guide to How to Enjoy SFV, starting with making good use of training mode, of course, but also going on YouTube for basic, intermediate, and advanced guides. Learn about footsies, combos, crush counters, and man does this game open up as something you can perfect not just for weeks, or even months, but potentially years. Watch tourmaments on YouTube for inspiration. There's so much you can engage with outside the game that can help you enjoy it more when you load it up.

And I'm serious. I can see this game as possibly dominating the genre for 2, maybe more, years to come.

That being said, again, I understand the mixed reviews, and I think it comes down to what kind of player you are. If your like me, and you can get obsessively hooked into training, perfecting, and really learning the details, I have no hesitation in recommending this game to you. I'm only a few hours in and I know this game is going to be with me at least through summer 2016, almost certainlyu longer, because story-mode will be a great new thing to get into in June. However, if you're the kind of player that likes a story, or plot, or a sense of immediate advancement when you game, then I wouldn't recommend this game to you, yet, and advise you to wait until the summer update.

As for the finer details, the game works fine (I had a problem with needing to unplug my WACOM tablet, but that's all), the frames are silky smooth, the servers are working fine for me, and I'm OK with waiting times for games as I'm happy training while I wait, which is usually around 2 or 3 minutes. I haven't bothered playing the mini-story modes yet.

My personal score at this early stage in my play is 7 out of 10. I imagine this might increase to an 8 or 9 when the summer update drops. Oh, and buy it on Amazon. It's only £22 there, and you get the steam key. For that price, it's well worth it.

reviewText:
inb4 people rate this review not helpful without reading..
Full review for the game. Will be very specific here. If you enjoy reading, you'll enjoy this review lol.
So, let me make this clear. SFV is a game that is getting a ton of hate for its lack of single player content and shakey online server. Don't get me wrong. I'm not saying this is okay, nor am I justifying them releasing this game at this price point. To be fair, I think you should use other specific sites to purchase this game for a lower price. However, I still think this game is worth a recommendation if you're willing to do some legwork and be patient with Capcom.

PROS -
-Crossplay. No matter how small the steam community may get, the PS4 community will probably stay active with this game, which will mean you'll always fine players to play against.
-The games netcode is absolutely amazing! Don't get me wrong. This is not a game where every match will be flawless, but the majority are really good. Don't play on wifi though, and try to play against people in or near your country for the best online experience.
-The roster may be smaller than USF4, but it means a better balance. Varity of play styles. From shoto, to zoning, grappler, semi grapplers, unorthidox characters, etc.
-The game looks good for a fighting game. It's by no means a graphical masterpiece, but it does look good.
-Upcoming FREE content if you choose to get fightmoney to buy this content.
-Easier to do combos. This is a positive in my eyes due to combos being difficult don't really show skill in terms of competitive fighting games.

Cons-
-Biggest con is the lack of keyboard, mouse, and controller support with dinput. This is absolutely unacceptable on launch. How in the world did this game not add dinput support despite also being a PS4 title WITH crossplay? I don't care what you say, this is just not okay. Please, if you have dinput controllers, use either joy2key, xpadder, or x360ce to emulate it to a xinput.
-Lack of single player content on launch. This is not a huge con in my eyes due to this mostly people a really silly complaint to me. Arcade mode may be unavailable, but survival kind of makes arcade irrelevant to me. Story mode is crap, but what street fighter had a great story mode? This is a very minor complaint to me because it's just not as bad as people make it out to be. However, if you don't like multiplayer in a fighting game, don't waste 60 on this.
- Server issues. This is due to its launch, and I give it the benefit of the doubt with it only being day 2, and it receiving way better server management than before. Found many games today that worked fine for the most part.
-Battle lounge is unstable. Can disconnect often.
-Although most character models are fine.. Some just look weird. Mostly Ken's character model. His face looks awful, and his hair looks like bananas (literally).
-Hitboxes on many moves seem shorter than the animations show. This has been a complaint since the beta of the game. This isn't a huge problem. This is just something players have to adapt to.
-Losing the chance to gain fight money due to server issues where you simply cannot gain fight money after completing certain objectives offline.
-Getting kicked from offline modes while online due to server disconnects. This shouldn't even be a thing, especially in survival mode where you're forced to replay the entire survival mode from stage 1 due to a server issue.
-Rage quitters are not punished for leaving games. Ranked games can be saved if rage quitting and preserving your record and points. This is horrendously stupid. This makes ranked ultimately worthless. Penalize leavers, Capcom.
-Stages are in 30 fps. This is due to console hardware having to run stages at 30 and ultimately having to tie framerate for crossplay.
-Some reported glitches regarding characters gaining max meter and v-trigger meter at the start of a round/match. WHAT?!

So overall, I think SFV is a good fighting game for competitive online play. I think it'll be even better once we get the march update, which it's been shown that we'll be getting PC keyboard and controller support soon. This is all amazing, but ultimately, this is an early access 60 dollar title. However, I enjoy the game regardless of these issues. I don't recommend this game if you want a story or single player experience. I do however emplore you to try this game if you wanna get a good fighting game to play for its online. The servers are slightly shakey but are clearly getting better, and will ultimately be even better by this week. Over the year, SFV will be even better with additional characters, a fully fledged story, and other content.
I give it a 8 out of 10 for multiplayer, but a 6 out of 10 for single player content till March.

reviewText:
First I will say this game got ALLOT if sh.it for releasing as basically a MP platform for content to be added later. When June comes and FULL CINEMATIC MODE is added this will be must have fighting game. I will simply put PROS and CONS and make a proper review come June.

SPECS:
i3 3.1
GTX660 2gb
8gb DDR ram
Windows 8.1
Settings medium - 60 FPS with drops to 50 during cinematic finishers.

Pros:
+ Hands down best looking Street fighter game with beautiful animations and finishers.
+ All fighters feel pretty well balanced which needs to be comended
+Servers while not the best at lauch have seen improvement
+ For ME living in SA I have not waited more than 2 minutes to find an online match (May differ from country to country)
+ EVERYTHING can be earned with in game money so no real world money is needed unless you want to spend it.
+ Fighing is hands down the best its ever been!!
+ Added PROPER training mode to help learn moves and combos with visual aids
+ Added 8 player lobbies
+ Small taste at story mode (Maybe just over 1 hour long) to show you whats to come
+ Punishment for rage quiters (Thanks CAPCOM)
+ Cross play for PC and PS4 owners

CONS:
- Small roster at release, 16 fighters plus Alex which has just been added so 17 total as of 4/3/2016
- Story mode was and is a joke until the full cinematic one gets added come June
- Connectivity issues regards less of ping of myself or my opponent

If you want a mainly MP experience then i can say buy it now as its all polished and very good. As for singleplayers add to your wish list and wait until June.

reviewText:
It's unfortunate what people's priorities seem to be nowadays when reviewing games.  I get it, it sucks to be excited and not be able to play online the first day you purchase the game.  But honestly, my experience has been fantastic. I really love the fighting engine, it's got the perfect balance between speed and tactics.  Every hit feels so punchy and satisfying and the netcode is the best I've ever experienced.  Also, cross platform gameplay is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome!

TL;DR:
It's simple. Do you have a dedicated, solid cable modem connection? And do you like the idea of mastering a beautifully designed fighting game? If yes, then this game is definitely worth supporting.


System Specs:

144hz 1080p G-Sync ACER monitor
GTX 970 FTW
i7 920 processor
24gb Corsair Vengeance ram
256 SSD EVO PRO

Cable Modem Connection:
100mb downstream, 12mb upstream, connected through gigabit port. average ping 8-20ms

reviewText:
This game needs work. Alot of work. No DirectInput controller support, so you need to use a 3rd party add-on/program just to get controller support, possibly with input lag. Game is super finnicky with graphic settings and framerate, it's fine in full screen for the most part, but avoid playing in windowed mode unless you have a really beastly PC. Then there's the game itself... extremely barebones unless you really like spending all day in training mode. The online functionailty is a joke, Battle Lounge doesn't even work right, I can't look up Fighter ID's from Steam users, says they don't exist, and battle lounge invites don't work either. There's just not much going for this game until Capcom fixes it. This release is so half-♥♥♥♥♥, I can't get excited at all for this game. It's a real shame.

Graphically, the game looks like ♥♥♥ just like Street Fighter 4 did, but just more high definition. Character models are ugly, completely lack the charm of classic Street Fighter 2D artwork and sprites. Far as 2.5D fighting games go, Guilty Gear Xrd is leagues beyond this game, and it uses an older version of the Unreal Engine at that.

As for audio, most of the character themes and rearrangements are pretty whatever, except for Zangief's theme which actually sounds really good. Character voices are pretty good, in English and Japanese, I'll give them that. HIt sound effects are nice and chunky, very painful sounding, so that's good at least.

Then there's the actual gameplay... honestly, it's Modern" Street Fighter at it's core

reviewText:
After 3 days and noticeable improvements to the servers, I figured it's time to update my review and make a note of what others are complaining about.

To many, this is an unfinished copy of the game and you wouldn't be wrong to believe that, it's unfortunate to see it release without some staple features of the series (Trials, Arcade, etc).
However I must say that there has been plenty of posts in gaming news and social media expressing the fact that the contents of the game will be more barebones at release to have the game ready for the Capcom Pro Tournament, and so players should have been more critical as to whether or not they should buy this game.

I figure I would summarize some of the issues people have been experiencing from my readings on the community hub and over other sites relating to discussion of the game, if any of this would deter you from purchasing the game in its current state, that's your decision to make.

- The game (currently) contains minimal single player content (Training, Local PvP versus, the Pre-Story episodes and Survival) and is more geared towards the online aspect and getting people prepared for the Capcom Pro Tournament.

- Although I previously stated the servers have been improved, this is not to say they're not perfected, this can be jarring when you are trying to complete a Survival run and are cut off at your feet because you disconnnect from the game servers.

- Some people have expressed their concerns about having a smaller roster than Street Fighter 4, with this game currently having only 16 characters on release and another 6 coming as DLC which can be obtained free (Costing 100,000 Fight Money each).

- Funnily enough although this game is exclusive to the PS4 and PC, the game does not currently support Playstation hardware (Controllers, Fight Sticks, Fight Pads, etc) and contains support and button prompts for XBOX controllers. This is coupled with the fact that people choosing to play with the Keyboard cannot currently customize their controls, these two facts are rather concerning and have been acknolwedged by Capcom who is aiming to amend this issue in the first update, as for now you will just have to use a third party program to get your controller to work.


If you can stomach that and are looking for a really solid fighting game, I would personally reccomend it. A lot of the new and returning characters feel fantastic with the games larger windows for combo links. There is also less of an emphasis on charge mechanics which may have intimidated newcomers, which could be seen as a pro or a con for certain players. The new netcode for the game is amazing to experience when playing against someone with a good connection and is currently the best I've experienced (I unfortunately won't be seeing MKX's new netcode any time soon :(  ).

There is a really good game to be found here which may have potentially had its reputation tarnished by a terrible launch, with the teams at capcom aiming to give us something new with PC - PS4 crossplay (which mind you also works really well and gives players a larger pool of opponents).

As future updates roll out I would like to encourage players to consider changing their reviews once the game has fixed any issues they may have had with the game at launch.

Thank you for reading and I hope you take what I have tried to convey here to heart and take your time with deciding if this is the game for you.

reviewText:
I have devoted well over 4000 hours into the multiple versions of Street Fighter 4 (  Raptr Profile for Proof[raptr.com] ) on various accounts.  I’ve spent thousands of dollars on peripherals, attended numerous local and regional tournaments, and developed a healthy case of arthritis/carpal tunnel in the process.  I think it’s safe to say that I feel uniquely qualified to weigh in on how this new game stacks up. Street Fighter is by far my favorite game series, and sadly this latest iteration is the sorriest excuse for a Street Fighter game, let alone a fighting game, that anyone has ever been subjected to...

The blatant and clearly intentional omission of content, the lack of stable online play, and a crystal clear (but luckily failed, for now) attempt at a money grab are all inexcusable.  You can barely call this worthy of being considered early access and that is a HUGE step backwards for the series.

After the masterpiece that 4 became online, Street Fighter 5’s online experience is the worst online I've encountered IN A VIDEO GAME, let alone a fighter where timing and fluidity are PARAMOUNT.  No filtering for fights by region.  INSANE and GAME BREAKING rollback on moves during matches.  TERRIBLE menus that DO NOT FUNCTION months after release.  These are all completely and utterly inexcusable in 2016.

If this was Street Fighter 4 on release, I would have been STOKED, but this is STREET FIGHTER 5.  A game that follows one of the most competitive fighting games of all time, ULTRA Street Fighter 4.  WHY THE HELL WOULD THEY START OVER SO FAR BACK?!  Oh that's right, to sell the characters and modes we really want back to us using their STILL non-functioning zenny store for real cash.  All of this while raking in the money from their sponsored tournament series that is the entire reason this game was released in this state in the first place... I'm SICK over the greed behind this game and you should be too.

It makes me so sad.  Capcom, you let us down and I’m not talking about Ono.  I know he loves this series with a passion many will never know.  It’s the corporate fools and investors that forced this abomination upon us, I’m sure completely against his wishes.

I loved this series!  I loved the fighters and how they all had unique style and charm.  I loved the systems in 4.  The unique ways Ultras worked in conjunction with Supers and EX moves to give you multiple paths to crushing your opponent.  In 5 the game's only decent feature is the actual fighting, and it is still one dimensional and uninspired when compared to 4.  Throwing what worked in 4 away almost entirely and starting over with stubby, nonsensically hitboxed moves.  There is almost zero UMPH and the sloppy, stale, and recycled animations do little to ease the pain of playing this game for longer than an hour at a time.  I could lose myself playing ranked matches in 4 for 8 - 10 hours in a blink.  This is just not that game...

The character models are NOT an upgrade to 4 despite the engine change, and in some cases 4 looks equivalent or BETTER.  WHAT THE F CAPCOM?  Blurry textures, uninspired backgrounds, locked FPS, lack of PS4/PS3 stick support, boring repetitive music (RAASHHIIIDOOOO?!?!?! WTF?!), and the list goes on...

For me, Street Fighter 5 is now the most disappointing game release I can remember.  I know they will probably get there with whatever iterations they decide to add over time, but the way this was released felt more underhanded than Daikatana for N64.  I will never forget this.  I will NEVER trust another Capcom product, and I will not be playing this game until it settles into what it was truly meant to be.  DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!

I will keep tabs and update as I go but for now this is one of the worst games to play online, period.  And trust me, there isn’t much to do offline to save it from itself.  Disappointing is not the word.  Soul crushing, greedy, and completely tone deaf are more appropriate descriptors, and even those feel hollow in the face of what we truly paid 60 dollars for.  Sorry Capcom, I know this might not be what you intended, but my trust has been shattered… Never again… :(

reviewText: Core gameplay is great, but the lag and netcode ruins its online experience. There's nothing more frustrating than successfully landing attack, only to realize a split second later that the game rolls that back and you're the one stuck in the middle of a combo. I mostly just play in the battle lounge with my friends since I know the connection will be okay. It's just disappointing that such a solid game's online experience is plagued by latency issues.

reviewText:
Updated Review : Street Fighter V

Street Fighter V is an excellent fighting game, with many characters surprisingly being well balanced at launch. The game had a tough start due to server issues and missing content, but now as the March update rolled in; it has now become a little more fleshed out and has fixed most of its problems.

The game is really fun for fighting game enthusiasts, it will however take time to learn for beginners to learn how to actually play the game. You have to out think and out play your opponent, you have to work for a win or you're going to die... and quick at that too.

The incorporation of unique V-Skills" and "V-Triggers" really makes every character in the game unique and will require you to actually learn how to counter those things.

This game is definitely a must buy if you're a fan of any fighting games
date: this one is absolutely fantastic. Sure it still has some missing content
recommended:
but it's fun nonetheless.

Pros +

+Trial Mode (learn characters)
+Unique Character Skills
+Beautiful Animations
+Great Fighting Mechanics
+PS4 and Pc Cross play

Cons -

-No Arcade Mode
-Takes a while to find ranked matches
-Weak Story (Free Cinematic Story Update in June)
-Lots of Rage quitters
-Too many people complaining
-Too many people not wanting to learn the game

Final Verdict:

Street Fighter V is a great fighting game

reviewText:
If you can log on and if you can find a match and if the netcode gods smile upon you SFV is a fantastic game. It's now day 4 and the servers are still borked, battle lounges don't work, ranked doesn't update, there's no penalty for rage quitters, the connection filter doesn't always work, the down time between matches is Herculean.
The game is great but it's hamstrung by an abysmal and broken backend that is both convoluted (CFN) and somehow also lacking basic features that other FGs like Guilty Gear have (8 man lobbies and a rematch button to name two) and should not have been launched in this state.

If it gets fixed I will alter this review accordingly and I thought it was fair to give them a few days at least before giving it a thumbs down but as much as I want the game to work and be enjoyed by new and old players it simply doesn't function in a way most people would find acceptable right now.

Edit: Capcom fanboys out in force I see. I encourage anybody considering buying this to check out the @SFVServer twitter and see for yourself how many issues the game has been having.

People need to know when a game isn't working anywhere near intended, get a life and stop defending piles like this. I can play Super Turbo on Fightcade for free with much more ease and stability than SFV and its implementation of GGPO is better.

Stay free people who think Street Fighter is the only fighting game ever made and think Capcom can do no wrong.
